<question>



Were any of you given steroid shots for lung development?  If so, what wk. and how long after did you deliver?



I was given the steroid shot yesterday and am 34wks today.  I have to go back today and get another one.  The dr said that they don't give them unless they really don't think you'll make it to full term.



Any insight would be great.  I'd like to make it to at least 38 weeks.  I'm having really strong and painful bh contractions.  But, I'm not dilated at all. (Which is great)!



</question>



<answer from>



ncshrty0...
Member since: 16 April 2007
Total points: 6879 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was admitted into the hospital at 32 weeks for premature labor, where they insisted on sticking a needle into my bottom (steroid shots)lol, for 3 days and put me on bedrest for the remainder of the pregnancy.
I gave birth a day before 35 weeks... so I lasted 3 weeks, and although my baby was small, 5 lbs, she did good and didnt have to stay in the hospital any longer than necessary.
I had dialated to about 2 cm on my premature stay in the hospital, and was having regular contractions for a month, and then when my water broke on THE DAY, I was admitted with 3 cm. dialated, not enough for the epidural and then hopped to 10 cm. in about 30 minutes after given pitocin to stimulate regular contractions.



Source(s):



a beautiful very healthy 2 year old



</answer>

<question>



Is this acid reflex or is he allergic to formula?



my son is 2 months old and has been spitting up alot he also always sounds like he cant breathe right. his nose is really stuffy. he also gets really stiff and mad as you know what after eating.  he cries most of the day and lot of times i can't get him to stop. so i took him to the doctor and he said he has acid reflex. he gave him some medicine but it doesnt seem to be doing anything and just recently got a horrible diaper rash. he cries bloody murder every time i change him. the doctor also told me to change his formula i use to have him on a hypo allergen formula but now he is on enfimil a.r. for babies who spit up.  also for the past two weeks he has been pooping after every feeding and at least twice in the night (he sleeps through the night but wakes up pooping) it is really bad smelling to.  i mean i know baby poop is not the greatest smelling but my other two kids didn't have anything like this and i am at my breaking point with him.  so should i put him back on the formula i was using i did not have hardly any problems with the diaper rash or pooping until his doctor changed it.



</question>



<answer from>



Iggy rocks
Member since: 28 September 2008
Total points: 1563 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



that does sound a bit odd...my little man was formula fed from birth and only pooed 1 time a day and  it was always firm and never upset him!  maybe try him on soy formula?  my brothers had problems with normal formula and as soon as my mum tried soy they were great! if he has reflux, elevate his mattress a little, my little man had a few chest problems and would get phlemy and we just elevated his mattress slightly and it works wonders...I know that it helps with reflus as well!!  good luck, and change his formula again though as he really shoudlnt poo that much on formula! its normally a lot harder!!



Source(s):



Aussie mummy of Iggy 17 months



</answer>



<answer from>



Jacob's Mommy
Member since: 15 June 2006
Total points: 19772 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yup, that is acid reflux alright....maybe the medicine isn't right or maybe you have to give it some time. My son was diagnosed with that at 1 month and has been on Tagament since July 3 times a day. We just recently cut back to twice a day because he seems to be getting better.



The pooping is not normal though that that does need to be addressed....try going back to his regular formula first though.



</answer>



<answer from>



golfgirl...
Member since: 20 May 2008
Total points: 4506 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



He may have acid reflux, but also if his sinuses are blocked, it may be hard for him to swallow formula.  I would clear his nose before you feed.  Also, the bad pooping is a result of the switch in formula.  It will get better, just give it time.  If he was allergic, you would see really bad rashes around the mouth and on his body not diaper rash.  That is from the pooping.  Just keep the area clean and put rash ointment and light powder.



</answer>

meppa30

<answer>



Your daughter is under 2 years with a high temp, she needs to be seen and ASAP, kids under 2 even if they have a mild temp need to be seen because it means they have an infection or an illness and they have a lower immune system and might need medication to help fight off the bug. It could be tonsillitis or an ear infection and you can't see it. If the medication isn't helping then you need to get help now.

<answer from>



Iggy rocks

</answer from>



<answer>



just give her a bottle until she latches on to the boob again!



its better for her to at least eat, than just let her have nothing...she must be starving, maybe your milk has dried up or taste weird...did you change your diet??? just give hera  bottle with express milk if you still have milk...



Source(s):

</answer>



<answer from>



Mellie
Member since: 26 June 2007
Total points: 287 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's possible she's going through what's known as a "nursing strike".  This is where something is bothering her about the nursing (maybe she's starting to teethe, maybe something startled her last time she nursed, etc).  Pump some breastmilk to be sure that she's still getting her nutrients, but don't stop trying to nurse.



Babies who are on a nursing strike are more likely to start back up if you try to nurse them while they are sleepy, or if you do things to encourage closeness - for example, take a bath with her and let her cuddle next to your skin.  Also, you might want to try wearing her in a baby sling so that she's close to you and can smell your milk.  Don't stop trying to nurse her though.



Google "nursing strike" or call your local La Leche League for more information!



</answer>

<question>



Can newborn babies breath underwater right after birth?!?



I've been wondering this for two years now, and I was under the impression that they could, simply because my Jr. year economics teacher said they could, he's a really smart man, so I was just wondering..?



</question>



<additional details>



I did graduate, and i know they can with the umbilical chord... I'm asking with out, I'm pretty sure I got my answer though.



What??? Nobody finds this topic interesting?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Army Wifey
Member since: 10 January 2007
Total points: 1415 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Since they are in amniotic fluid they can make the transition into water during the deliver. Since they have not been exposed to air they are still receiving oxygen through the umbilical cord.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thankyou mommies for all your answers. They were all pretty much the same, but army wifey worded it best.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



MUMMY to LIL gorgi ADDYSON♥
Member since: 02 December 2007
Total points: 5039 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



No they cant breath underwater, no human can, unless there is an unblicical cord or an oxygen tank attached. When babies are born underwater they are still using the umblical cord and placenta to breath just like they were in the uterus, once they hit the air then they take their first breath, I dont think your teacher is that smart



</answer>



<answer from>



Him ThatIs
Member since: 10 June 2008
Total points: 493 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



They can swim a bit. There was a study on this. They don't breathe yet because there is no air in the womb. There are organic plugs in the nose that must be removed, and the air supply is delivered via umbilical cord. After the child is born the doctor will spank it once to cause it to cry, this oddly enough, starts the breathing process.



</answer>



<answer from>



xxicyfla...
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 174 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



they cannot breathe under water, as no human can, but the reflex to breathe in when hitting air does not happen because they are still in water. as long as the umbilical cord is attached, they are technically still on the mother's oxygen supply.



</answer>



<answer from>



Maddie M
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 465 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



no. when a woman gives birth underwater, the baby does not breat in the water right when he comes out. when the baby first comes out it has never breathed air before, so it does not even try until it is pulled out of the water.



Source(s):



mommy



</answer>



<answer from>



queenroc...
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, babies can breathe underwater while they are still attached to the umbilical cord which gives the baby blood and oxygen from the mother. It also is living in the amniotic fluid so baby is used to liquid.



</answer>



<answer from>



Christin...
Member since: 27 November 2007
Total points: 6307 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Only if the umbilical cord is still attached. It's how they do water births. Once the cord is cut and the baby starts screaming, no. They need air at that point, and being submerged in water would drown them.



</answer>



<answer from>



katieee....
Member since: 19 September 2008
Total points: 259 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



as long as the umbillical cord is attached, the baby should be able to breathe.



</answer>

My kids are 5 and 10 now and I still carry and use baby wipes!

Did you have any problems having sex after having a baby .. did your partner complain about it  ? <answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hi, don't feel bad for asking this question! For me, I changed emotionally much more than I changed physically. A woman's emotions change after having a baby, and this affects her desire for sex. Don't be surprised if you feel numb to the idea of intercourse for a while...even a long while. Physically, you have NOTHING to worry about when it comes to being loose. That's not the case after having 1 baby. I never did one kegal (hate those- they feel wierd!) and I'm not only tight as can be, but able to have multiple orgasms now & I'm much more sensitive. Be careful the first few weeks after resuming sexual activity- your husband needs to understand that your body needs time to heal itself. If you rush things, you'll both regret it in the long run. Men just don't have a clue, do they!!! Good luck :)



Source(s):



myself!



</answer>

<answer>



You'd actually be surprised. I'm pretty darn tight down there at 4 months PP. We have noticed a spot further back in my vagina that is more prominent than before. With regular intercourse I'm sure we can work that out and I can get past the discomfort, but we just have to find time to have regular intercourse.



Our first struggle was getting past my episiotomy. We attempted sex at 8 weeks, then were successful at 10 or 11 weeks.



I felt loose in the beginning because I noticed while taking baths that water more easily got in me. My husband even noticed it looks more loose on the outside, but that was contradicting the inside lol.



I have to admit to you that getting "in the mood" is more difficult for me. My fear is not pleasuring him physically, but mentally. Same for myself. I want to enjoy it but sometimes I feel as if I'm just doing it to make him happy.



Just take it slow, and maybe it would help both of you to have a couple glasses of wine beforehand. I was recommended this by my aunt to help with pain to make me more relaxed. It could also help with the intimacy. We never tried it but I still consider it. We just don't really ever drink anymore.



Good luck!

<answer>



<evaluation>Answer hidden due to its low rating</evaluation>



"does it go back to normal down there after 6 weeks or will i never be the same down there"



Suffice it to say Yahoo! Answers has a high percentage of women with magical vaginas. It is statistically unlikely to ever be the same.



Childbirth is in general a disaster for the pelvic floor; you have about one in a hundred odds of becoming fecally incontinent...



You may be able to exercise your way back to some semblance of normality; you may not.



</answer>



<answer from>

Total points: 3073 (Level 4)

<answer>



They don't poop 50-60 times a week, more like 20-30 when they are a newborn. My son when he was first born pooped 3-4 times a day.
Breastfeeding can cause breast to sag a bit, but if you take good care of them and wear a good supporting nursing bra then it shouldn't be too bad.

<answer from>



Rose
Member since: 23 August 2006
Total points: 2509 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Newborn breastfed babies CAN poop really often - my son was feeding every two/three hours in the first week, and filling his diaper with every feed.  However, they can also go several days without having any bowel movements (experienced this with my second) and if they are totally breastfed you don't have to worry about constipation.  When it comes it is still soft.  Either extreme is normal for a breastfed baby.
About the boobs - research shows that any stretching etc. is going to happen during pregnancy, and your boobs aren't the same, but neither is the rest of your body!  A mother's body is a bit different, but no less sexy!  As someone said, wear a decent bra that fits while breastfeeding and it will be fine.
I recommend you and your husband reading "So That's What They're For" by Jan Tamaro - it is a really funny book about breastfeeding, but has all the facts you need. (Might do his buddies good too!)



I think the guys were just being guys, but honestly, they could use some actual facts like - the precise size of your wife's boobs vs a healthier, smarter child!



Source(s):



mother of 3, breastfeeding councellor



</answer>

<question>



How long should you wait to call the doctor?



Hi everyone. My daughter is 5 months old and yesterday she came down with a low fever. I have given her tylenol and is brings it down to about 99.5. Within 2-3 hours of giving her tylenol, her temp goes back up to 100.5-101. It hasnt been 24 hours of this yet, but just wondering if I should go ahead and call the doctors today or wait it out until tomorrow. Thanks for any good advice.



</question>



<answer from>



igglepig...
Member since: 09 December 2007
Total points: 881 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If in doubt always call the doctor - sorry to scare you but I have heard some awful stories of babies dying in the night after being put to bed with a temperature, If i was you I would call the doc : )



</answer>



<answer from>



Pinky*
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 615 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Is she teething? Most of the time when babies teeth they get a low-grade fever thats why I am asking. If it doesnt go away soon than I would call a doctor.



</answer>



<answer from>



asusan48
Member since: 19 October 2008
Total points: 339 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would definitely give the doc a call, if only to put your mind at ease.  She may be teething - that often causes a low-grade temp, drooling, and diarrhea (due to excessive saliva going down their throat).



Any breakthrough fever (one that breaks through a medication given to stop a fever) should have a doc's attention.



Source(s):



Mom of 3 that were pretty darn sick as babies!  :-)



</answer>



<answer from>



bitalin1...
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



As a single father to a 4 month old little boy, I have the doctor's number on speed dial. Even if it turns out to be nothing, they'll have up-to-date accurate information and be able to help you through whatever the problem is quicker and more efficiently.



More than likely it will turn out to be nothing, so don't get alarmed... But in my personal opinion it's always better to be safe rather than sorry.



Hope this helps, and I wish you & your daughter the best :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Pooh Bear Fan
Member since: 26 March 2008

Lindsey

<answer>



I would call the docs to make sure but its probably nothing but a virus.  I always find my self waiting to call the doctors until after hours and wind up in the emergency room.  I'm pretty sure that a fever is ok at this age until it gets to 103.0. But i ALWAYS feel more comfortable to hear it from the doctors.  My seven month old has had quite a few fevers. One at three days, One at three months and one last week. But if there are no other symptoms they are more than likely to just say that there is nothing they can do. ( this was the case last week it turned out to be a virus that lasted about four days)



And also, it really depends on which doctor you talk to about a fever when teething some say its possible some say that teething will not cause a fever.



Source(s):



mommy to a 7 month old



</answer>

<question>



Baby Keeps Crying PLZ HELP!?



I have a baby that is almost a month & a half old and she will not go to sleep (she hasn't slept in almost 7 hours) and just keeps crying.  She will fall asleep when I am feeding her;, but the second I put her down she wakes back up and starts crying again.  I've made sure she has a clean diaper, she's been fed, and snuggled.  I just have other stuff I have to do around the house, but I can't do it while holding her all the time.



</question>



<answer from>



justme
Member since: 01 November 2006
Total points: 13937 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



If she is falling asleep while you are feeding her, she probably hasn't burped right? I would guess she has gas. Try to keep her awake while she is feeding and burb her every 2 oz. or so.



</answer>



<answer from>



speechy
Member since: 16 July 2007
Total points: 14170 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



i agree with making sure your baby has been burped.
then try swaddling to make your baby feel snug and secure.
you can always call your pediatrician and talk to a nurse, not that I think your baby needs medical attention, but the nurse may be able to give you advice on what to try.



</answer>



<answer from>



sarah
Member since: 15 July 2007
Total points: 456 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



feed



burp



swaddle



and swing.. its like magic.. my baby would sleep for 3 hours at  time in his swing..  goodluck.. i would also advise you to watch



the happiest baby on the block video. it helped tremendously.



</answer>



<answer from>



K-Suds
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 636 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



This could be colic, it's very common and usually starts in the first 6 weeks of life.  It's thought to be caused by painful bubbles of wind caught in the bowel and can be very distressing for a new mum.  You should talk to your health visitor or equivalent about this.  Does your baby draw her legs up when she cries and does she go red in the face with a high pitched, pained cry?  These are signs of infant colic.



Infacol is good for dispersing trapped gas, but it can take a few doses to be effective...(UK)



Talk to your health care team if you are very concerned.



Good luck....x



</answer>



<answer from>



x-x yummy mummy x-x
Member since: 02 November 2008
Total points: 93 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



she is getting used to falling asleep on the bottle or breast. my son did this and i was advised to put him down after feeding him and wake him up this sounds awful but by rearranging his nappy he would stir a bit then i would swaddle him and put him down to sleep. its important to put her down awake and she will learn good sleep association rather then always relying on 1 method to fall asleep i.e feedork in the ing, rocking. these always work in the short term but not in the long term. your baby needs to wake up and remember the they fell asleep there and they will go back off themselves in the night aswell. i ididnt believe this would work at first but my 4mth old now goes to sleep. at first the crying will last up tp 1 hour, just go to the cot every 15 minutes and pat her reassure her and hen leave, after a few weeks (and its exhausting) you will be able to put her down and off to sleep she will go!! this works for day naps too. hope this helps. also try colic drops if you think this may be the case and talk to the doc if still no success!good luck!x



Source(s):



my own exhausting baby! nd the book silent nights by Bryan Simon



</answer>



<answer from>



spunky96
Member since: 12 September 2008
Total points: 421 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It could be a few things.  First it could be colic which is gas and very uncomfortable.  Try mylicon drops for that.  If shes fed, and has a clean diaper and you suspect nothing else is wrong with her then just put her in her crib and let her cry herself to sleep.  It may be upsetting or annoying to deal with at first but she will learn to put herself to sleep eventually.  If shes falling asleep while you feed her maybe shes isnt getting enough food and is hungry.  Make sure while feeding her you try your best to keep her awake by talking to her.  Set a regular feeding schedule and sleep schedule, maybe that will help.



</answer>

I lay in bed at night and when i know my  partner and son are fast asleep i cry and cry and cry

<answer>



how do you know its not postpartum depression?  Just because you are most upset in the evening?  Its natural for you to feel more depressed at certain times of the day.  As a depression sufferer myself, i often had the most problem in the evenings.  Call your doctor back and ask about postpartum depression.  It really sounds like it to me.  You will do your family a better service by taking steps to make yourself feel better than ignoring this.  I am sorry your doctor blew you off, because he of all people should be able to support you in this.  Maybe you just need to try to talk to him again.

Amber E

</answer from>



<answer>



Hon, it definitely can be postpartum depression, even though you feel it most at night. You just put your body under tons of stress to get your baby here, and now you are using all your energy taking care of her. It is totally normal to feel overwhelmed and a little sad or cooped up. But this whole cyclical crying, reaching out for help, and crying this is not normal, and you need to tell your doctor or your man how bad it is. There are so many options for you to get help, but you can't pursue any of them until you admit this to someone.



Please, please, please tell someone near you and get the help you need. You will feel soooooo much better!



</answer>



<answer from>



K-Suds
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 636 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



This sounds very like post-natal depression.  If you are in the UK you must talk to your health visitor about this, or see your doctor.  This is soooo common and the chances are that a course of anti-depressants will make you feel vastly better.  Talk to your partner, tell him how you are feeling.  Please don't suffer in silence as you are most definetely not alone in feeling like this.  Your hormones are all over the place after the birth of your baby and your moods are often the first thing to suffer, the pressure of a new baby is enormous and it is perfectly natural to feel overwhelmed by the enormity of your responsibility.



You are right in thinking that something is wrong that you cant fix alone, get the help you need and deserve and I honestly believe that if you do this you will feel massively better just from confronting your fears and asking for help.



Good luck and congratulations on your wonderful new addition. xx



</answer>

<answer from>



Mama Bean
Member since: 31 January 2008
Total points: 4714 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



sounds like classic postpartum depression, which is normal, common and totally treatable. my advice, call your doctor right now. not tomorrow, not next week, now. schedule an appointment to discuss what you're feeling and take the next step from there once you have looked at your options. Be honest don't just say "I feel a little overwhelmed." They can only help if they know what is wrong, and they will not judge you. I suffered with bad post partum depression for almost 3 months before I even hinted to my doctor that this way happening, and I regret all the precious time I lost feeling that way when I could have spoken up sooner. Now I am on a low dose of antidepressant and talking to a counselor twice a month and the difference is amazing. I feel so much happier and confident being a mother, and I rarely let things pile up the way I did before. Please please call your doctor right now!



</answer>

Member since: 05 May 2007

<answer>



I wish I had known:



1. Never feed your baby to sleep.
2. You don't have to change the baby everytime he wakes up at night.
3. Keep the lights dim when getting him up to feed at night.



We have a lot of sleep issues and I wish I had done some research about sleeping beforehand. Now, my number one piece of advice to new moms is to research baby sleep issues before they are born so that you have an idea what you're going to do when problems arise.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



My 5 Wk Old doesn't take entire bottle but acts hungry again soon after?



My son is 5 weeks old. I offer 4 ounces of formula which he rarely takes all of, however he acts hungry again soon after but won't take any more of his bottle. He's also a bear to put down and KEEP down for a nap. He'll sleep as long as someone is holding him but as soon as you put him down he's awake & crying.



My mom is recommending a little rice cereal (I know what the doctors say). Could it be that he just doesn't like his formula and I need to switch it up? Any suggestions welcome!



Thanks in advance for your help.

<answer from>



dumpling...
Member since: 21 December 2005
Total points: 52487 (Level 7)



</answer from>

<answer>



babies this age like to cluster feed.. meaning eat many times.... this is because of the nursing instinct... if a baby nurses more often more milk comes inthe mother's breast... since you are formula feeding it is possible he's just trying to cluster feed the bottle??? who knows..



don't try rice cereal yet, it can cause constiption and might cause digestive problems later if introduced too early



babies need to eat and feeding on demand is not unusual.... I know it gets tedious but obviously your baby is self regulating his feeds and knows how much he wants to eat and when... which means he won't over eat [usually] if you introduce rice cereal that may mess up his inner "measuring" system



</answer>

<answer from>



Rachael
Member since: 12 January 2007
Total points: 3494 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



If he won't take any more of his bottle, he's not hungry again.  It's probably a problem with his formula.  Ask his doctor before switching him, but he might need to go on soy formula.  Also make sure he's burped properly during and after his feeding.  At 5 weeks, he still needs to be burped after every ounce or so of formula.  Do NOT give him rice cereal.  That will only make his tummy problems worse.  Newborns can't digest rice and it can give them very painful gas.  At 5 weeks, he needs to be drinking formula not only for nutrition, but for hydration.  If he's full of cereal, he won't want a bottle and risk becoming severely dehydrated.



Try swaddling the baby tightly when you put him down for a nap.  This can often trick a newborn into thinking he's being held and help him sleep better.



Source(s):



Mother of two.



</answer>



<answer from>



susanliz...
Member since: 06 December 2007
Total points: 283 (Level 2)



</answer from>

Babies this young have a natural need to suck. The sleeping is pretty normal to. If there are things you need to get done than I would suggest a carrier of some sort.



Source(s):



own experience

I learnt my lesson when number 2 came round.  i laid her in her own crib from day one, awake.. now at 19 months she can get laid in her bed and put herself to sleep without me having to rock her, or hold her. much better for everyone, even her.

<answer>



A very balanced diet is key, follow the food pyramid! Drink lots of water. As far as exercise...I started back into things really slowly. I first started walking about 1 mile everyday. Soon I added 45 minutes of cardio dance exercises (I love the crunch DVD series). Finally I added 15 reps from each of my total gym stations. After about 9 months I had close to what my body used to be, I still have a "baby pouch" at the very bottom of my stomach, I hate it! I think all those skinny celebrities have Liposuction after they have babies because no matter how much you work out there is just no way to loose all that "baby belly fat" in 8 weeks, it is impossible! They make us all feel like there should be nothing to losing the weight, but it is a very difficult thing to do! I wish you luck!

Pregnancy & Parenting



Newborn & Baby



</category>



<question from>



thumblin...
Member since: 13 December 2007
Total points: 266 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Breast feeding question?



i have been breastfeeding for about ten weeks or so and it feels like some days i dont have enought to offer my son i supplment during the day from 630 to 3 because i go to school but the rest of the time hes nursed and i dont nurse in public and the past couple days we have been out and about so i didnt nurse as much did my milk decrese and why does he get fussy and wont take the brest sometimes



</question>



<answer from>



Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 31225 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



Are you pumping while you're at school?



If you aren't, that means you're regularly going 8 hours without pumping or nursing -- longer if you are routinely giving bottles in public.



That can definitely cause your supply to drop.  (And if he's getting lots of bottles AND your supply is dropping, he's probably refusing to nurse because he had learned that the bottle is where his food comes from.)



Advice:
1.  If you aren't pumping during the day, you MUST do so.  8-9  hours is just too long to go without nursing.  If it's not possible to pump, then you will need to nurse VERY often in the evening and during the night to keep your supply up. (Your breasts can usually adapt to one long stretch, but not 2.)



2.  Learn to nurse discreetly in public.  It's easy to do, and will help keep your supply up.



If you keep up your current pattern, your milk will dry up/baby will refuse to nurse, and you'll be 100% on a bottle within a couple of weeks.



</answer>



<answer from>



HouseMom
Member since: 09 January 2007
Total points: 1497 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



HOnestly, if it were me I would just nurse in public. If your baby is hungry, the opinions of people who don't have a clue come second; baby comes first. Find a quiet, out of the way place and put a blanket over you. You might be surprised - some people might not even know you're nursing.



Have you tried pumping? THen you wouldn't have to supplement and you can increase your supply because demand is increased. If you're not nursing as much, your supply could go down, or the letdown reflex is delayed, and he gets fussy because he's used to the automatic letdown of milk from a bottle.



Source(s):



mom of 2, 19w with #3



</answer>



<answer from>



Meg
Member since: 07 August 2008
Total points: 394 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's a matter of supply and demand.  If you nurse less often, your milk supply will decrease.  Is it possible for you to pump between classes?  That would help!



</answer>

<answer from>



klilkimb...
Member since: 22 September 2008
Total points: 221 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



ok by cot do you mean crib?
There are several philosophies on this...I think it just depends on what works for you.



You can co-sleep for awhile--which they say helps with bonding.  Or keep the baby in a bassinet/cradle in your room.



I plan on putting my baby in his crib right away and getting him used to the crib (whether or not this will work...I do not know.)  But his room is right next to mine, so it's not a big deal to me.  I don't really buy the whole bonding thing with co-sleeping.  I think my baby will be better off getting a good sleep routine right off the bat and mommy will be better off as well.  We will be bonding all day and during night-time feedings.



I think it is all a matter of what works for you and for the baby.  Every baby is going to be different, so we can't necessarily predict when they will do everything or what will work best.



</answer>



<answer from>



Isaiah 40:31
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 111 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



My kids were in their own rooms at 4 weeks. I used a good baby monitor after that. There is no required age before you move babies into their own rooms. It is whatever you are comfortable with. You have to be able to sleep also, so that you can be the best for your baby. Be careful to not take so much advice from people that you do not listen to your own instincts. God gave us women a natural ability to be mommies. Trust yourself.



</answer>

Kimberly

<answer>



I think it all depends on the parent. If you can have a baby monitor on at night and wake up within seconds of your baby crying (i do and it gets annoying sometimes when he has a bad dream) then you can put the baby in its own room once you get home from the hospital. A lot of people keep them in bassinets next to their beds because it just makes it that much easier to change them, feed them and back to bed as soon as you can. I would say once you feel you have gotten caught up on your sleep change the baby to the crib in his room. You will get better sleep once you don't hear your baby moving next to you.



</answer>

mybabyis...
Member since: 31 October 2008

<answer>



I registered 3 1/2 months before my due date.  You don't want to do it too early because baby products are constantly changing.  You don't want to have a bunch of stuff on your registery that was discontinued, and you don't want to miss out on registering for new stuff that comes out.



Registering is so fun!  I loved it!!!  Take a good friend or sister or your mom with you.  It's more fun that way.  And be prepared to spend the whole day at the store - take snacks & water in your purse.  It took over 3 hours for me to register and I already pretty much knew what I wanted from looking online.



</answer>

<answer from>



inwardbo...
Member since: 18 April 2007
Total points: 1741 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well that means that your other boob isn't getting sucked as much as the other.  Make sure you're taking turns.  Because, that leakage is the more rich stuff.  So, when this is happening make sure you express the milk out because it is a waste.  I hated the pads getting soaked than my shirt would be wet.  So it's best to have disposable ones and ones you can wash as well!



So say morning feeding suck on the left boob, than 2 hours later, suck on the other boob, vice versa!



</answer>

Member since: 20 November 2007

<answer>



Its normal, if you want to save the milk for any reason, try breast shells, they collect all the leaking milk and keep you dry!!



They dont leak anymore, but I used to take spare breast pads out with me. (also get washable ones, theyre better for your breasts and youll save lots of money!)



EDIT; if shes only a week old, dont worry, your milk comes in strong at first, once your body has figured out how often she feeds, itll regulate the milk supply and they wont leak as much.

<question from>



newcastl...
Member since: 20 March 2008
Total points: 520 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Not enough milk to breast feed. Any way to produce more?



My little boy is 11 days old and I have been trying to breast feed. I tried just the breast until the third day. He didn't have any wet or dirty diapers since the merconium on the first two days. I tried to get him to latch on and feed for the first 15 minutes of every feeding then gave him a bottle so we would get SOMETHING in him. I started to pump, but I am only getting about 3 ounces a day. I don't know what else to do to produce more milk. 3 ounces isn't enough and I really don't want to formula feed him exclusively. Any tips?



</question>



<answer from>



nothingc...
Member since: 03 March 2006
Total points: 22780 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Politics



Elections



</answer from>



<answer>



fenugreek in capsules at GNC



Oatmeal



http://www.babycenter.com



Awesome site with a breastfeeding section.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lisa
Member since: 01 August 2007
Total points: 8393 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



You definately need to contact a latch league or breast feeding clinic to help you.



The first thing they're going to tell you is to stop offering him the bottle.  If you're serious about breast feeding him, you need to get him to take the breast before you introduce the bottle or he'll just take the bottle, it's easier for him.  Sure he may not be successful at first, but that's okay.  Both Mommies and babies need to learn how to breast feed, it is not an easy task!



The more he physically nurses from you, the more milk you'll make.  Keep yourself hydrated and eat lots of healthy meals.  Rest when baby rests.



If you really want to top him up, use a cup or something to tip it into his mouth.  You really don't want him to get nipple confusion.



Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Elyse's Mommy ♥
Member since: 23 June 2008
Total points: 4014 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



My advice is to get a lactation consultant and work on your latch.  Baby was not getting enough milk because you both were not latching on correctly and stimulating the milk to come in.  At 11 days you should avoid a pump and fenugreek is not needed at this time.  Call your hospital ASAP, they have them on staff.  If you explain the diaper situation they will come right away.



Giving the bottle on the third day has totally confused the infant and for your milk to be able to come in properly you need the baby to nurse, not a pump.



</answer>



<answer from>



Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 31247 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



Call a lactation consultant. Now.



The pump is not a good indication of how much milk you have. You need expert, hands-on



help to figure out what the problems is, and how best to solve it.



</answer>



<answer from>



I♥Y!A
Member since: 16 March 2008
Total points: 1818 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



just keep nursing him.  for some mothers and babies breastfeeding doesn't come naturally.  just keep him on the breast and encourage him, he'll get the hang of it gradually.



pumping is not necessary, it doesn't accurately reflect what the baby gets out, the baby's sucking is more efficient (and natural) than even the most expensive breast pump.  so give the pump a rest and practice with your baby only.



leave the bottle alone for about 4 weeks until baby is established with breastfeeding.  the way milk comes out of a bottle is different than how it comes out of your nipple, so that might mix him up a little bit.



i breastfed for 1 year, just fully weaned 2 days ago.



** at 11 days old, you should have a ton of milk, it's in there, even though you may not feel it, i promise...
drink a lot of water, before and after nursing.



Source(s):



good luck and congrats on the new baby.  Congrats on breastfeeding as well.  it gets better!



</answer>



<answer from>



sleepyhe...
Member since: 21 December 2006
Total points: 2998 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Tip from my breastfeeding consultant:  Offer your breast to baby everytime they are hungry, then offer a bottle AFTER if you feel they are still hungry.  Baby is only 11 days old so stick with it and your milk will definitely grow.  It's too early yet to tell and most women give up at this point, so don't fall into that trap.  Keep on with what you are doing and eat lots of oatmeal and get Mothers Milk Tea.  That has fenugreek in it that stimulates milk production.  There are also capsules.  What also helped for me is to stay hydrated with water and gatorade (lime and orange flavor).  For some reason those helped me make a lot more milk.



EDIT:  The hospital gave my baby a bottle right off the bat and due to my C-section, breastfeeding was a hard and arduous task.  The baby was nipple confused but she quickly got over the "confusion" the more I put her on the breast.  I totally understand what you are going thru and don't feel that it's too late cause baby got confused with a bottle early on.  They do get over it, as long as they are still little and you keep at it.  Good luck and God Bless.



</answer>



<answer from>



Rachael
Member since: 12 January 2007
Total points: 3504 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Nurse him all the time.  It will cause you to produce more milk over time.  Even if he's not getting much from you, try latching him on for at least 15 minutes every hour.  I know that seems like a lot, and it is, but that will help your body get a better understanding of the demand and boost your milk supply.



Also, make sure you're well-hydrated and not extremely stressed when you're trying to breastfeed.  Anxiety often interferes with your let-down reflex.  So try to sit, kick your feet up, take a deep breath and relax while you nurse the baby.



If you still have milk now, there's not reason you can't make more.  Keep trying and good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



whatruki...
Member since: 07 April 2006
Total points: 2146 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is a common problem.  First - many moms think their baby will starve that first couple of days if they don't supplement.  Not true.  This is the beginning of the problem, because once babies feed with a bottle nipple, they find out that it is so much less work than the breast, and we lose them forever :-(



First, drink TONS of fluid.  You cannot produce milk if you are not hydrated.  Second, be sure to eat a well-balanced diet.  You need carbs, protein, and fruits and vegetables.  Finally, be sure you are getting rest when the baby is resting.  Stress or lack of sleep can definitely affect breastmilk quantity/development.



You are supposed to wait several weeks before pumping milk, but since you have started, then try pumping every time you feed your son.  This way, you begin to teach your body what the demands are for breast milk.  The more you demand, the more your body produces.  As your son's appetite increases, you will be increasing your own production as well.



Finally, if you really want to breast feed exclusively, then once your milk development has increased, try to wean the baby over to breast feeding only.  It may be difficult for sure.  If he won't do it, then at least you'll have plenty of breast milk to feed him instead of formula.  They get used to the flavor of formula eventually, and then they reject breast milk then too.



Oh - and one other thing, talk to your pediatrician about mixing breast milk with formula.  My daughter did that for two whole months with her son, and that seemed to help the baby not have to adapt to one or the other!



God bless you and your baby!



Source(s):



Learned the hard way when I took my son off of breast feeding after three days.  He never would breast feed after that, and I dried up very quickly.  With my daughter and her son (she lived with me the first six months after the baby was born), we put together this strategy and it worked very well.



</answer>



<answer from>



mammak
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Firstly, you need to see your health nurse and get into a lactation consultant. They are brilliant. They will have more tips and advice than you could ever need! Right now though you should make sure you drinks plenty of water (no less than 2.2lt a day) and eat really well. Your body needs the fluid to produce milk. You can increase the frequency of pumping as breast milk is made on a supply- demand system. The more you pump more often the more you'll produce faster. When you pump or feed make sure you empty the breast so that it fills completely instead of just making a small amount of replacement milk. The other thing you can do is stop worrying! Your baby will fine no matter how he gets fed - breast or bottle, the main thing is to enjoy every second.



</answer>

<answer>



ok... your milk didn't come in until day 3-5.... your bby would not have have a poopy diaper until after your milk came in... are you sure the diapers weren't wet? remember the commercial diapers are very absorbant and the small amount of pee breastfed babies do at a few days old may not look like alot or may "look"like none....



Stop the bottle... it will cause your milk supply to go down...



your milk has come in by now... you need to nurse on demand.. meaning let your baby call the shots.....
your baby gets more than 3oz a day... pumping is not as efficient as a baby breastfeeding....
stop formula
only nurse
on demand
as often as baby wants
stay for longer than 15 mins on each breast
have baby finsih one breast, then offer the other
pump after baby is done to stimulate your body to produce more milk



stop formula you may cause yourself to lose your milk
your milk is in by now and you should be able to feed your baby,



call a lactation specialist at your hospital or through la leche league [llli.org]



here are some links to help out



http://llli.org
http://kellymom.com
http://askdrsears.com



is bby getting enough milk?
http://www.askdrsears.com/html/2/T022600...
http://www.llli.org/FAQ/enough.html
http://www.llli.org/NB/NBmilksupplyissue...



remember breastfed babies also go through times of "cluster feeding" meaning they will want to nurse all the time... this is normal... it will the stimulation of sucking will stimulate your body to make more milk.... cluster feeding is normal and does NOT mean you are not producing enough



by introducing the bottle this early it is possible he may reject breastfeeding because it does cause them to work harder for the milk than a bottle...



stop the bottle and just breastfeed!
if you want to be able to continue nursing....



get ahold of a lactation specialist

<question>



My daughters injection site?



My daughter got her 6 month shots yesterday and her leg is red and theres a knot under the redness. Im going to call the dr tomorrow if its still like this but I was wondering if its normal or if anyone has had any bad outcomes if the injection site looked like this. She doesnt have a fever or anything but it is sore when its touched even lightly. Thank you :)



Here is a picture of it.
http://s52.photobucket.com/albums/g20/lu...



</question>



<additional details>



she has a little fever now 100 i just gave her moe tylenol. But the dr says 100 is normal for shots so she will be fine Im sure thanx for hte answers so far :)



</additional details>



<answer from>



Rachael
Member since: 12 January 2007
Total points: 3504 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



That looks pretty normal.  My kids always get spots like that when they get their shots.  One of the shots, I think it's the DTAP, seems to cause a lot of redness and some swelling.  It's pretty common.



Try alternating warm and cool compresses and Tylenol to keep her comfortable.  As long as she has no fever and no serious swelling (like the whole leg) she's probably fine.  But take her to the Dr. if you're really worried about it.



</answer>



<answer from>



mommy of a 7 month old!
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 119 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just massage the area gently, and place cool rags on her injection site! My daughter def. had this problem, and that's what her doctor told me to do. Also, try giving her tylenol every 4 hours, unless your doctor told you not to! It will help with the swelling and ease her pain a bit.



</answer>

A question for parents who are AGAINST the CIO method, and those alone?



I am completely with you on that, I could never nor will never let my son 'cry it out' for my own benefit, I won't ramble on but I just don't agree with it.



Anyway, for the last few months it's been tough getting my now 10 month old to go to sleep - it can take up to 2 or 3 hours in the evening, and now he's waking up in the night again it leaves me very little time to do my work that I need to keep up with as I'm studying a degree from home. I'm a single mum so don't have anyone else to rely on. Anyway I've got so used to the routine of trying to get him off to sleep after his bedtime bottle that I don't even attempt to leave the room any more as I know he always screams the second I do. However two nights ago I needed to quickly nip out the room after he'd finished his bottle as I was desperate for the loo, so I kissed him on his head and shut the door (the light was already off). When I came out of the bathroom, all was quiet, so I waited outside the room for ages and could hear movement at first and then eventually he went silent, so I went in and checked and he was fast asleep! So last night I thought I'd try the same - I kissed him on the head and went out the room, he burst into tears for 5 or 6 seconds and then instantly stopped again, and went to sleep soon after. I know the crying is just tantrum that I've left, and there isn't anything actually wrong, but I just feel SO guilty that I've left him and he knew that when he cried I didn't come back even if it was only for a few seconds. However he gets to sleep so much faster than he does when I'm in there with him, and also it gives me a couple more hours to get work done in the evening which is precious! So I just wanted advice from parents who are AGAINST crying it out - do you think this is acceptible? I could NEVER leave him to cry for an extended period, not even a couple of minutes, I just don't believe in a baby crying himself to sleep, but as I said this is just 5 or 6 seconds and then he starts playing in his cot and then eventually drifts off by himself. Would you do this or would you go in the second he cries?



Please don't answer if you are pro-CIO - I have no interest in hearing your opinions, thanks.

<answer>



I am against the crying out method if the baby is screaming crying...when the baby is crying because they are sleepy-it is time to let them cry-a few seconds or a few minutes is not horrible and is better for you and the baby-as long as he is feed, diaper is changed, and you spent some loving time with him, then if you need to let him cry for even a minute and falls asleep that is what he needs!! Just now (I am a single mom too but I live with my parents) my baby girl was crying so hard and I couldnt figure out why-I had to take a rest since it was over 30 minutes-i put her down 30 seconds later she fell asleep. My dad said this...babies dont always want to be held all the time, especially when they are sleepy. I think the CIO is when parents get confused on when to do it-if they are fussy or tired-its time to let them settle themselves-but if they are truly upset about something-and you know-you need to be there for them. Remember babies cry for a reason-if they are sleepy-they dont know they are and they feel strange so they cry-I would say its alright to do this-as long in my opinion if he isnt CRYING for 5 minutes straight-if he is fussy or just moving-i wouldn't do anything. 10 months old....its ok do this do for a few minutes as long as you know he isnt so upset and just sleepy.

<answer>



im so anti CIO.



take the bedtime bottle away. teach him to go to his cot and fall asleep on his own. i had similar problems and this solved my problems. establish a good solid routine.. my routine is -



5.45pm - dinner



6pm - bath with sleepytime bubbles and massage with lavender bedtime cream, then PJs on.



6.20pm - her fave show is on



6.50pm - we have a 9oz bottle, then read a story. if i see she is falling asleep on the bottle i take it off her.



7pm - she plays till she starts tiring.



7.30/8.00pm - she tires, we say our goodnights, kisses and cuddles etc. she gets the toy she wants for the night then i put her in her cot.



i put her lullaby light show on and give her a dummy.



i leave the room. she whines on noticing im not there and stands up.



i go back in right away, shhh her and lay her back down.



i do this continually till she is sleeping.



night 1 took 20min of in and out.
night 2 took 15min, night 3 took 10min and night 4 took 5min.



by night 5 she realised it was bedtime, mummy wasnt taking her out of the cot, and it was ok because if she needed me im straight back in there. so she goes to bed feeling secure and bedtime is a nice time, not a time to be scared and left to cry.



once she was used to this, i stopped taking her into our bed in the middle of the night, this was harder. i dont this as i done before. but she would cry, but i would cuddle her as she was standing in the cot and spoke to her, but she did not get out of the cot. i stayed awake with her till she fell asleep, i was right beside her and she knew i was there.



again, after a few nights she learned there was nothing to be scared of. now at 15mos, she is in her cot for 12hours a night. she wakes but self soothes.

<answer>



I gave my baby following food.



One bowl of rice washed in water, dried in shade, gentle roasting  in  pan, coarsely grind in a mixer.
One bowl of Moong dal ( an typical Indian pulse), same procedure as that for the rice as mentioned above.



Mix both the things together and use it in the following way.



Take three to four teaspoons of the mixture and then cook it in about 150 ml of water along with carrot or cabbage or tomato with soem salt to taste, till the things turn soft.  Add some butter of ghee to it at the time of feeding. This gives almost completer nourishment as it is a rich source for protein, starch and vitamins.

<answer>



The best bottles are Dr. Browns or playtex airvent which reduce gas and help with colic, but really any bottle that is BPA free is good. As far as nipples go, if you are breastfeeding then, go with the NUK silicone nipples, because they simulate a nipple so the baby does not get confused between the real nipple and the bottle.



</answer>



<answer from>



Colton's Mommy
Member since: 18 August 2008
Total points: 150 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



lol parents choice... the nipple is more important.... in my opinion... i got a set of Soothie's at my shower and my kid hates them.. so i have $60 of bottles i'll never use!



</answer>



<answer from>



troublem...
Member since: 28 January 2008
Total points: 279 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I used the Breastflow bottles by First Years. They are the closest to breastfeeding. I nursed for the first 6 weeks and then due to a medical condition I had to switch to formula and these were the only bottle my daughter would take. They were the only ones that she did not spit up everything with.



</answer>



<answer from>



Addison
Member since: 27 March 2008
Total points: 442 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It can really vary from baby to baby.  Don't stock up on one particular brand until after your baby is born.  You may have to try a few bottles before you find one that works well for your baby.  Some bottles that work great for other babies, may leave your baby with gas, or may be hard for your baby to drink from.  Buy a few types of different bottles.... and see what your baby does well with.... then go out and buy some more.



Personally, we found that the playtex vent air (wide) worked great for us.  We used wide because that's what is recommend for nursing mothers.  IF your not nursing.... then it won't matter if you buy regular or wide as much..... but I am no longer nursing and I still purchase wide just because I think they work great for my son.



</answer>



<answer from>



lyndseyg...
Member since: 30 May 2007
Total points: 9112 (Level 5)

<answer>



I used a lot of different bottles, but Playtex Drop-Ins were by far the best. You can push the air out of them so no gas... They are extremely convenient to use while traveling. I am pregnant again and due in Feb. also and without a doubt will be using the Playtex Drop-Ins. I breastfed and my son had no problem switching back and forth. He rarely spit up and when he did it was only a tiny amount. He was a very happy baby, not at all colicky or gassy.



The only downside is having to buy the liners, but Wal-mart has a generic brand that fit the Playtex bottles that are a little cheaper. And In My Opinion well worth the money.



</answer>

</question from>



<question>



Differerenct between colic and accid reflux?



my son is 14 wks whats the difference between colic and acid reflux and whats the best thing to give to get rid of it



</question>



<answer from>



mommy of a 7 month old!
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 114 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ok, my daughter was really  bad colic, and also had acid reflux (GERD) her doctor told me to put rice cereal in her milk, which helps reduce spitting up, and also cuts down on feeding, because usually colic babies want to eat 24/7 because its only a temporary fix. Her doctor explained



that when a baby is colic, they think they are hungry, but it only increases the pain! I would try the rice cereal, and also they make something called Gripe Water. It helps also!



</answer>



<answer from>



mommy068...
Member since: 08 May 2008
Total points: 428 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



all I know is acid reflux is where they spit up alot and colic is where they cry alot. if they are doing both its probably acid reflux bc the spit up hurts them bc is is acidic, my son has it and we had to put him on a formula with more rice cereal in it to keep it down and try not to give too much acidic like orange juice or tomato sauce.



</answer>



<answer from>



Purrr
Member since: 25 August 2006
Total points: 2113 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I believe colic is where the baby will cry for hours sometimes at the same time every day. It's not proven that it has to do with gas but the chances are it is.  Peds. will give you meds to calm the baby down, but really Colic is something babies just grow out of.



Reflex is where the milk is not digested and will come back up and the baby will spit it out, thus losing weight. For reflex the best thing to do is burp the baby alot in between feedings.  Also, give the baby woodwards Gripe water, it helps with the digestion. Or call the ped. and they will prescribe something....



</answer>



<answer from>



dumpling...
Member since: 21 December 2005
Total points: 52503 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



reflux is where they spit up,colic is when the wind that hasnt been brought up with burping ends up in the bowel and needs passing the other end



Source(s):



nurse



</answer>



<answer from>



littlebe...
Member since: 24 October 2006
Total points: 1761 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You need to speak to your health visitor or gp.  My baby has reflux.  They first suggested SMA Staydown, however, it was much too thick in his bottle and he couldn't drink it.  They then prescribed me Infant Gaviscon which I put into his bottle.  Its brilliant and really helped him.



</answer>



<answer from>



mystic_e...
Member since: 21 October 2006
Total points: 94124 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



Colic means that they can not find a cause for the baby's pain.



Reflux -or more properly GERD is when a baby has more reflux than is normal and it causes pain.  (Normal reflux is GER -no D as its not a disease)



The best thing to deal with both colic and GER is lifestyle changes.  Increased holding is very effective for both.  As is paying more attention to when and how much you feed baby, what position they are in during and after feeds, etc.



GER: WHAT IT IS; WHAT TO DO; FAQ's
http://askdrsears.com/html/10/t106004.as...



COPING WITH COLIC
http://www.askdrsears.com/html/5/t051300...



</answer>

<question>



When can a baby sleep on their tummy?



sigh...I feel like I should know this, I have 3 kids.



My baby is 9 months old, and she insists on sleeping on her tummy. I flip her back several times a night, and she rolls right back over. LOL. We co-sleep and I have had to move her into her own bed, because we have a mattress topper, and I don't like her face-down on it.
When is it safe for her to be on her tummy?
Thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



only1bub
Member since: 19 December 2006
Total points: 3317 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It's definitly safe right now. :)  Once they can roll over themselves, it's not a concern AT ALL. :)  She's well past that.  With a mattress topper - you've done the right thing putting her in her own crib.  It's about this age I made my son sleep in his bed all the time - I would always sleep with him on my arm so he wouldn't roll, & about the time my arm gets really numb from the weight is when they have to go in their crib all the time. :)



Source(s):



http://parenting.ivillage.com/baby/bslee...



</answer>

<answer>



As long as you put your baby down on her back, she's safe to sleep any way up she chooses - i.e. the moment she can roll to be face down she's safe to sleep that way. Stop wasting your time and disturbing her sleep patterns flipping her - how would you like it if someone did that to you every time you got comfortable?



</answer>

<question>



My baby won't sleep? Can you help me?



I have a 6 month old baby and he doesn't sleep at all. I have asked our pediatrician and she keeps telling me to sleep train him. And I've tried that. But the thing is he doesn't sleep during the day or night. And if he does, it's 15 minutes here and there. Then maybe if I'm lucky he sleeps 45 minutes. Then at night he hardly sleeps at all... I don't understand whats going on? Did/does anyone have this problem and what did you do for it?

<answer>



i had this problem up until a week ago lol.. what i did was move the crib into my room. the baby would only sleep any length of time in bed with me so now with the crib in here he sleeps 7 hour stretches lol.... but make sure hes exercising alot. my 6 month old sleeps 12 hours a night now not in a row!

<answer from>



Jen D
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 154 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



First make sure he is nice and full before putting him to sleep ... 2nd I know this sound extremely cruel but it works ... let him cry himself to sleep for up to 45 mins ... do NOT go in and interrupt him unless he sounds like he's choking or something horrible, this will tire him out, build his lung and it is PROVEN that a baby that cries himself to sleep sleeps more sound! After awhile he will cry less and less each night! ....Also my baby sleeps for 12hrs at night and 3 during the day! BUT only if i have country music on and some what loud to ... try that ... good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



Emily T
Member since: 22 February 2008
Total points: 196 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its difficult my boy was like that but he is fine now at 11 months. day time i wasnt too bothered with but night times i suggest you try and resolve first.
before he goes to bed bath him play with him or read him a book with some calm music. you have probably tried these but i suggest you stick to one strict bed time routine! 8pm nath was in bed by at 6 months every night no acceptions and now he goes down about 7pm and sleeps right through till 7/8 if im lucky. just keep doing the same thing over and over, and when he wakes up in the night keep him in a dark room, cuddle him for a bit then put him straight down and leave him, if he cries go back and do the SAME again. over and over and over, keep doing the same things!! i cant stress that enough. he will get it sooner or later. goood luck. x



</answer>



<answer from>



carrieir...
Member since: 12 March 2008
Total points: 405 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You have to be willing to let him work it out on his own. You don't have to leave him there screaming for hours, but he needs to learn how to fall asleep on his own. Have a bed time routine. My 7 months old has always been bottle, bath, lotion, pj's, soft baby music and bed. We do this every night so she knows when it's time to start settling down to sleep. Also, make sure he doesn't need a special kind of formula (hypoallergenic) as this gas can cause colic and result in discomfort and zero sleeping. Good luck!



Source(s):



being a mama :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Rissa
Member since: 24 April 2006
Total points: 618 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I've had this same problem with my 2 yr. old and some of my friends have gone through this with their young toddlers and all of them told me about and swear by giving my daughter a half of teaspoon (crushed up) of "Melatonin" either in some food or drink and that will get them right to sleep and on a normal routine..Melatonin is actually a normal thing produced in your body but some people have lower levels of in which they dont sleep. So this natural sleep aid regulates that for you...its also something you can just go up to any store and get; in the pharmacy area..and if you want more info. or have any questions about it you can talk to them about it...I did, and they told me that it was fine for babies and kids as a natural sleep aid. Hope this helps and Good Luck!



Source(s):



Friends and family with kids,
http://www.med.umich.edu/1libr/yourchild...
"Part about Melatonin on that website"
What about medications to help my child sleep better?
Research has shown that behavioral treatments (in other words, parents using good sleep time strategies) work better, and have longer lasting effects than medicines.  If your child needs more than a behavioral program to help them fall asleep, you may want to talk to your child’s doctor about trying Melatonin.  When used under the direction of your child’s doctor, Melatonin can be a safe and effective treatment for kids [10], and is especially useful for kids with special needs who have more troublesome sleep problems [11,12,13].



Melatonin is an over-the-counter medication in the U.S. But even though you do not need a prescription to get it, be sure to talk with your child's doctor to find out whether it is appropriate for your child, and how to use it safely.



</answer>



<answer from>



Stacy B
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 103 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Answer hidden due to its low rating</evaluation>



Hi,



I think the most important thing to start with is to get your baby into a good sleep routine.  I had massive problems with getting my 4 month old son to sleep.  He would just lie awake and cry for hours, then when he finally went to sleep he would wake every hour or two hours through the night and cry again!  Talk about pulling our hair out .... we were absolutely desperate for sleep!



It was a baby sleep audio program recommended by a friend that finally saved us. We followed the advice and began by creating a baby sleep routine which included bathtime, dimming of the lights, putting James into his crib, final nappy change and then lullabies. We also made recommended changes to his naps during the day and used some of the other recommended techniques. Within two weeks he was sleeping through the night most nights with just the odd night where he would just wake once!



Definitely start by creating a good baby sleep routine though and you could find that solves most of your baby sleep problems.



Good luck!



Source(s):



If you want to take a look, the audio program is at http://www.babysleepsolution.com



</answer>

<answer>



Sounds like way too little nursing and too much food.  Up till a year a breastfed infant's calories should be max 25% from solids - the majority should be breast milk.  Elyse is also 7 months.  She nurses about 6-8 times a day plus two 5-6 oz bottles of expressed milk while I am at work.  We introduce food once or twice a day - sometimes she eats a bite, sometimes she doesn't.  It's all practice up until a year - your baby needs your breast milk, not more solids, that is why he is waking up to nurse more.



</answer>

<question from>



heathern...

</question from>



<question>



Why can't you give egg whites to babies?



Every meal idea I have read says use the egg yolk only for my 11 month old. Why is this? Thanks



</question>



<answer from>



Josephin...
Member since: 08 September 2007
Total points: 1980 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



allergy food



</answer>



<answer from>



Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 31279 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



Egg whites are highly allergenic. (Most people who are allergic to eggs are allergic to the whites.)



However, recent research has found that routinely avoiding allergins in older babies (babies old enough to be eating solids at all -- 6 months+) does NOT reduce the odds of allergy.  So current advice says that, unless there is a strong personal/family history of allergy, there is no need to hold off on egg whites.  (Many books/websites have not yet been changed to reflect current research.)



</answer>



<answer from>



Luv my kids 4evr
Member since: 18 May 2008
Total points: 1248 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Egg whites can harbor traces of harmful bacterias such as salmonella that an adult's body is able to digest without any issues, however, babies have much more sensitive digestive systems and these traces of bacteria can make them seriously ill.



</answer>



<answer from>



ryleah20...
Member since: 31 March 2007
Total points: 4234 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is because of allergans.



I gave my kids egg yolks for a while, starting at 4-5 months, and they were eating whole eggs by 7-8 months. We have no egg allergies in our families, so I spoke to our health nurse, and she said it was fine. So did my ped.



</answer>



<answer from>



I ♥ my thumbs down fairy
Member since: 21 December 2006
Total points: 29926 (Level 7)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



pippin is right, I wouldn't worry about it. my baby has been eating the whole egg since about 7 months, we have no history of allergies in our family



</answer>
