<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Newborn & Baby



</category>



<question from>



~~Baby#2...
Member since: 21 November 2007
Total points: 864 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Please read I need advice in a hurry...!!!....?



So I have a friend who literally smokes a bowl of pot then nurses!!!! She says that it doesn't get into her breast milk. But I say it does,who is right?? What are some things to tell her to get her to stop this, like possible effects of doing this???



</question>



<answer from>



mystic_e...
Member since: 21 October 2006
Total points: 94134 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



http://www.babycenter.com/404_is-it-safe...
There are few published reports on the effects of marijuana on breastfed infants. Some studies suggest that one-time use of marijuana leaves only minute amounts of THC, the active component in marijuana. THC is fat-soluble, which means it builds up in the body with chronic use. After a breastfeeding mother uses marijuana, THC is evident in her baby's urine and stools (Perez-Reyes and Wall, 1982).



Any secondhand smoke the baby is exposed to increases the amount of the drug he receives. And animal studies indicate that marijuana may suppress lactation. It stands to reason that an infant exposed to large quantities of secondhand smoke could become too lethargic to nurse. The combined effects of less breast milk and less suckling from the infant could further depress the mother's milk supply and create problems for the baby.



http://medicalmarijuana.procon.org/viewa...
Susan J. Astley, PhD, Professor of Epidemiology at the University of Washington, and Ruth E. Little, ScD, Researcher at the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, wrote in their article "Maternal Marijuana Use During Lactation and Infant Development at One Year," published in Mar. 1990 in the journal Neurotoxicology and Teratology:



"Very little is known about the effect of postnatal marijuana exposure on infant development. Postnatal exposure can result from maternal use of marijuana during lactation. Delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) transfers and concentrates in the mother's milk and is absorbed and metabolized by the nursing infant.



The present study investigated the relationship between infant exposure to marijuana via the mother's milk and infant motor and mental development at one year of age. One hundred and thirty-six breast-fed infants were assessed at one year of age for motor and mental development. Sixty-eight infants were exposed to marijuana via the mother's milk. An additional 68 infants were matched to the marijuana-exposed infants on pre- and postpartum maternal alcohol and tobacco use.



Marijuana exposure via the mother's milk during the first month postpartum appeared to be associated with a decrease in infant motor development at one year of age."



http://www.kellymom.com/health/lifestyle...



Separate from the direct, chemical effects of marijuana on a baby, use of marijuana may affect a mother's ability to be able to properly care for her baby. Maternal judgment may be impaired.



Any secondhand smoke the baby is exposed to increases the amount of the drug your baby receives. Also, because street drugs are rarely pure, marijuana may be laced with other drugs or substances that can also be harmful to the breastfeeding baby.



The active ingredient in marijuana, THC, will be stored in mom's fat tissues for long periods (weeks to months) and will build up in the body with continued use. Small to moderate secretion into breastmilk has been documented, and THC is concentrated in human milk. According to Hale, analysis of breastmilk from chronic heavy users indicated an eight-fold concentration in milk compared to mom's blood plasma, however the dose received by baby was insufficient to produce significant side effects. Studies have shown significant absorption and metabolism in infants, although long term effects have not been shown.



Marijuana can cause sleepiness in the baby, which can lead to slow weight gain and possibly slow overall development in the baby long term. In addition, babies whose mothers smoke marijuana regularly have a higher risk of SIDS.



Hale reports a possibility of decreased milk production. In animals, THC decreases the amount of milk produced by suppressing the production of prolactin and, possibly, by a direct action on the mammary glands.



There is significant brain growth occurring during a baby's first months of life; marijuana may alter brain cells. Animal studies (on babies whose mothers' milk contained THC) have shown that DNA and RNA metabolism may also be affected and the proteins needed for proper growth and development impaired.



After a breastfeeding mother uses marijuana, THC is evident in her baby's urine and stools (Perez-Reyes and Wall, 1982). Infants exposed to marijuana via breast milk will test positive in urine screens for long periods (2-3 weeks).



One study (Astley and Little, 1990) found that exposure to marijuana through their mother's milk during the first month of life resulted in decreased motor development at one year of age. In another study of 27 infants evaluated at 1 year of age who were exposed to marijuana via breastmilk (compared to 35 nonexposed infants), no significant differences were found in terms of age at weaning, growth, and mental or motor development. Follow-up of these infants has been limited.



Long-term effects of marijuana exposure through breastmilk are unknown.



</answer>

at birth, my first one was 8lbs13oz...19 days later she was 9lbs7oz so that is a total weight gain of 10 oz... and she was fine, no concern by the doctor...



</answer>



<answer from>



Bow2some
Member since: 11 July 2006
Total points: 4931 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I breastfed my son exclusively too.  He was 8 lbs. 6 oz at birth and 8 lbs when we left the hospital.  At his one week checkup he was 8lbs 4 oz and at 2 weeks he was 8lbs 9oz. My doctor also told me that breastfed babies tend to gain weight slower, which is not necessarily a bad thing.



Most babies lose weight during their first week and then get back up to their birth weight by the time they are two weeks old. Since he is over his birth weight, your Pediatrician is probably right that he is growing just fine.



Also, newborns usually gain about two-thirds of an ounce each day. So if he was 6lb. 7oz. at about 4 days of life, then he gained 6 ounces over the next 7 days, which is still well within normal expectations.



If your really concerned check with your doctor. But he sounds healthy and happy to me! :)



Good Luck & God Bless! Congrats on your little one!



Source(s):



Chit chat from the Mama of a wonderful 18 m/o Boy Jaxon Pierce.



</answer>

<question>



Am I being completely selfish?



I'm really upset right now.  I just had a huge fight with my husband over the phone.
I did a post about this situation last week and received a lot of great feedback.  Although I took some of the advice and it has backfired on me.
My husband's family lives about 3 hours from us.  We live in the same city as my family.  I'm due tomorrow with our first baby.  I don't think I'll be having the baby tomorrow though!  His mom wanted to come stay with us for the first week our baby is here.  Like we are to call her as soon as I'm in labor and she will come right away and then stay for a week.  I've never wanted this...I wanted alone time with my husband and baby.  But I knew there would be World War III if I didn't go along with it.  So reluctantly I said yes.  That was several months ago.



As I've come closer to my due date I've really thought about how I do not want her here.  I understand she wants to see the baby...but couldn't she wait a couple weeks?  Drop in visitors I am fine with...in house guests for a week immediately following the birth of my first child...not exactly something I'm thrilled about.  I had told my husband all along that I was not thrilled with this idea but that I would go along with it as to not piss anyone off.  Well now I'm about to give birth and am more concerned with my own well being.  I just got a call this morning from the doctor's office to schedule my induction for next wednesday.  I called my husband and told him.  He immediately calls his parents and then calls me back to say, "They will be coming on Wednesday, is that okay?"  I hesitated and said "Okay, that's fine."  So since he knows I'm not crazy about his mother and father coming here (the plan is for his dad to stay a couple days, his mom to stay a week) he says he knows I'm not fine with it.  I just told him again how he knows I'm not fine with it but that I don't really have a choice since I already agreed to it.  This then leads to how all I'm thinking about is myself...his parents are so excited to see this baby and I'm going to deny them of that...why don't I tell my family that they can't see our baby at all.



I just want time alone with my husband and baby after giving birth.  I don't want houseguests.  But I'm only thinking of myself right now according to him.  It's his baby too.  I just feel like he's trying to make his parents happy instead of me.  Am I being a total jerk?  I shouldn't have said anything...I should have just gone along with it.  Now he's probably called them and totally trashed me and it'll be even worse.



To make matters worse today is his birthday.  He said to me thanks a lot for ruining my birthday and the birth of my child and then hung up on me.  I'm just so upset.



</question>



<additional details>



Just to add---my mom and 2 sisters live 5 minutes from me.  I don't need her help nor do I want it (gosh that sounds totally rude!)

<answer>



You are not selfish. Your wish for intimacy is very understandable.



But before you get too wound up on this: When you have a new baby, family staying with you is not there as bothersome house guests but as unpaid serving personal. With your new little angel in your arms and the physical exhaustion from birth, you won't have the time nor the energy to clean, cook, do laundry, get groceries etc. That is why they offer you to be there. They are going to work for you, not steal your time.



</answer>

<answer>



You may not like this answer, but you may want to take a few things into consideration.  If you MIL is going to help with cooking and cleaning, then it may be good to have her there.  If she is the type who expects you to cater to her, then put your foot down.  My mother had to deal with her stepmother and MIL in the house when I was born, and both of them expected her to do all the cooking even though she'd just had a baby!  My MIL stayed with us shortly after my daughter's birth, and I couldn't have done it without her!  My husband was just as tired as me and drop in guests were fabulous, but having someone there consistently to manage the visitors, food, etc. was a godsend!  My husband and I honestly just stayed in our bedroom most of the time bonding with our little one.  It was GREAT!

<answer>



You're in a tough spot and neither of you is totally wrong. <question from>

<question>



Weight question............?



Do you think genetics play a big role in weight??



Is there anyone out there with a big mom and dad that is skinny?



is there anyone out there with a small mom and dad that is big???



</question>



<answer from>



SpeshalB
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 292 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think genetics play a huge role but you have to look further than just the parents. You need to look at the grandparents and extended family.



My husband is a huge guy but his dad is small and so is his mom. But his grandparents and ancestors were big people.



I am a big girl too (close to six feet) and with my huge husband I had a six lb daughter that is now the skinniest thing (although she is tall). The second baby is also just on the very average side. So only time will tell if they turn into incredible hulks like us.



Oh I am taller than my dad and my mom!



</answer>



<answer from>



Luv my kids 4evr
Member since: 18 May 2008
Total points: 1250 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



My mother is heavyset by choice.  She doesn't like to exercise and has a love affair with high fat foods.  I am skinny by choice, I enjoy being active and practicing portion control.  I don't think genetics has much to do with it...but heavyset parents will set the tone with eating habits and activity levels which is why obesity seems to run in families.  It's an optical illusion of sorts.



</answer>

<answer from>



Mystic
Member since: 12 February 2008
Total points: 1453 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sorry to say....but just because the baby dropped, doesn't mean labor is imminent.  Sounds like you are having Braxton Hicks...which is good to get your body ready for labor, but doesn't actually start labor.  At 37 weeks you could have up to 5 weeks left (let's hope not!) and since you haven't told us of any other signs of early labor, I would just say relax, and let your baby set its own time table.



Source(s):



My daughter dropped at 37 weeks; gave birth at 39 weeks.



</answer>



<answer from>



Noah's Mommy & Marine Wife.
Member since: 08 October 2007
Total points: 46045 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dropping has nothing to do with when you'll go into labor. My baby dropped around 34 weeks and I still carried him to 39 when I was induced. Sorry to say but you could still go FULL term(40 weeks) or past your due date.



</answer>

<answer from>



lildevil
Member since: 12 August 2007

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



i had my son 10 days early



my best friend was due febuary 14 had him october 26 at 24 weeks preg he weighed 1 pound 10 oz and was kept in the hospital till at least his due date (thats like four months) was on oxigen till he was something like 6 months or more...his eyes are verry sensitive to sunlight and he is only about as far along as a nine month old ( he just turned a year old)  he also has a patch of underdeveloped skin on his side that will never fully mature.



he had heart surgery at six days of age because it was not completely developed yet i think.



he is one year old and still smaller than my 10 month old...... when my ten month old was nine months on october 2 he weighed 19 lbs when hers was a year old on oct 26 he weighed 19 lbs



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thank you !! I am glad everything worked out



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Tanya
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 455 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



All my 3 babies were late.  All natural but 2 were induced.  However I have a couple of friends who have had premmies.  One had both her babies 4-6 weeks early due to cervical cancer problems and couldn't hold the baby any longer and one had her baby 4 weeks early due to other medical issues.  All babies are now 2-4 years old and doing fantastic.  Usually premmies take a couple of years to catch up with children their own age in milestone achievements but by 2, they may be a little shorter but otherwise, developmentally they are up there with their peers.  Just remember though, a lot of babies still have a good chance of survival even as early as 24 weeks gestation.  I wish you all the best of luck and hope these answers have put yours or someone else's mind at ease :-)



</answer>



<answer from>



Mariah
Member since: 24 May 2007

<question from>



Emily T
Member since: 22 February 2008
Total points: 196 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why is my 11month old throwing angry strops!?



He is always a little stropy if i wont let him do something like climb the stairs and touching the oven. but the past couple of days he seems really angry. screaming at me and wavin his arms around. he refused to eat yesterday and kept spitting the food out into his hands and wacking the spoon as it nears his open mouth. he's walking now and im thinking it might be that he just wants to walk and not be sat down eating when he could be practising. help, am i doing something wrong or is he just a perfectionist?



P.S dont know if this has anything to do with it he is a boy.



</question>



<answer from>



Jessica B
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 130 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hi Emily,
No you're not a terrible Mum. As I am a fairly new Mum I am reading a few books to help me with all these problems.



I am reading a book at the moment called On Becoming Baby Wise (Five months to Fifteen Months) By Gary Ezzo and Robert Buckman. In the book they claim that children from about 8 months of age can understand communication but can't speak. So they recommend teaching your child to sign. It is only basic words like Please, Thank you, Food, Drink, More, Yes, No, etc. This gives them a way to communicate to you about what they want. When talking to other mothers they had heard this as well from other sources. It is believed that if children can express themselves and communicate what they want/need/feel at the time, then the temper tantrums decrease and maybe even cease. In the book they also discuss high chair manners and mealtime activities. Stick at sitting to eat because if he gets into the habit of walking and eating, then it will be harder to retrain him. You want him to sit to eat when you go out.



This book is written by Christian doctors, but it doesn't try and convert you. They just want parents to be able to enjoy parenthood and have well developed children.



Good luck with your precious little man. May he bring you joy in the future. Be strong!!!



Source(s):



On Becoming Baby Wise Book 2: Parenting Your Pretoddler Five to Fifteen Months. By Gary Ezzo M.A. and Robert Bucknam M.D.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



i brough this book the other day. i will definatley get into it sooner now. thanks



</asker's comment>

Member since: 09 December 2007

<question>



When did you start to train your baby to take naps in his crib?



My baby is 10 weeks old, he sleeps in his crib in the night no problem. When i put him in the crib for his nap, he cries for few min. but ten falls asleep, but will wake up after about 30 min.



I pick him up and he will sleep in my arms for another hour. I want to train him to sleep in his crib for the whole nap time.  When can I start to do that(will involve crying) and how do I do it? Am I doing the wrong thing by picking him up now?



</question>



<answer from>



Treasure
Member since: 27 March 2008
Total points: 1832 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



What I did was I would put him in his crib when he was wide awake...and play with him...so he got a feeling of security being in his crib...that it wasn't a bad place to be...which worked for us...he naps in his crib just fine...but he does only nap about half hour normally...but sometimes has almost a 3 hour nap.



</answer>



<answer from>



ericakam...
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 1644 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



He's 10wks old..give it some time...just be glad he is sleeping in his crib at all..you are doing something right!!!! He may just be a cat napper, my son is like that at most of his naps!!! 30-45minutes...then some days he'll take a 2hr nap...



</answer>



<answer from>



sleepyhe...
Member since: 21 December 2006
Total points: 3008 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



your Baby is only 10 weeks old.  I usually let my baby nap wherever she was comfy .  I doubt you will be able to "train" him to nap anywhere til he's a little older.  I also would never let my baby cry it out and they are to young to be spoiled by being held all the time.  They need it, they are babies!!



</answer>



<answer from>



reminise...
Member since: 13 June 2007
Total points: 1106 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your baby is 10 weeks its good for you both if you hold him now.  I would wait a lil longer before training him to spend the entire time in his crib.  We co-sleep with our daughter some of the night and put her in her crib for part of it.



Naps, we wait till shes almost asleep before we put her in the crib. She does not usually cry, but when she does we pick her up and try again.  Babies thier age just need to be comforted, it helps build trust and security for them.



Source(s):



13 week old Premie



</answer>



<answer from>



Shut up Obber!!!!

</answer from>



<answer>



He's very young to be cage-trained just yet.



Thirty minutes is a good nap for a near-newborn. There should be no "whole nap time"; babies need to sleep when they're sleepy, not when Mom's soap opera is on.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ellie04

</answer from>



<answer>



I never felt the need to "train" my 11 month old because he is not a Golden Retriever.



It is part of my job as Mom to rock or snuggle him to sleep and if he only naps for 15 minutes and wakes up happy I know that 15 minutes is all he needed. If he wakes up after 15 minutes crying for Mom, it is because he wants Mom to pick him up. Simple as that.

<answer>



<evaluation>Answer hidden due to its low rating</evaluation>



I had massive problems with getting my 3 month old son to sleep.  He would just lie awake and cry for hours, then when he finally went to sleep he would wake every hour or two hours through the night and cry again!  Talk about pulling our hair out .... we were absolutely desperate for sleep!



It was a baby sleep audio program recommended by a friend that finally saved us. We followed the advice and began by creating a baby sleep routine which included bathtime, dimming of the lights, putting Paul into his crib, final nappy change and then lullabies. We also made recommended changes to his naps during the day and used some of the other recommended techniques. Within two weeks he was sleeping through the night most nights with just the odd night where he would just wake once!



Definitely start by creating a good baby sleep routine though and you could find that solves most of your baby sleep problems.



Good luck!



Source(s):



If you want to take a look, the audio program is at http://www.babysleepsolution.com



</answer>

If he goes over 24 hours, that may be cause for concern. If he goes over 2 days, you can try the ProSobee or call his ped.

<answer>



"Some breastfed babies, after the first three to four weeks of life, may suddenly change their stool pattern from many each day, to one every three days or even less. Some babies have gone as long as 15 days or more without a bowel movement. As long as the baby is otherwise well, and the stool is the usual pasty or soft, yellow movement, this is not constipation and is of no concern. No treatment is necessary or desirable, because no treatment is necessary or desirable for something that is normal."



http://www.kellymom.com/newman/04enough_...



</answer>

<question>



Q: For breastfeeding mothers?



My daughter is 2 months and I wanted to know if all breastfeeding mothers feed there babies every 2 hours? is it okay to feed your baby only when she cries? or when she puts her hand on her mouth?



</question>



<answer from>



Jaiden Eats At Mommy's
Member since: 07 July 2008
Total points: 2513 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You should watch for signs of hunger. Feeding On Demand is the key. Don't try and put your baby on an "every 2 hours" schedule. A baby knows when they need food, so don't deny it and don't force it... Here is a good link for you. It has good info on hunger cues for breastfeeding mommas and babies :)



http://www.kellymom.com/bf/start/basics/...



"Common infant hunger cues include:



Early



* Smacking or licking lips



* Opening and closing mouth



* Sucking on lips, tongue, hands, fingers, toes, toys, or clothing



Active



* Rooting around on the chest of whoever is carrying him



* Trying to position for nursing, either by lying back or pulling on your clothes



* Fidgeting or squirming around a lot



* Hitting you on the arm or chest repeatedly



* Fussing or breathing fast



Late



* Moving head frantically from side to side



* Crying"



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Really helped thanks.



</asker's comment>

Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 114 (Level 1)

She fought it at first, but says it just succeeded in making them both cry needlessly. :)  Also, just about everything I've read says you can't over-feed a breastfed baby.  If you think she's giving you hungry cues, I'd say feed her.



Keep trusting your instincts!  Sounds like you got this thing covered already.  :D

There is no way of telling how many hours she'll go.  Just feed her when she shows the signs and you both will be happy.  Your supply will go up and she'll be a contented little nurser.

mom2baby...
Member since: 18 June 2006
Total points: 4838 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are often daycare assistance programs that can subsidize daycare while you work.  Also, look into what other public assistance programs you might be eligible for.  For instance, WIC, Section 8 housing vouchers, or food stamps.  It's not wrong to ask for help if you really need it and know it's temporary until you get on your feet.



Most work at home things are a scam.  However, I know that a couple of tele sales companies, like West, hire people to answer phones at home.  You have to have a dedicated land line for it, and they only pay pennies on the minute, but if you have a knack for talking to people, you can earn money keeping people on the phone and making commissions on what you sell.



</answer>



<answer from>



poprocks...
Member since: 14 August 2007
Total points: 985 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You could try looking for a job at a fitness centre daycare, they usually allow you to bring your own kids with you.  You could also try running a home daycare or babysitting.  Other than that there probably aren't a lot of jobs you will be able to do from home with the baby at home, most work at home jobs require you to have a quiet space to work in.  Watch out for scams, any work at home job that requires you to pay for anything up front or promises that you'll make thousands of dollars a month isn't legit.



Source(s):



http://www.pcworkathome.net/
This is the only website for work at home jobs I've found that doesn't have any scams in it, hope this will help you.



</answer>

<answer>



My baby is 10 months old and was waking frequently too.  He is also breastfed and I was feeding him to sleep every time he wakes. <answer from>



mystic_e...
Member since: 21 October 2006
Total points: 94174 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



Well my advice is that it is completely normal for a 9 month old to be up that often at night, and that you should only attempt to change it if you resent the behaviour or it is effecting your ability to function.



Weight has nothing to do with sleep maturity and the ability to self-soothe.  How much they eat during the day has little to do with sleeping at night, in fact your baby may be waking to nurse more at night because he is eating too many solids during the day and has to get all his breastmilk at night -which is what he really needs to survive.



http://www.kathydettwyler.org/detsleepth...
The expected pattern is for mother and child to sleep together, and for child to be able to nurse whenever they want during the night. Normal, healthy, breastfed and co-sleeping children do not sleep "through the night" (say 7-9 hours at a stretch) until they are 3-4 years old, and no longer need night nursing. I repeat -- this is NORMAL and HEALTHY. Dr. James McKenna's research on co-sleeping clearly shows the dangers of solitary sleeping in young infants, who slip into abnormal patterns of very deep sleep from which it is very difficult for them to rouse themselves when they experience an episode of apnea (stop breathing).



http://askdrsears.com/html/7/T070200.asp
Nightwaking has developmental benefits. Sleep researchers believe that babies sleep "smarter" than adults do. They theorize that light sleep helps the brain develop because the brain doesn't rest during REM sleep. In fact, blood flow to the brain nearly doubles during REM sleep. (This increased blood flow is particularly evident in the area of the brain that automatically controls breathing.) During REM sleep the body increases its manufacture of certain nerve proteins, the building blocks of the brain. Learning is also thought to occur during the active stage of sleep. The brain may use this time to process information acquired while awake, storing what is beneficial to the individual and discarding what is not. Some sleep researchers believe that REM sleeps acts to auto-stimulate the developing brain, providing beneficial imagery that promotes mental development. During the light sleep stage, the higher centers of the brain keep operating, yet during deep sleep these higher brain centers shut off and the baby functions on her lower brain centers. It is possible that during this stage of rapid brain growth (babies' brains grow to nearly seventy percent of adult volume during the first two years) the brain needs to continue functioning during sleep in order to develop. It is interesting to note that premature babies spend even more of their sleep time (approximately 90 percent) in REM sleep, perhaps to accelerate their brain growth. As you can see, the period of life when humans sleep the most and the brain is developing the most rapidly is also the time when they have the most active sleep. One day as I was explaining the theory that light sleep helps babies' brains develop, a tired mother of a wakeful infant chuckled and said, "If that's true, my baby's going to be very smart."



7. As they grow, babies achieve sleep maturity. "Okay," you say, "I understand this developmental design, but when will my baby sleep through the night?" The age at which babies settle – meaning they go to sleep easily and stay asleep varies widely among babies. Some babies go to sleep easily, but don't stay asleep. Others go to sleep with difficulty but will stay asleep. Other exhausting babies neither want to go to sleep nor stay asleep.



[...]



An important fact for you to remember is that your baby's sleep habits are more a reflection of your baby's temperament rather than your style of nighttime parenting. And keep in mind that other parents usually exaggerate how long their baby sleeps, as if this were a badge of good parenting, which it isn't. It's not your fault baby wakes up.



8. Babies still wake up. When babies mature into these adult-like sleep patterns varies among babies. Yet, even though babies achieve this sleep maturity some time during the last half of the first year, many still wake up. The reason? Painful stimuli, such as colds and teething pain, become more frequent. Major developmental milestones, such as sitting, crawling, and walking, drive babies to "practice" their new developmental skills in their sleep. Then between one and two years of age, when baby begins to sleep through the above-mentioned wake-up stimuli, other causes of nightwaking occur, such as separation anxiety and nightmares.



Even though you understand why babies are prone to nightwaking, you realize it's still important for parents and babies to get a restful night's sleep, otherwise, baby, the parents, and their relationship won't thrive.



http://www.pantley.com/elizabeth/books/0...
My research began in earnest. I searched the library and bookstores, and I took to the Internet. Observations and laments were easy to come



</answer>



<answer from>



blondie
Member since: 31 August 2007
Total points: 14191 (Level 6)



</answer from>

</answer>

<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Newborn & Baby



</category>



<question from>



Vincent was born in 08/30/08 ^_^
Member since: 27 December 2007
Total points: 269 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How long can a mixture of formula and milk sitting outside before feeding?



I want to mix the formula in advance, so when my boy wake up, the milk is ready , so he doesn't have to wait ...But how long can i leave it outside after mixed ???



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm confused why you say a mixture of formula and milk?  You're not mixing your formula with cow's milk, are you?



The can of formula should tell you, but it is probably good for about 2 hours unrefrigerated once it's mixed.  If you put it in the fridge, it's good for 24 hours.



</answer>

<answer>



I think it has more to do with people not marrying the right people rather than having an unrealistic view.  Their view may be ok, but the person they're with isn't -- or isn't right for that ideal.



I've been married over 11 years, and yeah, we're the only ones "still standing" among all our friends who were also married.  But for each marriage that fell apart, I could have told you ahead of time they weren't going to make it.  He was too selfish, she wasn't sure what she wanted and got married out of boredom, they didn't really look at their finances before having kids and now are fighting all the time over the bills, and so on.



It's a matter of being honest about who you are, who your partner is, what you both want, and a commitment from each other to roll with the punches and grow with each other.



</answer>

HouseMom
Member since: 09 January 2007
Total points: 1559 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I breastfed my first for 18 months and my second for 22 months. That was our special time, like you said - before bed and naptimes. You are still doing him good with having the nutrients, etc. from your milk, and if it's giving him comfort, then that's great. Over time you'll develop a new, special routine to replace breastfeeding once you've weaned him.



I can remember thinking at one point that maybe I should stop, and then was like, "WHy? It's not bothering me, and the kids still want to, so why stop?" I think sometimes people still have these outdated and antiquated notions about nursing and it's amazing how the negative views still pervade our culture. I'm so sick of the sexualization of breasts and how people can't get over their REAL, primary function - not to be toys to men, but, should you have a child and choose to nurse, a source of nourishment first and foremost! Get over it!



There's a big difference between nursing 14 months and until 5 years. No one ever said you were doing that. Good for you!



Source(s):



20w with #3, a future booblet!



</answer>

Maya

Total points: 92 (Level 1)

<answer from>



mystic_e...
Member since: 21 October 2006
Total points: 94271 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm neither proud nor ashamed that I am nursing a 2.5 year old and an 11 month old.  I merely know that humans are designed to consume breastmilk for 2-5 years



Its normal, and stopping sooner than that has serious side effects for both baby and mom.



Some days its annoying, some days its awesome.  Mostly its just the same as making a sandwich or putting a load of laundry in, its just normal.



You can find lots of women who are nursing/nursed a baby older than a year here:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/milk_drunk...



-------
American Academy of Family Physicians
http://www.aafp.org/online/en/home/polic...
If the child is younger than two years of age, the child is at increased risk of illness if weaned. Breastfeeding the nursing child after delivery of the next child (tandem nursing) may help to provide a smooth transition psychologically for the older child.61



---
American Academy of Pediatrics
http://aappolicy.aappublications.org/cgi...
# Increased duration of breastfeeding confers significant health and developmental benefits for the child and the mother, especially in delaying return of fertility (thereby promoting optimal intervals between births).196
# There is no upper limit to the duration of breastfeeding and no evidence of psychologic or developmental harm from breastfeeding into the third year of life or longer.197



-----
http://www.kellymom.com/bf/bfextended/eb...
#  Nursing toddlers benefit NUTRITIONALLY
# Nursing toddlers are SICK LESS OFTEN
# Nursing toddlers have FEWER ALLERGIES
# Nursing toddlers are SMART
# Nursing toddlers are WELL ADJUSTED SOCIALLY
# Nursing a toddler is NORMAL
# MOTHERS also benefit from nursing past infancy



--------
A Natural Age of Weaning
http://www.kathydettwyler.org/detwean.ht...



-------
Nutrition for Nursing Toddlers
http://kellymom.com/nutrition/solids/tod...



Many nursing moms are told that they must introduce cow's milk at a year. Your nursing toddler is already getting the best milk he can get - mother's milk! Breastmilk has a higher fat content than whole cow's milk (needed for baby's brain growth), and all the nutrients of human milk are significantly more bioavailable than those of cow's milk because it is species specific (not to mention all the components of mother's milk that are not present in cow's milk).



There is no need for additional milk or (or the equivalent nutrients from other foods) as long as your baby is nursing 3-4 times per day. Cow's milk is really just a convenient source of calcium, protein, fats, vitamin D, etc. - it's not required. There are many people in many parts of the world who do not drink milk and still manage to get all the calcium, protein, fats, vitamin D, etc. that they need.



-------------



How is Breastfeeding Related to Cancer



http://www.cancerhelp.org.uk/help/defaul... longer the women had breastfed during their lifetime, the less likely they were to get breast cancer. According to the researchers, this was a very striking finding. They made sure that the women’s age; menopausal status, ethnic origin, number of births and their age at the birth of their first child were all taken into account. Breastfeeding still lowered breast cancer risk by 4.3% for every year of feeding. There is also a 7% reduction in risk of breast cancer for each child born.



A 4% lowering of risk doesn’t sound much. But, as breast cancer is quite a common disease in developed countries, breast feeding every child for an extra 6 months would mean about 1,000 fewer cases of breast cancer in Britain each year.



You will have less chance of Breast Cancer and other Cancers



http://www.breastfeeding.com/all_about/a...



If women who do not breastfeed or who breastfed for less than 3months were to do so for 4 to 12 months, breast cancer among parous premenopausal women could be reduce by 11%; if all women with children lactated for 24 months or longer, the incidence might be reduced bynearly 25%.Source: Newcomb,P. etal. “Lactation and reduced risk of premenopausal breast cancer.” N Engl J Med 1994; 330(2):81-87.



Women who were breastfed as infants, even if only for a short time,showed an approximate 25% lower risk of developing premenopausal or postmenopausal breast cancer, compared to women who were bottle-fed as an infant.Source: Freudenheim, J. “Exposure to breast milk in infancy and therisk of breast cancer.” Epidemiology 1994 5:324-331



An increasing duration of lactation was associated with a statistically significant trend toward a reduced risk of breast cancer. Sources: Newcomb, P.A. et al. 1994 Lactation and a reduced risk of premenopausal breast cancer. The New England Journal of Medicine330(2):81-87. (P Byers T, et al. Lactation and breast cancer: evidence for a negative association in premenopausal women. American Journal of Epidemiology Vol 121, pp664-74, 1985)



Siskind V, et al. Breast cancer and breastfeeding: results from and Australian case-control study. American Journal of Epidemiology, Vol130, pp229-36, 1989



Uterine Cancer



A protective effect against uterine cancer was found for women who breastfeed.Source: Brock, K.E., “Sexual, Reproductive, and Contraceptive Risk Factors for Carcinoma-in-Situ of the Uterine Cervix in Sidney. “Medical Journal of Australia, 1989.



Ovarian Cancer



Breastfeeding should be added to the list of factors that decrease ovulatory age and thereby decrease the risk of ovarian cancer.S ource: Schneider, A.P. “Risk Factor for Ovarian Cancer. “New England Journal of Medicine, 1987



Endometrial Cancer



Lactation provides a hypo estrogenic effect with less stimulation of the endometrial lining. This event may offer a protective effect from endometrial cancer. Source: Petterson B, et al. “Menstruation span- a time limite



</answer>



<answer from>



fishes_r...
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 516 (Level 2)



</answer from>

<question from>

<question>



New Baby advice?  Schedule and poop!?



Does anyone have some good advice on how I can start getting my 2 week old on a schedule?  I have to go back to work soon, and need him to sleep at night, not all day.  He wakes us up right on time, every 2 hours at night to eat, and every 4 during the day.  How can I get him to switch? Please don't respond if you're going to tell me to just deal with it, I need a solution and know it can be done, somehow, but I need to find out how.



Also, does anyone know how to get poop out of clothes, changing table covers etc?  He's still pooping the yellow stuff, and ALL just isn't getting it out, I tried Shout too, and it didn't help.  Any secret tricks?



</question>



<additional details>



Thanks for the help so far, I'm not expecting him to sleep all night, and I just want him to get used to eating and waking more during the day.  He's made his own schedule with the eating every 2 or 4 hours, if I wake him up every 3 like the Dr. said, he just plays with the bottle and barely gets an ounce down in an hour, where if I let him do it his way he eats 2+ in about 20 minutes.  I'm just hoping if I start early, it will be easier to transition him to all night sleeping later on.  But I'm fully prepared to do the up every few hours thing until he needs less.



Plus, it's really hard to wake him up sometimes, he could sleep through a freight train, literally, but will wake up at the sound of the faucet at night.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Emma S
Member since: 24 July 2008
Total points: 1227 (Level 3)

<answer>



Spray clothing with Spray in wash right after poop!
2 weeks is still early for a baby to have a schedule but the best way to start is every night at the same time give a bath and get baby ready for bed. Then give a bottle and try to put baby down. Close door and walk away, let cry for 5 min. Then get baby up...but do this at the same time every night



</answer>



<answer from>



Joleen's Mommy
Member since: 07 February 2008
Total points: 1517 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



show him day and night.



day keep lights on. take him out in the sun. play with him. talk to him, etc.
night. dim or off lights. swaddle him with a blanket. sing to him. start a bed time routine to help him realize it (bath, swaddle, short book, sing, then lay down)....best of luck!!  No playing during night time.



This doesn't make a "schedule" but will help your baby understand day & night and in turn eat more before bed and sleep longer.



they can't digest the cereal so please don't do that!!
Do NOT try to wake him up or try to keep him up so he sleeps at night....recent studies show this actually makes it harder for them to sleep at night and can cause problem with develpment.



Source(s):



9 wk old girl sleep 6-7 hours straight at night since 3rd day home.



</answer>

<answer>



well what i did was start limiting his naps during the day to 2 hrs and keeping him up in the evening. it was hard. when he would start falling asleep i would take his socks off anf then part of his onsies or go change him and shake his rattle. i even tickled his belly bc he would startle and not b all the away asleep. i then up his oz at night so he is fulkl and will sleep more hrs. i also have him on a routine. he gets changed into night clothes or a bath around the same time everynight and dim the lights. i didnt start his schedule until he was 4weeks bc i had 2 weeks to get him on it.also make sure where he naps is kinda bright during the day and if possible dnt turn on the lights at night when u feed him or change him. i alos have him in daycare and they keep him up.

<answer>



Well he's only 2wks, I think you are asking a lot..with that said...we kept our son in his pack n play during the day in the living room where it was nice and bright...then at night, we would play with him during the evening hours (he would stay awake from about 6 until about 9 or 930  we would bring him in his room with just a nightlight on and put on some soft music, give him his last bottle and put him to bed in his crib...this didn't really start to work until 4-6 weeks..at 6wks he was sleeping 6hrs a night...you really can't ask for more!!!! they need to eat.
Get him used to light and dark...and have a routine before bed..some people swear by a bath..but at that age they don't need it it dries out their skin...well in some babies...we bathed our son about once or twice a week at that age...
good luck



as for the poop...not worht trying to get it out..throw the clothes away and use disposable pads on the changing table

Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



Wake baby more often during the day.  4 hours is far too long for a newborn to go without eating.  If he gets enough to eat during the day (and your milk supply becomes better established) he should be able to go longer at night.



So wake him to nurse every 2 hours during the day/evening, and then let him sleep as long as he will at night.



</answer>



<answer from>



curious
Member since: 18 September 2006
Total points: 9238 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's very hard to get a newborn on a schedule.  They need to eat often & have their diaper changed often.  Most babies do not sleep through the night until they are at least 3 months old.  This chaotic schedule is just something that they will slowly grow out of, not much you can do to control it.



For the poop, I would spray Shout on it right away, let it soak a few mins, than throw it in the washer.



Just for comparison, my first baby didn't sleep through the night until he was probably around 7 mos old, & he ate every two hours for a couple of months.  My second baby slept through the night at 3 mos & ate every 3 hrs for probably 4 months.  When your baby sleeps longer at night, just make sure he has a full belly & a dry diaper right before bed.



</answer>

OH yeah my milk is flowing fine and she seems to get full THANKS

<answer from>



kass ♥

</answer from>



<answer>



If she is hungry, she will eat! As long as she is gaining weight then she should be fine.



</answer>



<answer from>



flakes
Member since: 28 November 2006
Total points: 2367 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You do not need to wake her unless she is not gaining weight properly. You will find this out at your next appointment (but don't be alarmed if she has lost a few ounces since birth, this is normal). Does she seem content? Does she have 4-5 wet diapers a day? These are the things to be concerned with, not the number of feeds books and people put in your head.



</answer>

<answer from>



Stephanie M
Member since: 22 March 2007
Total points: 5319 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



A lot of people might disagree with me but I, personally, would wake her.  She's a newborn and needs all those nutrients.  If she's not getting enough of them, she will start losing weight.  Then more than likely, the doctor will blame your breastmilk by saying it isn't good enough and they will encourage you to supplement, which isn't good if you want to breastfeed.  If you have a scale and can keep track of her weight then it might be ok.  If you don't establish a consistent nursing bond with her now, your milk will end up drying up.  That is one of the reasons they say to nurse every 2-3 hours.  If she sleeps 4 hours at night, then I would let her sleep but during the day, I would nurse every 2-3 hours.  You need this to establish your milk supply or it will dwindle.



</answer>



<answer from>



heather
Member since: 29 April 2008
Total points: 832 (Level 2)



</answer from>

Source(s):



mitchells mum and 34 weeks preg with Amelie

i think its fine to have a shower for each child. its not about getting gifts, its about celebrating for the new baby that will soon be entering your lives and if one baby deserves one, so do the others. i had a shower for my first and again with my second and plenty of people came. ive also been to several other showers where the mom had already had a previous child and i didnt think anything of it. if you have some of the bigger items like the crib, bassinet, swing, etc. left over from your first then thats great but there are still plenty of other things the new baby will need. if someone doesnt want to go, they dont have to. its that simple. you shouldnt feel bad about it. im sure you'll have food and games and stuff like that so people can enjoy themselves. im sure you arent just going to be sitting there collecting gifts the whole time.



</answer>



<answer from>



malmerck
Member since: 15 January 2008
Total points: 275 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I wouldnt say rude, but it might seem like you are begging for stuff. If someone offers to throw you one then I dont see a problem with that but usually I think you only have one. Since they are so close you should be able to re-use stuff.



</answer>

<question>



My baby's hands are always moving, as if he's strumming a guitar. Is this normal?

Now that he's able to grab things, I'm assuming it distracts him for a short period of time. He moves his hands a lot more when he gets excited, almost uncontrollably. Are these movements normal, or should I be concerned?



</question>



<answer from>

<answer>

<question>



Please help - how can I encourage my baby to sleep longer at night?



My boy is just under four months old and only sleeps for up to two hours at a stretch  in the night - then has a bit of milk and goes off for another hour if I am lucky. Have tried to feed him up before bed ( he is bottle fed) and keep the lights off, things calm etc all night. I have a little girl who slept right through from eight weeks so this is a shock!  - any tips?



</question>



<answer from>



coco
Member since: 28 April 2008
Total points: 255 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



is he able to go to sleep on his own? or is he feed until asleep? my five month old still wakes alot in the night and i have tried all the methods, crying it out etc. he can cry for 2-3 hours and then i end up giving in and he is super hungry. just go with it i say it wont last forever. one thing though is that if he doesnt already he needs to learn to go to sleep on his own, so once he is feed and happy put him to bed awake, he may cry first few nights but will get the hang if it and also do the same in the day put to bed awake. good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



Samantha E
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 155 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Inside of giving a milk bottle when he wakes just comfort him. If possible try to not even pick him up, just rock his cot or pat his bum. Also make sure he is not sleeping too much of a day. A good bedtime routine helps as in bath bottle bed & at the same time every night. Having the day routine helps with them sleep through as well.



</answer>



<answer from>



MM
Member since: 04 July 2008
Total points: 3117 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have 3 girls and 1 boy and my son was a nightmare baby compared to my girls he would wake every couple of hours until he was 2 years and 3 months and that's when he started sleeping through the night. I have brilliant night time routine with bath; massage; dress play feed adn swaddle then bed but it never worked for my son; most people will give me thumbs down but I had to get up in the morning for my other children; so I would basically prop his bottle up with a blanket instead of me sitting there feeding him a bottle 4 times a night; he knew which way the bottle was and he would go back to sleep like this; by 6 months he could hold the bottle and I would have bottle of cold milk in his crib ready to give him when he woke. ( By the time he woke for the bottle it was at room temp). It saved my sanity because nothing worked with him.



</answer>



<answer from>



Roxanne H
Member since: 02 November 2008
Total points: 104 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is this stuff called Johnson bed time bath. Bath your baby in it (or any other product that contains lavender)as it helps them fall asleep. Give him a bottle after, burp and then put him straight down to sleep. do this as a routine every night and your son will get use to it.Hope this helps.



</answer>



<answer from>



superior...
Member since: 02 June 2007
Total points: 1374 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Wrap him up really tightly and leave a dim light on (he may be scared of the dark).  he could also be missing his mum, what you could do is take your top off at the end of the day and put it over a pillow, then let him fall asleep on the pillow and put the whole thing in his crib, it might help him to sleep better . .



</answer>



<answer from>



Shelby
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 257 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



My son woke every two hours until he was about 5 months old. The only thing that changed it for us was a book called Save our Sleep! It was fantastic, I got him into a routine where we had to teach him how to re-settle himself after his 40 min sleep cycle, it took about 4 days but worked wonders.  he has slept 12 hours every night since! Good luck.



</answer>

superior...

<answer>



she sounds fine, they cant really control their eye muscles at such a young age so they can look "wonky eyed" - my son sure did! You are doing the right thing by getting her checked out though as it will put your mind at rest or if there is something wrong (which it doesnt sound like there is) they will catch it and treat it really early.



They also cant focus on things that are a distance away do she will only see you clearly if you are close up.



Three smiles a day at 13 weeks is amaxing! my son didnt smile at all until 16 weeks, and then I think it was wind!!

<answer>



I never bought my photos from the hospital, some of them were pretty cute but I have a digital camera and took extra cute ones that were more special because I took them myself in any position or clothing of the baby that I chose and was able to take my time with it.
I think if u have a digi ca that u can take the same type photos of your baby, besides the pics ion the hospitals that they take are not worth spending all of that money. JC penny portrait studio is cheaper. I go to the website which is really nice. It's http://www.shutterfly.com/.
It is completely free to use. U keep all of your pics from your digi cam in a photo album on there that is safe to use and password protected..U can take those pics and free of charge add borders,pictures,words,holidays themes etc to them which turns out very cute. There are so many fun things that u can do with your own pics on that website. then if u feel like u want to buy then they have deals where u get the first 20 prints free (with decorations of your choice) and there packages are well priced.



Your babys pics came out cute and he is adorable..If u feel like u want to buy them let no one stop u from doing what u want but I am pretty sure u can take the same pics at home, maybe even better and using the link I gave u, your pictures will come out beautiful...I have ordered pics from there and they arrives glossy and looked exactly like professional ones, everyone asked where I got them done =o)

<answer>



I used to wake up at 4.30 on the dot every day, this was NOT the time i went into labour, i started labour at 7.30 and finished at 20.59 no where near the time i woke up in the night, HOWEVER, it was the time my daughter woke up for the first month of her life. My mum said that i was waking up because my daughter was waking up inside me as at this point in pregnancy your child will have a regular sleeping and waking pattern, and this was her right until she was a month old from pre birth.



</answer>

<question>



Question about my breasts (breastfeeding)?

a) What could be the problem?, and
b) How do I fix the situation?



Thanks so much!!



---J



</question>



<answer from>



mama.toa...
Member since: 12 September 2008
Total points: 1073 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



i had this, put your daughter to the left breast first, cause they suck harder at the beggining of the feed, so you try stimulate it a bit more!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Angela J
Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 146 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Start expressing form the breast which has reduced its milk supply. Hopefully this will increase the amount of milk it is producing again



</answer>

<question>



Can i still introduce finger food if my 6 month old refuses pureed food?



i am having the toughest time with my 6 month old as she doesn't want any pureed food (homemade).  however, she tries to grab food from my hands when i am eating.  for e.g. she refused pureed banana but doesn't mind nibbling the whole banana when i eat it (though she makes faces at the taste).  same with apple, she refuses the puree so i tried cuting a slice of apple and she tried holding it and nibbling on it (again, she makes faces at the taste but at least she is trying).  i also tried giving her whole carrot which she loves.



but i am really scared that she might bite of a chunk and chock on it as she has not had much practise eating the pureed foods.  the only pureed food she has accepted is carrots (finely pureed, she chokes if a slightly lumpy piece goes in her mouth) and rice cereal.



what finger foods can i give her as i feel really bad refusing her food when she makes a grab for my food but she totally refuses pureed food.  as soon as she sees the spoon, she turns her head to the point where i can't even give her rice cereal or pureed carrots which she loves.



oh, she doesn't have any teeth!!



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Of interest:



http://babyledweaning.blogware.com/



</answer>

<answer from>



Angela J
Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 146 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I suffered from baby acne when i was a baby. My mother used to wash my face with cotton wool and unfortunately you just have to wait untill it goes away on its own whch was about a month I think. On the positive side when a baby has acne is usually means that they will have good skin as a teenager/adult. I for one have never suffered from pimples since and have really good skin. Hope this helps



</answer>



<answer from>



mama.toa...
Member since: 12 September 2008
Total points: 1075 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



my daughter had this, i felt so bad for her pimpled face, so i found out at least once a day, wash the face  with cooled boiled water and let air dry then apply breast milk, after 3 days it disappeared, then returned a week later, repeated that ritual, gone again and stayed away!!



</answer>



<answer from>



039;ȿ Μʋɱɱʮ
Member since: 04 January 2008
Total points: 12439 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



there really isnt much you can do, but it DOES go away on its own. my daughter developed it at around 2-3 weeks old and had it till about 3 months. her face was really red and she has red and white spots on her forehead, cheeks, chin and nose. i just used warm water when washing her, and it eventually went away.

<question from>



curious
Member since: 16 March 2008
Total points: 9764 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



Breastfeeding question...I really need the some advice.?



Ok, I have a friend that had a baby 1 month ago, she stopped breastfeeding after a week..if that, anyway, she said it just wouldn't work and that she was hurting and made to much milk, she also was pumping every hour, she said her baby didn't know how to latch on because she was so small..born at 37 1/2 weeks..6 1/2 lbs. Anyway, I am due in a week or so and all she does is tell me how i won't be able to breast feed, how not to feed the baby every hour because I will get to much breast milk and leak it everywhere..blah blah blah.



Ok, now please correct me if I'm wrong on this stuff...



1) breastfeeding is hard in the beginning and its going to hurt for a few weeks until your body gets used to it.



2) your encouraged to nurse baby often in the beginning to increase your milk..once your body figures out how much milk your baby needs you won't make AS much. It is normal to be engorged a LOT in the beginning.



Am I at least half way on track?/ I want to breast feed my baby so bad and quite frankly don't care if it kills me, I want to do it!!! Please correct me if I'm wrong on any of this...



Any advice would be great!!



</question>



<answer from>



Hallie's Mommy
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 474 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



First of all, congrats on your baby and your decision to breastfeed!! It's the best thing you can do for your baby! The health benefits to your baby (and yourself!) are amazing! I'm sure you already know all of that though. Your friend sounds like she will feel better about her decision to quit breastfeeding if you don't breastfeed. Do not listen to her!!



I have a 3 month old who is breastfed, and I never had any problems at all, except right after the birth. I was exhausted and groggy from the epidural, so the nurse gave the baby a bottle of formula. The next morning though, the baby latched on like a pro and never had any problems since. It also never hurt when the baby latched on. Engorgement is extremely uncomfortable, but all you have to do is take a warm shower and pump your breasts until they aren't so full.



The worst part of breastfeeding for me was leaking! Just get some bra pads and extra nursing bras. I thought they would never stop leaking, but now (around 3 months later) I rarely get leaks anymore, just sometimes at night. You are right, your body will figure out how much your baby needs and you won't make as much.



You sound so determined, that's great! You are doing something wonderful for you baby. And I promise once your baby stares into your eyes while you are nursing her, you will feel a love that you didn't know existed!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks :)



</asker's comment>

<answer>



You are totally correct. Breastfeeding is hard at first but once you and baby know how to do it, it is easy and painless. And newborns have very small stomachs, they need to nurse a lot.. but your body will regulate itself.



You will be a great mom and I am sure your baby will be a champ at nursing. Congrats mom!



</answer>

<answer>



1) breastfeeding is hard in the beginning and its going to hurt for a few weeks until your body gets used to it. IT SHOULDN'T HURT BUT IT MAY FEEL UNCOMFORTABLE, IF IT REALLY HURTS THEN YOU NEEDS TO SEE A LC ABOUT HELP WITH LATCH, MOST BABIES NEVER GIVEN A BOTTLE OR PACI AND NURSED WITHIN HOURS OF BIRTH LATCH JUST FINE



2) your encouraged to nurse baby often in the beginning to increase your milk..once your body figures out how much milk your baby needs you won't make AS much. It is normal to be engorged a LOT in the beginning.NURSE YOUR BABY VERY OFTEN FOR THE FIRST 6-8 WEEKS, THIS WILL BRING SUPPLY IN AND MAKE SURE YOUR BABY GETS ALL THE MILK THEY NEED, NURSE ON DEMAND BUT NEVER LET THEM GO MORE THAN 4 HOURS WHEN VERY YOUNG.  YOUR BODY IN THE BEGINNING MAKES TONS OF MILK ONCE ITS COMES IN AND LEARNS HOW MUCH TO MAKE BY HOW MUCH YOUR BABY REMOVES FROM THE BREAST, NO PUMPING UNLESS YOU PLAN TO GO BACK TO WORK, IF YOU GET ENGORGED YOU AREN'T NURSING ENOUGH, YOU SHOULD GET ENGORGED ONCE OR MAYBE TWICE OTHERWISE YOU SHOULD NURSE MORE OFTEN.



OH AND YOUR FRIEND SOUNDS AS THOUGH SHE WANTS YOU TO FAIL BECAUSE SHE DID, A REAL FRIEND WOULD SUPPORT YOU IN YOUR DECISION, I'D BE LOOKING FOR SOME NEW BFING FRIENDS, MAYBE GO TO A LLL MEETING.



</answer>

You're pretty well right on - breastfeeding can be pretty painful the first few weeks while you're body adjusts to it and figures out how much milk to produce. wag35

<answer>



You are correct on all counts.  And the pain can be eased if you start using some lanolin ointment now, before you start nursing.  It really helps.  The engorgement in the beginning isn't that bad, I mean it is uncomfortable and I certainly wouldn't want to be like that for a long time, but it is usually over in like 2 days.  Leaky breast are just a part of nursing, no big deal, you get used to wearing a bra most all the time and breast pads inside the bra.  I don't sleep in one but make sure that I wear a cotton shirt at night when I nurse and the one breast leaks usually soaks the front of the shirt so I have a replacement on hand. ( quite frankly I am so exhausted I could care less.)



</answer>

<answer from>



m@nd@
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 1128 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You are correct on both! My daughter had trouble latching on at first, but I just kept trying (also with the help of a nipple shield-ask for one!). After about a week she knew what she was doing. Also, the only thing that hurts is the nipple-it may become cracked and very sensitive, but for me it only lasted a few days. Then you are used to it and there is no pain. And for the first several weeks you are supposed to let baby nurse on demand-whenever he/she wants to. That builds your milk supply to the level that your baby needs. Engorgement is only supposed to last a few days I think; I didn't experience it though.



Breastfeeding really is a wonderful thing: the bond with your baby and knowing that he/she is getting the best nutrients. Good luck! If you really want to breastfeed, just stick with it and ask for help if needed.



</answer>



<answer from>



its_vict...
Member since: 28 January 2007
Total points: 7667 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



You are correct on both points.



Baby will breastfeed on demand.  This means that as soon as baby cries, first offer the breast, and then offer something else if baby doesn't want to eat.  There are lactation consultants at the hospital and plenty of hotlines you can call if you can't get baby to latch correctly.  After a few weeks, baby will get the hang of it all and everything will get better.



But, you really really need to talk to your friend about her negative attitude.  The more she tells you that you won't be able to breastfeed, the harder you will think it is, and you will let her get the best of you and will quit.  Sit down and talk seriously with her.  Tell her that you are sorry breastfeeding did not work for her, but it is different with every baby and every mother.  Tell her that you really want to try breastfeeding, and you would greatly appreciate her support.  And, tell her that if she can't be supportive, to please avoid being negative because the last thing you need is her negativity ruining what you are trying to give your baby.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sonja H
Member since: 24 October 2008
Total points: 137 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Good for you for wanting to give your baby the best possible start!  Breast feeding is very hard.  I'm not going to lie or make it sound like a walk in the park.  It took my daughter and me three months to make it work.  In the meantime, I suffered through clogged milk ducts (warm compresses work wonders!), a baby who refused to latch without silicone nipple shields (which she stopped using at 3 months), and VERY sore nipples that cracked and bled.  I think I kept Lanisoh in business by buying their lanolin ointment!  (Which, by the way, if you use, make sure you use breast pads because it does leave a greasy residue on clothes that doesn't come out in the wash! Breast pads in your bra also help with the leaking milk issue.)



Different people produce different amounts of colostrum and milk initially.  A friend of mine could have fed five babies with her milk, and she was constantly engorged.  Meanwhile, I had to meet with a lactation consultant to figure out why I wasn't making enough milk.  I've had to breastfeed and then pump to essentially "tell" my breasts to make more milk.  If your friend was pumping every hour, she was essentially telling her body to make more milk.  Yikes!



Breastfeeding is one of the most unnatural natural part of being a mom, but it's worth it!  I got a cold last week, and because there were antibodies in my milk, my daughter only had a very mild version of my cold.  That alone was worth all the pain and frustration!  Good luck and try to stick with it!  If you choose not to though, don't beat yourself up about it.  Being a new mom is hard enough without the guilt we try to lay on ourselves for doing or not doing whatever it is that we are doing or not doing!



</answer>



<answer from>



jupiter
Member since: 22 November 2007
Total points: 4099 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



you're very right on both points... 1 and 2

best of luck to you



</answer>

Christopher P
Member since: 01 November 2008
Total points: 127 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think there is anything wrong with goat formula. You could also try soy formula. Also infant formula can be given from birth. Just select the right product for your child's age.



Babies are pretty tough little things and they will usually thrive on any good quality infant formula. Your infant has developed a rash so sure - change the formula and see how it goes.



Really the biggest battle is ensuring you get enough sleep each night so you can function properly. Little kids can feel it if you're all stressed out. So if the baby's got a rash, and it could be itchy and making them cry, then change the formula and see how it goes.



Source(s):



Two kids of my own.



</answer>

<question>



For those mommies that make their baby's/babies' food...?



What kinds of veggies did you mix together? I'm having trouble being "creative" and have only mixed green beans, sqaush, and carrots together. Other than that I've been giving him the veggie by itself.



Any fruit combos would be welcomed too! We've tried pears and bananas mixed and he's enjoyed those two.



</question>



<answer from>



Hannah's mommy
Member since: 30 July 2007
Total points: 12740 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Some ones I did:



Use different types of squash:  butternut and acorn



Mix fruits and veggies:
apples and sweet potatoes
pears and squash



Veggie mixes:
Corn and squash
spinach and squash
spinach and sweet potato
cauliflower and sweet potato



Fruit mixes:
blueberries and bananas
apples and blueberries
apples and pears



Meat mixes:
chicken, sweet potato and apple
chicken, butternut squash and pear



</answer>

<answer from>



Frances L
Member since: 03 December 2007
Total points: 256 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can try imitating the ones that you can buy-- or you can do what I did with Lilly and mix a bit of vegetables that your babe doesn't like into larger amounts of veggies or fruits that the baby likes. I slowly mixed more of what she "didn't like" into lesser amounts of things she loved.  Or instead of just mixing the different veggies serve 2 or 3 veggies with different textures at the same time.  I got more into mixing once Lilly was eating meats and more textures-- one of her favourites was pureed Chicken or Turkey with Papaya and either whole rice or barley.



</answer>



<answer from>



Anastasi...
Member since: 23 October 2006
Total points: 3989 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



If your baby is willing to eat the veggies without being mixed then that's a good start to get them into eating a bigger variety of foods, which is not a bad thing, if your baby doesn't like one particular veggie, then mix it with another veggie that baby does like. Personally potato was the base for all my mashings, every other veggie just seemed to go well with it, depending on your babies age, if baby is at the right age for finger foods, speaking from experience my 3 babies all love to chew on a cob of nice juicy corn, they like peas, as they are easy to eat and a little fun to chase around the plate...avocado is also very good for babies, you can try little chunks of that, mixed with your potato.
The good thing about babies is if they don't seem to get bored with the same foods if you serve them for 2 days straight.
I also used to mix grated veggies in with my tomato based pasta sauce, only grated because that way they mix better in the ground beef without being chunky, not to mention i havent met any child who doesnt like pasta!.



</answer>

<question from>



Baby Concerns
Member since: 18 April 2008
Total points: 46 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



My son is  months old. I gave him a teaspoon of egg yolk of a half boiled egg and he loved it.?



Now someone tells me that eggs are to be fully boiled only. Why can I not give half boiled (egg yolk still in liquid form)? Also can I give egg white now?



</question>



<answer from>



039;ȿ Μʋɱɱʮ
Member since: 04 January 2008
Total points: 12453 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



dont give runny yolks. there is a risk of salmonella. its not worth it. would you eat a half cooked burger? then dont give your child a half cooked egg. aside from this, eggs arent recommended till at least 9mos.



Şơƥɦɨȩ'ȿ Μʋɱɱʮ ˣ ˣ ˣ



</answer>



<answer from>



Abbies mummy
Member since: 11 October 2008
Total points: 140 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I agree with the person above. Definetly dont give him egg unless it is fully cooked ..(hard boiled) babies are much more susceptible to salmonella/ food poisoning etc than we are.
Also you didnt say how old your baby is? Around 8months I started giving my little girl egg, including the white. I found it was difficult to get the egg to a good consistancy for her to eat, so I pureed it with some baked beans.
If he enjoyed it thats great, just keep an eye on him the second time, as often if a baby is allergic to something they will not have a reaction to it until the second time they are exposed to it. Look for rash, wheezing, vomiting, difficulty breathing etc.
Good luck, sounds like you have a great wee eater!



</answer>



<answer from>



Autism's Beautiful Face**
Member since: 05 January 2007
Total points: 32317 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Parenting



</answer from>



<answer>



So when can I give my baby eggs?
Because of the fact that many children tend to be allergic to egg whites, doctors advise that you avoid egg whites altogether for the first year. If there is a family history of food allergy, then it might be worth excluding egg whites from your baby's diet for the first 2 years.



Well cooked egg yolk, however, can be given to your baby from 6 months of age - although you may want to wait on egg yolk, too, if there is a family history of allergy. The easiest way to separate the yolk from the white is to hard boil the egg, then simply remove the yolk. Alternatively, you can crack a raw egg into two, then tip the yolk back and forth between the shell halves, allowing the white to drain into a cup. However, some traces of egg white may remain and even tiny traces can lead to a severe reaction in an allergic baby.



Source(s):



http://www.homemade-baby-food-recipes.co...



</answer>

jae24002...
