<answer>



Ohh I used to stress exactly the same! at that age though they can petty much move their head around. My girl keeps rolling on her belly, so its not like I can take her mattress away fo fear of her not breathing.



I have an old sheet which I cut in half and I swaddle her (wrap her tight). and put her on her back. She's abit of a hudini  though so generally she gets out. Then I stressed that she'd choke on her vomit or something.
So what did I do??
Stopped worrying.... Sounds silly but it has worked. She usually ends up horizontal and uncovered but babies are babies and they roll about.
I know this isnt help but just sharing my experience, Because I now sleep better.
P.S. the bars on the crib are designed so that babies cant get their heads stuck. Try a porta cot if your really worried, No bars or bumpers and they can roll around all they like



</answer>



<answer from>



Cindy V's now got 3!
Member since: 16 July 2007
Total points: 15870 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think it is a lot safer to take the bumper off the crib because if she gets her face pushed up against it and tangled in the sheets and can't get out of it, you could have a potentially fatal accident. I don't want to sound like a downer, but a friend of a friend had a 6mth old who had the exact thing happen to her and unfortunately nobody got there in time and she passed away to sids.



As far as i am aware, all SIDS recommendations in Australia say not to use crib bumpers at all.



I have never used one and I have never encoutered my children hurting themselves by bumping on the wood. Occasionally they wriggle around and fall back to sleep with a leg or arm hanging out of the bars/slats, but it was never a problem.



I think I would rather have a bump on the wood than deal with something potentially far worse.



Source(s):



mum of Eliza 6, Isaac 3.5 and Aidan nearly 4 mths!



</answer>

<answer>



My 6 month old girl sleeps from 6 at night till about 6 am. With a feed or two durin the night.



She will usuall go back to sleep within an hour and half of waking up for another 2. Stays awake till about 2 then has another hour.



But every baby is different. My first is crazy still now (20 months) but at 6 months she NEVER slept during the day. I got so nuts from not having time out for mysef that the same time every day I put her in her room ( between 11 and 1). For the first fw weeks she screamed the whole time! but then she fell into a great routine of playing around for a bit then having a nap.



Increasing sleep is good... no no its great! Baby's take as much sleep as they need, And as long as its not interfering with theyre night routine let them. Also if you have started solids it could be related to that. staying fuller for longer.
Hope this helps

<question>



Caffeine passing into breastmilk...how much and how fast does it happen?



I'm trying to find out about caffeine passing into breastmilk.



My midwife and doctor have told me that if you were to breastfeed your baby and then have 1 standard alcoholic drink, it will have passed through your milk and you can feed again safely as little as 2 hours after that drink, but is it the same with caffeine??? I know that it is okay to have a coffee (or coke etc..) when breastfeeding I just want to know how quickly it would get to the bubs.



Anyone know anything regarding this....



</question>



<answer from>



Randall
Member since: 26 March 2008
Total points: 3716 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



about 5 minutes.  Chocklate will be very irritable to the baby as well.



</answer>



<answer from>



jae24002...
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 145 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



it goes through the same amount of time it takes to go through your system. About 5 mins after you begin drink, and then 45-2hr after.
But honestly... I wouldn't stress. I drank coffee normally with mine (one in morn and one in arvo) and it didn't affect her at all. Others can be different though. Your body is amazing at working out what bubs does and doesnt need, So really the minute amount that gets through doesnt affect them. But I have heard opposite also



</answer>

jae24002...

<answer>



sweetie stop stressing.
All babies develop at different rates hey. My girl is 6 months now and still rarely smiles. Where as my first was smiles from day one.
I am guessing that you have afew mothers around you that you have to compare to? Dont!
As soon as you stop comparing the happier you will be.



As for the turned out eye, it wont be a problem I am sure. My daughter had the same thing and her sight is fine now. theyre still learning to controll theyre eyes, legs, arms, yawns, burps, feeding, weeing, pooing etc. Its hard to co ordinate all of these things at once. Give it a few months before you worry. Alot of doc's stress that it could be something to do with brain function but majority it is nothing at all. Hope this helps

</question>

you shouldnt need any extra vitamins or calcium for your baby. they should get everything they need from brast milk or formula. and also from health fruit and veg if he's old enough yet.

<answer from>



cathrl69
Member since: 10 July 2007
Total points: 22200 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



No, you feed babies either breastmilk (much preferable) or formula. They do not need extra calcium or vitamins, and too much of some vitamins can be harmful.



</answer>



<answer from>



Cindy V's now got 3!
Member since: 16 July 2007
Total points: 15878 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



For a baby 12mths or under they should be drinking formula or breastmilk in which case they will be getting all that they need.



For babies over 12mths that are on cows milk, as long as they are having cows milk, some cheese, yoghurt etc..they will also be getting enough calcium.



If your baby is eating and drinking a well balanced diet that is appropriate to their age, then you should not need to be giving any supplements at all.



Source(s):



mum of eliza 6, isaac 3.5 and aidan nearly 4 mths



</answer>

<question>



Hey my baby wont let me do anything no even go to the loo what do i do?



my baby is nearlly 7 months old and doesnt ever want me to go or leave him for 2 mins just to go loo allso i have a kitten which is the same age as my son and all she does is the same as my baby but she follows me everywhere and when i shut a door behind me and she cant get in she miaws and when im in bed she meows help i have 2 babies really!! lol



</question>



<answer from>



dinoula1...
Member since: 11 August 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



I know exactly what you mean, i to have a cat who thinks he's my son and a little 6 month old.  Unfortunately you can't do anything right now as it's calledseparationn anxiety and all babies go through it.  They eventually get over it.  As for the cat, not sure on that one lol.



</answer>



<answer from>



jae24002...
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 145 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



okay hun, its really herd to do but it does work.
You really need to let them cry. most importantly relax. If you do the "im comming, im comming" thing they will pick up on it.
Show them that you will not rush to their every bec and call.



Some babies really just want to go where you do, if you have a walker pop him in that so that he can learn to move aout on his own. And place him in sight when your doing things. He just wants to know what your doing.
But when it comes to going to the loo and getting yourself dinner you really need to just let him cry.
It takes a while and persistance but it will be fine in the end.
They know that you love them.... just give him a hug when you get back and say "see that wasn't so bad". It will start loud and demanding but after afew weeks he'll know that you'll be back shortly.



AS for your kitty, she sounds gorgeous!! she needs alot of love and cuddles too, but you sound like you need you time. So why dont you set up a little bed with some bikkies in the laundry and just leave her in there afew hours a day. She too will learn to not depend on you ebtirely, You sound like a really loving mum, but just try not to be a pushover okay



Source(s):



mother of two... nany of 9 in the past



</answer>



<answer from>



Jodie
Member since: 18 November 2007
Total points: 2594 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



There's not much you can do, but that doesn't mean you have to be around him 24/7. Sometimes it is better for you to just leave him for 5 minutes to cry. Leave him with something distracting so it might take him a few minutes to notice that you're gone.
Separation anxiety is common from 6 months, and it shouldn't take too long for him to grow out of it. As long as he is learning that he doesn't need to rely on you every second of the day.
Good Luck



</answer>



<answer from>



babycak...
Member since: 23 March 2008
Total points: 428 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



OMG! I had the same problem. It is so----- hard to get things done when you have a needy baby! They just love us so much , that is why they do that. They grew inside us for 9 months! You have to let the baby cry [ which is very hard to do! ]. Our first instinct as a Mom is to pick them up whenever we hear a peep out of them. This will be hard but things have to get done like taking a shower, dishes etc.  Make sure they baby is fed, not wet , & not sick. If you need to jump in the shower,  put the baby in the crib. Same thing if you need to do dishes......  You need "me " time . If you are married, ask your husband to help you.  It is OK to let the baby cry for a little bit. PLUS, picking him up everytime will only teach him that this is okay when its not. It will get harder as he gets bigger if you dont nip it in the butt now. I think your kids sound like mine & they will always be attached to you . However, if you do those things I said , you can have it a little easier. Also, remember they are only young once & to cherish these moments where they do want you all the time. They will grow up so fast!! You will ask yourself where the time went!!



Source(s):



2 kiddos of my own



</answer>

<answer from>



Dannie
Member since: 15 June 2008
Total points: 912 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



"I think I still have the nail marks in the inside of my lip from when my daughter was 5 months old and grabbed my lower lip and decided to see if she could pull it off".

My little girl is 5 years old now - and what I miss the most about her being a baby is the way she used to find relief for sore gums when she was teething.  Not only would she chew on my fingers, but she used to turn her head from side to side very quickly while I held my finger on her gums, making a squeeking noise.

Anyway: back to your question...

When I came home from the hospital I received a "subscription" to gerber baby.  I loved this magazine (being a new parent) because I didn't know what to expect from my baby, what was normal, and what to look for in her developement.

What gerber did was provide details about my baby's "phases" which I followed along with as she grew.  It was great reading about month to month expectations, and then watching her for the behavior or goal.

You may want to check out their website. They provide quick facts in the developement section about your baby's emotional, social, and physical goals.  It was both educational and fun for me.  I hope you enjoy their site.



Source(s):



http://www.gerber.com/phase/index



</answer>

<question>



Sterilising & weaning?



I began weaning my baby at 18 weeks, she is now 20 weeks.  I began early because she is not a "milky" baby.  She's never cried for food, and wasn't really interested in her bottle.  Someone told me she might be more into food than milk, so as soon as I could, I tried.  She loves food.  I want to make food for her myself, and also give her jars so that I can take her out and not worry about food spoiling and also because restaurants etc wont heat home cooked food, but will heat jars if necessary.



Anyway, I'm sterilising EVERYTHING when I cook the food myself, because she is still young, and also she has been hospitalised twice with nasty infections, and I can't risk her getting another one.

My question - which bits of the food preparation cycle do I need to sterilise and which ones don't I?  I'm sterilising all the cooking utensils, masher, ricer, blender, chopping matts...everything.  Part of me thinks I should just use jars until she is a bit older (because its "safer"), but I feel like its a bit of a cop out.

What do you think?  I'd really appreciate opinions or experiences.  Many thanks x



</question>



<additional details>



Maybe I should elaborate... I'm not a Monica off Friends type.  My baby almost died, twice.  She caught her infections from "people", and so I try and keep all things around her clean and sterile.  We're not sure yet if she has a metabolic disorder which makes her prone to infections or not.  There is something that changes in you as a parent when you see your baby so sick, and something in you which wants to protect her from anything else which might make her sick again..... I know I sound overboard, and I need to relax, so that's why I asked! :-)



</additional details>



<answer from>



Sabrina R
Member since: 06 August 2008
Total points: 1001 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



i think that sounds a bit overboard. i never sterilized anything and never had any major problems. but do what makes you feel comfortable.



</answer>

Member since: 10 February 2007
Total points: 5314 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>

I do think your going overboard but this is all I could find for you

http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/HealthAndWel...

<answer>



Hello.Just wash up in hot water(wear rubber gloves so it can be very hot).Wipe the chopping mats over once a day with a kitchen spray and once a day wash up in hot water.Just sterilise baby's bowl and spoon.Also wash your hands with soap and water before preparing food.

<answer from>



BABA BOOEY!!!!
Member since: 21 March 2008
Total points: 3263 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



i have made every piece of solid food my baby has eaten since he started solids at 5 months (except if we are at a restaurant and he has some of my dinner) - and i have never sterilized a thing (just wash things with hot water and soap like i do all of our dishes and utensils).



it's much healthier to make your baby's food and i don't believe jarred baby food is any safer at all, it can be contaminated in the factory it is made, there are often baby food recalls on jarred food.  i have never bought a jar of baby food and my son is super healthy and never gets sick.

i think what is safer and healthier is buying fresh veggies and meat and making your own you know exactly what is in it.



Source(s):



mommy of a 7 month old



</answer>



<answer from>



Mama_Ihe...
Member since: 26 August 2007
Total points: 2612 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You do not need to sterilise everything. Just washing all the cooking items in hot soapy water is adequate.

There is such a thing as being overly clean, and children raised in these sorts of environments are more likely to develop asthma. Think about it, soon your baby will be crawling around and putting things from the floor into her mouth. My son is only 4 months old and already puts his hands onto restaurant tables and other dirty surfaces then straight into his mouth. It has done him no harm.

You really do need to stop sterilising everything your baby comes into contact with and by doing this you will be letting her immune system develop.

Sorry if what i have wrote seems a bit harsh, but you really do not need to sterilise everything your baby comes into contact with.



</answer>



<answer from>



Dame Katkat - Pissed off again
Member since: 25 June 2008
Total points: 1204 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I totally understand your being anxious, but others are right, sterilising absolutely everything may well make it worse, she does need to be exposed to some things, to help get her immune system up and better :)

I would sterilise feeding equipment, but not utensils.



Don't use jars, she's better off with your food, though it's perfectly OK when you go out and things to give her a jar if it's more convenient.

Just remember, she puts her hands and her toys in her mouth, and you can't sterlise all of those!!



</answer>

<question>



Anyone have a baby cough remedy?



My 4 month old son has developed a dry, hacking cough as well a blocked nose and i want to know if there is any home remedy i can give him.

I know that when i have a cough i normally have hot water with honey, but as honey is a no-go for babies under one i cannot give him that.

I do not really want to give him a cough syrup as they are full of artificial colours.

Can anyone help me with a home remedy as my poor little lad really seems miserable.



</question>



<answer from>



Tamara G
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 1306 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You can try a bit of vicks on the chest. A small amount.



The best, most suggested thing, by DR's, and you can look this up, is to either take him in the shower with you and stay in for a bit, so that the moisture helps to clear him up.



Or, you can run the shower/bath while you sit near it, and it has a similar affect. The water itself, from the showering together, will help the nose to clear up. It will moisten and loosen up the boogies. :)

There's not much you can do aside from that. Keep him in warm pj's? Anyway, if it persists, then you can take him to your DR and let them know your concern, and they can prescribe you sugar and dye free medicine for him.

I've done it all with both my kids. My daughter was the worst. Hers seemed to happen when it was close to seasons changing, winter, and when she had teeth coming in. Of all those, they worked fine. Its just something you're going to wait out, on top of the suggestions. Sorry. :( Best wishes.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks - i will buy some vicks and be sure to keep him warm. If he is not feeeling any better i will take him to the doctors on monday.



</asker's comment>



<comments>



Tamara G



IDK if you, the "asker", will get this, but if he has a fever, you shouldn't keep him warm, that only encourages the fever to raise, and will do more harm than good.



</comments>

<answer>



I found that a good steam helped mine for a few hours. I would close the bathroom door, and put a towel on the bottom to help escaping steam and put my babe in a swing while I took a hot steamy shower. Then id leave him in the hot steamy bathroom in his swing (usually having a good sleep) until its not steamy anymore! It always helped him clear up his airways for about 3 hours or so.



</answer>

Whether it was the sugar or the children’s minds at work, the syrup dramatically relieved coughs, and could be a gentle, inexpensive first line treatment for coughs from viral respiratory infections. <answer>



Run the shower on hot, and sit in there holding him.  Let him inhale the steam.  Also, get saline drops from the drug store.  Drop 1-2 drops in each nostril, then you can either use the aspirator to suck out the blockage, or you can just sit up with him and let it loosen on its own.  Babies tend to HATE the aspirator, so with my kids, I just dropped in the saline and let gravity do it's job.  If that didn't help much, then I would use the aspirator.  I just felt like the poor baby is already sick and feeling crummy, why get them even more riled up.  Good luck.  I know it's awful watching them like this.  =(



</answer>






<original file>index;_ylt=AnOIIw1Jd0TFK3y2ii0q2ikGBgxe45e.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk38248.txt</current file name>



<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Newborn & Baby



</category>



<question from>



mom4peac...
Member since: 16 August 2006
Total points: 1379 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



I'd like to hear from mom's that have twins, any advise, do you have a routine, any information is useful thx



</question>



<answer from>



ljb
Member since: 06 December 2006
Total points: 11373 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



I'm a mom of twins (who are now 17 months old and starting to wake up from their nap) -- I will post a reply later but I wanted to be sure to refer you to the forums at http://www/twinstuff.com . You may already be familiar with them, but if not, they are forums for parents of multiples (the majority are parents of twins, but there are parents of triplets and higher order multiples as well) and it is an invaluable resource for information, advice, etc. The forums specifically for "The First Year" are wonderful, I don't know how I would have gotten through the first several months without them.

Good luck!
--------------------------------------...
Later that same day....

If you can have some kind of help caring for them, by all means, do it. I was confident I could do it all on my own and while it's certainly possible, and many people do it, help, if you can get it, is a wonderful thing. You may want help caring for the babies or you  may want help with, you know, everything/anything else. Many people recommend having some help for a week or two when the babies first come home -- the pros to that are obvious so I will play devil's advocate and point out the main con (which has nothing to do with having twins vs. having a singleton, by the way): you may want time alone, as a family unit, to bond and settle in when your babies first come home, and you may not want anyone there. If you have a partner/spouse and he is able to take time off from work when the babies come home, chances are that he isn't taking off much time, and you may not want others there at that point. Also, if he can take time off from work, and if you're taking off more time from work, you don't want to go from having "lots of help" and people around (your husband, and, say, a relative who is helping you out, or a baby nurse, or whatever) to having no one at all when husband goes back to work and the help situation ends. Anyway, that said, take help that's offered!! But be clear about the kind of help you want -- if relatives live nearby they'll probably be quite interested in helping with the baby, when what you will probably really want is help with things like laundry! Be that as it may, think about what you want in help and what is possible....and take it if you can get it.

Routine, routine, routine -- before motherhood I was not very...good...about routine. But I believe it's imperative, and has a lot to do with why my children (now 17 months) are so happy. You don't have to be rigid about things, but routine is great for most babies and gives them a sense of security...and with twins, routine is great for the caregiver and gives them(us) a sense of sanity! It also means trying to keep both babies on the same "schedule" -- you know that old saying, never wake a sleeping baby? Feh. That saying is inapplicable where twins are concerned. If you don't wake a sleeping baby what you end up with is a situation where you are *constantly* feeding. If one baby wakes at 1am to eat....the other one gets offered the breast/bottle then as well. Otherwise, you're in trouble, you will never sleep, and you will truly suffer. If you breastfeed, try breastfeeding in tandem -- after you're comfortable breastfeeding at all. If you bottle feed, find ways to feed simultaneously. If you do both, you can breastfeed one while bottle feeding the other...and switch that around at the next feeding. Etc. Establish a consistent bedtime routine with your babies before you even think it makes a difference to them; it can be very simple but be consistent. This will help with getting them to sleep (although sleeping through the night is a developmental thing and can't be rushed against an individual baby's particular inner schedule....unfortunately). Have a routine of waking, eating, and playing, and learn to look for "sleepy signs" to put your babies down for a nap....the ability to sleep well is a learned skill and when babies get very tired they don't sleep. If you try to keep them awake longer it will backfire, and nights will be terrible.

Get the support of other moms of multiples. For me, the forums at twinstuff.com were very very helpful. Most questions/concerns that moms have are pretty universal on some level, whether the mom is dealing with one baby or five. But the options, solutions, etc. are different when you have twins as contrasted with when you have a single baby. Pure and simple. Most of the well-intentioned advice from moms of singletons isn't very applicable, and if nothing else it gets very annoying because the bottom line is people who have not parented multiples just don't get it. So be sure and have some resource, some group of people in the same position or people who have been in that position, to help you through, whether it's on-line, or a local parents of multiples club, or just a subscription to Twins magazine. Something.

Be organized. Someone else mentioned keeping a notebook. My husband and I made a chart -- a very simple chart, basically dividing a page in two, one side for our son and one for our daughter, with columns for: time, feedings, diapers, and "other." We printed them out on our computer and used one chart per day, noting the time for each baby of feedings (how much they drank or for how long they breastfed), diaper changes (wet, "poopy" and yes, color and consistency b/c that info is telling for a doctor). In the "other" column we put everything else, from medication taken to temperature to what new food they had tried....whatever. It was extremely helpful for us, and for our doctor. You'd be amazed at how much you don't remember that stuff (especially when you're utterly sleep deprived). Very important.



For practical stuff in preparing for twins, remember first of all that twins doesn't mean you need two of everything! One baby may love a bouncy seat while the other hates it. Ditto a swing. Get one, see how it goes. Our twins shared a crib until they were six months, too. As for the stroller, there really is no such thing as a perfect double stroller, at all! To start with I urge you to get infant car seats that snap out of the base and can be carried...and a snap n go stroller, which is basically a base into which those car seats can fit. Makes life very easy. The stroller is cheap, it's light, it can be used for as long as the kids can be in those seats, and buys you time to learn what you really need/want in a stroller so you can get one (or probably two) that truly fit the bill.

If you have same-sex twins, if they are identical or if they appear identical, find some consistent, agreed upon way to tell them apart. Sounds stupid, but I've heard again and again from parents of ID twins that they could not tell the babies apart when they were very little. Some use a touch of nailpolish on a fingernail, some go by color of clothing...whatever.

Diapers: 1800diapers.com. They have excellent prices (yes, you can find better sometimes, but time and effort do have value, you have two babies to look after, after all!) and, they deliver right to your door. Orders over $50 are shipped free. They sell bigger boxes than you can find in most stores. You can even "schedule" a delivery with them so they deliver, say, once a month (but if you do that remember to change/update the size you need!) I cannot tell you the hassle it saves me from, not having to buy the tons of diapers we need every time we go shopping. And it's not just diapers, they do formula, wipes, and various other baby needs as well.

This doesn't speak to the raising of twins, but nonethless: if you are still expecting and they haven't been born yet, be prepared earlier than a woman pregnant with a single baby would be. Chances are pretty high that the babies will be born early. Or, you may find yourself on bedrest at some point. So get ready early.

This is a ridiculously long answer, I'm sorry for that. I'll leave you with two other thoughts. One: be prepared for a lot of attention and a lot of comments, which can be sweet and can be annoying. No matter how sweet it is you will get annoyed by the attention and the questions...and for some reason people tend to want to touch twins more than other babies. Two: This is the most important thing to remember. Have fun. Raising twins is....very challenging. It's the hardest job I've ever had, let me tell you. It is also the most fun you'll ever have. Enjoy it.

Sorry to go on for so long. Congratulations!



Source(s):



mom of fraternal (b/g) twins, born prematurely at 32w



s



</answer>

dueoct16...

Total points: 40076 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



It isn't necessary to warm baby bottles if you don't want, it is more a comfort thing and not needed.  The bottles should be washed though after every use but that isn't neglect according to CPS.  Not sure on what medication she is on but it does sound bad that the father is saying to give more to knock her out that would concern me.  The bouncer thing all the time is bad but at 6 months old there is no law that says she has to have solid foods.  Some babies can go 2 days without a bath, frequent baths dry out their skin sometimes (my pediatrician said that too) so unless she is going a week or something without baths they may not see that as neglect either but her clothes should be changed and her diaper should be changed obviously.  Cradle cap isn't necessarily a sign of neglect either, most babies get it and it can be hard to get rid of, with my boys i had to use selsun blue shampoo to get rid of it (per pediatricians recommendations).  She should be able to support her head though and should atleast look at you when you talk to her so I would say something may be wrong there, was she a premie or anything?  Really it is a call you will have to make, do you think they neglect her or not?  You didn't say what she weighed so I couldn't say if the weight is ok or not and really that would be hard to say if it proves neglect or not without knowing the situation because i know babies that are failure to thrive that are in good homes.



</answer>



<answer from>



chrissy7...
Member since: 28 April 2006
Total points: 5270 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's sounds like neglect to me but you never know the whole story. They could be great parents going on doctors orders. Although the TV thing isn't good for any child but that alone isn't neglect, just poor parenting and they will pay for it later when the kid won't sit still or focus on anything. It's really a judgment call on your part. Are these people well-rounded loving people or is there some possible drug/alcohol abuse going on? You see the situation is questionable...just look at the parents and see if there are any flags. Unfortunately contacting CPS only means they will do the bare minimum to address the situation. I have heard many parents talk about notices left on their doors including a date and time for the next visit CPS will make; which means the parents can clean up their act that day and go back to doing what they do after that. If you decide to call, certainly do it but don't expect anything special but if they do their job it will be a good thing. Best wishes.



</answer>

MoM oF tWo

<answer>



You should call social services. The baby could just be small for her age, but there is really something wrong if she cant hold up her own head! <answer>



Hmmm, it sounds like a very complicated situation. Kudos for trying so hard to do the right thing. You have my respect.

The baby sounds unhealthy. I'm not so much concerned by the lack of baths (cradle cap can actually be made worse by too much bathing - try olive oil, it works a treat), but by the poor condition and dirty bottles.



As her baby sitter you are in a good position to make sure she at least gets good care while she's with you. Keep up the good work.

Do call CPS. And if you don't feel confident visiting a nurse try calling the hospital/health centre anonymously. Describe the childs physical condition and circumstances and ask for their advice.



Go with your gut on this one, darling. Listen to your heart and you'll do the right thing.

Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



pengworm
Member since: 12 February 2008
Total points: 850 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm a Mother of three and I honestly can't believe that anyone would tell you not to contact someone about this child. What's the worse that could happen? Maybe the parents get investigated and it's found that things are fine, well then so what? Now what's the worst that could happen? I don't even want to go there.

I know that child protective services makes it VERY hard to get children taken away from worthless parents. I have a cousin who had a little boy with his girlfriend and you couldn't really get much worse as far as parenting. They were young and completely selfish and clueless and doing a lot of drugs on top of it. It took my family months and months to finally get something done. Today the child is in a normal home and is well adjusted. I shudder to think what might have become of him if we had looked the other way and allowed him to be treated the way he was.



Now this was not a fun thing to do. My cousin is very close to me as is our entire family. But to me there was no question what was right to do. This child does not have any say and cannot do anything about the way it's being treated. So people like us have to give them the voice they don't have.

And yes some people are right about some of these things not necessarily being neglect. For instance my two year old has ezcema and could only bath two times a week at most when he was that young and trust me I'm a great mom. Plus cradle cap happens too even if you're doing everything right. Not warming the bottle, not necessary either.



However the things that worry me are first and foremost the father telling you to give the child more meds to "knock her out". I'm sorry this is pathetic. I can't imagine saying that to a babysitter. If they are open about that to you can you imagine what they do in private?

Plus the child sitting in the bouncy seat alone and not being able to hold up it's head is not right. Maybe there are health issues but even so you'd think the parents would explain this all to you and let you know what's going on...I know I would.

My gut tells me that these people are selfish idiots who have no business "raising" a child. Could I be wrong, of course. The thing is I'd rather take a chance on being wrong then take a chance on a poor helpless child being abused or neglected.

I just can't get over the fact that these parents do all these things like not washing the bottles in front of a sitter. I mean if that's acceptable behavior to them in front of a babysitter I don't want to fathom what else they think is acceptable.

I wish you the best in your decision. I really do think though that all of us need to look out for the best interest of children and to me these people don't look like they are.



</answer>

<answer>



i never personally. i never bought a book when i was pregnant, never bought one when my daughter was born.

Total points: 28535 (Level 7)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



Many of those "rules" are things that have come about from years of studying parenting methods as well as medical and psychological research.

For example, not introducing solid foods before a certain age is to ensure your baby's immune system is fully developed and to ensure the baby is mature enough to actually chew and swallow the food. But most age targets related to feeding have to do with developmental milestones rather than specific ages. The ages tend to be more of an average.



Not nursing your baby to sleep is in the same category as not walking on tip toes while baby is sleeping and not rushing to your baby the instant they cry. If everything is always just so then baby never learns how to cope if something isn't just so.



</answer>



<answer from>



tumsntoe...
Member since: 07 September 2008
Total points: 253 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



yeah i do, i read all the books when i was pregnant but when it actually came to being a mum no amount of book reading can tell you how hard it is so i listened to my gut instinct and did it how thought it was right!
I weaned my little girl at 4 1/2 months because simply milk wasn't enough for her and it's been ok to do it for years when my mum had her kids so why is it different now?
I say listen to your instinct and do it how you feel its right!



</answer>

<answer>



I agree. There is way to much recommendations out there. Honestly I found it the hardest part of being a new Mum. I had one group of people telling me to put my baby down to cry or else she would become spoilt. I had another group of people telling me to rock her to sleep and pick her up as fast as I can everytime she crys or she will have insecurity issues later in life. One group said if I didnt put her on a 3 hour feeding schedule she would be over feed while the other group said if I dont feed on demand she will be under feed. I was so freaken confused! It made me so depressed everytime I tryed things one way because I worried about the consequences that I may reep according to the other group of people.
Finally I stopped listning! I did things as I felt I should do them. I picked her up when I felt she needed me and let her cry when I could tell that she would soon settle back to sleep and i feed her when I felt she was hungry without looking at the clock. Now me and baby are both happy and finally I feel like I am doing a good job!. Mother definatly knows best because every baby is different. No book or expert can tell you how to best parent your baby. Only you can know that. 
And yes I find Y!A to be a very opinionated place when it comes to those rules. As long as we all love our babies and provide what they need then who cares if one mother chooses to feed to sleep and one mother prefers to cry it out. We all do what we feel is best for our children and we cant ask for more then that



</answer>

<answer>



I never listened to the "rules" aside from of course "Back to Sleep", carseat safety, etc.

We have a basic routine but I take things one day at a time and do things based upon when they're tired- hungry- etc.

I also rushed to my girls when they started to cry and I tiptoe when they're sleeping.  Why?  Because if I'm loud they wake up and if I don't rush to them when they start to cry then they wake up the OTHER one.  :-D

I did all kinds of stuff that's against "the rules" but my girls are happy and healthy so what more can I ask for?  :-D

<question>



How can i loose weight without it affecting my breast milk?



Hello mummy's
I put on 3 stone while pregnant and i have lost 2 but this last stone is impossible to loose every time i try to my milk seriously reduces for example this time yesterday morning i got 12oz out of my boob's (i express by the way and don't have any problems until i start losing this final stone) this morning i only got 7oz! this wk so far i have lost 2pounds so why does losing weight affect my milk i'm confused as I actually need to lose another 3 stone yet to be my ideal weight 
Ive not really cut my food down except for not eating the choccy bars cakes etc etc 
How can i lose weight successfully without it affecting my supply??



</question>



<additional details>



For got to mention he is now 11 wks old and i have been expressing since he was 4wks so no probs at all



BTW the i dont get 12 oz at each pump i think it was cos of night time and no feed usually i get 6-7 oz in one go!



</additional details>



<answer from>



becca
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 1778 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I've not heard of women having problems with breast milk because of loosing weight! However I've heard the opposite that breast feeding helps encourage weight loss! Are you doing anything else different besides trying to loose weight? Also it could be a mind thing! I'd get a hold of a lactation specialist that can help you with this. Maybe increase the amount of vitamins you are ingesting without going up in calories and fat! Also if your not drinking enough water during this weight loss then perhaps that is why you have alack of milk. Try increasing the amount of water and liquid you drink! Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Alyssa Nichole // New Mommy!!
Member since: 13 July 2008
Total points: 821 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Breastfeeding is supposed to help you lose the baby weight. I'd make sure that you aren't stressing out about breastfeeding your baby. This could reduce your milk supply. Make sure that you are giving your body enough liquids to keep yourself hydrated, and pump regularly if you can (I pump or feed him every 3 hours for my baby). Breastfeeding is based on supply-and-demand. The more you express or the more your baby feeds, the more milk your body will produce.



If you still are having troubles keeping your supply up.. see a lactation consultant. She will be able to help tremendously.



Here is a link that talks about increasing your supply.
http://www.breastfeeding.com/all_about/f...



Props to you for breastfeeding your baby! Good luck!



Source(s):



mommy of baby boy



</answer>



<answer from>



BEC~ ~Lucy's~ ~Mummy~
Member since: 07 June 2007
Total points: 9814 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



I asked a similar question a little while ago and no-one could understand my problem..,.. everyone just kept telling me that breastfeeding *helps* you lose weight. Well for me, it's like my body takes everything it needs first and whatever's left over goes into milk production...if there's not enough left over (if I haven't eaten enough or if I've done too much exercise) then my supply suffers...so I know exactly what you mean. You just need to take it slowly and not try to lose too much at once. When my daughter was born I said my goal was to get back to pre-preg weight by my SIL's wedding late november....It's less than 10 weeks away and I still have about 8 kilos to go :(
I don't think I will get there but have decided that since Lucy is 7 months and eating solids so well, I am going to take t slowly and aim to lose half a kilo a week (which is the recommendation anyways) and if it effects my supply too much then so be it...

Good luck...just know you're not alone!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Kelly
Member since: 14 August 2008
Total points: 273 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I went to my doctor about the same problem as this, I could not shift the final 4lbs! She said that it was probably just water retention as you reatain a little water whilst bf-ing. Dont forget the weight in your boobs too! Especially as you can express 12oz in a sitting! Fair play, most I ever managed was 1oz!

Only thing that worked for me (and agonisingly slowly) was to have a healthy balanced diet and take more exercise. You need the right food to produce milk rich in all the nutrients, so cutting calories isnt the way to go. Just up exercise!

I hope you lose that stone soon, and good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



fastplay...
Member since: 04 May 2007
Total points: 1197 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Breastfeeding sheds those pounds fast if you are eating right and drinking lots of water!!  However, you wont be able to lose those extra pounds b/c  your body is retaining water and is storing some fat for the milk.  this is normal.  Im exercising right now like i was before i got pregnant and im breastfeeding.  I feel better and i feel like im getting more toned but the weight is not coming off.  Im not worried b/c i know my ody is retaining water and some fat.



You dont want to burn all the fat off while nursing and your body wont let you or it wil be harder if you are nursing.  Continue working out making sure you feed the baby an hour after your work out to preven lactic acid from gtting to the baby and try to pump or feed the baby before going to the gym. Drink tons of water...i mean tons!!  That fills you up, its good for the milk, and it prevents constipation. Your skin also looks better.  Eat right.  Do not diet!  Go ahead and splurge once in awhile. I do!  I refuse to diet and i cheat all the time but im exercising and i know whats im done breastfeeding, those extra pounds willc ome off easier.  I have have to admit that i also use formula or supplement for my baby.  My milk supply has gone down alot but im returning back to work next month.  My baby is turning two months next week.  I still breast feed her but only about 4 times day at most. The rest is with formula when im not home.



My stomach is still very flabby and needs alot of work.  Im doing alot of stomach exercises but i know it wont go away for a while.  It took me about two years to really feel like my old self after i had my first baby.  Now with my second, im so busy with my first one too that im lost my pregnancy weight faster jsut from running around being a mom.  I still have 12 pounds to go but that wont be gone until after im completely done nursing.



</answer>

<question>



My friend has been diagnosed with having Postpartum psychosis...?

Is there any way i could help?

</question>

<answer from>



Mason's Mama
Member since: 07 January 2008
Total points: 3321 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Go see her, take her some magazines or crossword puzzle books to help keep her mind occupied. Yes, you could look after the baby if she needs someone to and you could also go by her place to clean and catch her up on laundry or dishes. Right now the thing she needs most is love, understanding, and support. So, just be there for her!



Source(s):



my own experience with depression



</answer>



<answer from>



Christin...
Member since: 02 June 2007
Total points: 16247 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Wow. I think I was actually one step away from that. I was hospitalized with Severe PPD because I didn't want anything to do with my baby and I was suicidal.



What you can do is look after her baby, call and just talk to her. You should call the hospital and check to see when visiting hours are. Chances are you CAN visit. I was allowed visitors. So was everyone else there.



Another thing, I know you have an infant but you can cook a couple of meals that can be easily frozen so she doesn't have to cook.

Does she have a husband or boyfriend? I'm gathering she doesn't from the way you are talking.



She probably will be put on meds which should help but it will take a few weeks at least for them to kick in. Also maybe if you have the time you can offer to clean her house. Well, maybe not her whole place but maybe just tidy up some? Call and talk to her. Tell her if she needs anything to call you.

I personally understand how hard it can be. I wish you all the luck. I hope she gets the help she needs.



Source(s):



mommy to 6 month old girl



</answer>



<answer from>



Bag
Member since: 26 June 2007

</answer from>



<answer>



She is in the best place she can be right now and her baby has to come second, just for the time being.



Postpartum psychosis is a very dangerous disease and needs to be treated carefully.

My cousin let hers go untreated, then threw herself off a cliff, leaving a few week old baby with no Mummy.



She in the the right place. Visit if they will let you and by all means care for her baby, but they should keep the child at the hospital with her.

<answer from>



I'd rather be at the beach
Member since: 28 May 2008
Total points: 2508 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's your "let down" sometimes it can take a while.  Maybe after her bath, you can pump, just until the let down happens (just until your milk starts to come out).  That way it's ready when she starts to nurse.  I found I had slow let down when feedings were close together.



</answer>

Laurie N

</answer from>



<answer>



How far along is she?  A few days can make a good bit of difference.

Preterm females have a higher survival rate.



Gestational age is not the only criteria for a healthy baby.  Lung development is a biggie.  Did she have any complications, like meconium at delivery?  Is her heart rate stable?  Does she require oxygen?  If so, at what percent?

It might be, and this is just a thought, that the doctor is emphasizing this because he/she thinks your daughter s not taking seriously the danger of preterm delivery.  He or she may think that because she's had five babies she should stop having children.  Doctors are only human and they have their own personal biases, in addition to the huge bias they bring as doctors in our current society.

I have had eight children, four of whom were preterm.  They have never figured out why they were preterm.  After my first preterm baby, the doctor told me I was stressing my body too much and my babies would be increasingly preterm until they could no longer survive.  He was wrong.  My last baby was born one day LATE.

The fact is, babies are created by God and each one has a purpose and extreme value to Him.  Trust God for the outcome He chooses best because He knows way better than doctors.  He can make the impossible possible.  I will pray that God fulfills His purposes in her life and that no weapons formed against her would prosper.  I pray that she has no complications.  Above all, I pray that God's peace, presence and power are with you.



</answer>



<answer from>



mystic_e...
Member since: 21 October 2006
Total points: 87415 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



Generally speaking premature boys do less well than girls.  However the birth weight can mean a lot more than the gestational age (which can be wrong).  There may also be other things wrong with her.

I strongly urge you, grandma, to help mom if mom feels she is not getting the information she needs to know what is going on with her baby.  Mom and Dad are the only ones who can and should make medical decisions for a baby, and they must make informed decisions.

If you can afford it, it can work wonders to have a lawyer drop by the hospital or draft a letter for the baby's file.  Also check the hospital to see if they have a patient advocate to assist, or request a social worker.  Help keep track of information for your daughter.  Obtain copies of the medical file for your daughter (you will likely have to pay per page) AND/OR request that mom or baby's primary physician be provided with copies of all records (this is supposed to be standard practice so that there is one place for all records the next time they are needed, and because the primary care physician should be more knowledgeable about ongoing medical problems)



</answer>

<question>

<answer>

<answer from>



Netty
Member since: 24 September 2007
Total points: 1312 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It really depends how many weeks you are and how the midwife measured it. If it was measured by Ultrasound scan, it's pretty accurate (though not perfect)  and she's probably right that the baby hasn't grown, which could unfortunately be bad news.
If he/she measured the height of the top of your uterus with a tape measure, then the accuracy generally depends on the skill and experience of the person doing the measuring. This way is generally used as a tool to chart the progress of the pregnancy, and a lack of growth from one visit to the next might indicate a problem.

You haven't said how many weeks pregnant you are.....so if you're early on in the pregnancy and the baby isn't growing, the most likely outcome is that you will have a miscarriage. They are very common (about 1 in 5 pregnancies) and there's nothing to blame yourself for -it isn't anything you've done or not done, it's just nature's way. If you're more than 32 weeks and the baby isn't growing, it's possibly a problem with the placenta and doctors may try to induce the baby early.

It's understandable you're upset, but you need to know one way or the other as soon as possible, so why don't you ask your doctor/midwife for further tests? They will probably monitor you carefully anyway and another scan in a week or two's time will tell you more.

Good Luck... it isn't always bad news, I've seen unexpected things happen.



Source(s):



Currently working in an Early Pregnancy Clinic.



</answer>



<answer from>



Maisy D
Member since: 24 August 2008
Total points: 93 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<answer from>



andrew's mommy
Member since: 10 April 2008
Total points: 9116 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Yogurt and cheese are a bit special when it comes to these 2 foods being dairy products. While there is NO great magic in Yogurt or Cheese, the most common reasons for yogurt and cheese being ok for baby prior to age 1 year old are:

Unlike Whole Cow Milk beverage, your baby is not at risk of formula/breast milk being replaced by Yogurt or Cheese.



The medical community worries that if Whole Cow milk is introduced to an infant prior to 1 year old, that parents would stop formula and/or breastfeeding and use Milk as the replacement. This would possibly be dangerous to your baby's health! They, however, neglect to specify the difference between baby drinking milk and eating yogurt and/or cheese.



Lactose is broken down with the culturing of the yogurt or cheese and milk proteins are either semi-removed or limited. The culturing makes yogurt and cheese easier to digest. Many people with lactose intolerance often are be able to eat cheese and/or yogurt without trouble. The same is often true for some people with a milk protein (either to the casein or the whey) allergy.



As mentioned, the one "magical" quality that may be found in Yogurt is that studies show that even people who are lactose intolerant may be able to easily digest Yogurt. Lactose is already converted to lactic acid during the manufacture/culturing of yogurt and people with lactose intolerance (and even the milk protein allergy) often more easily digest it than other dairy products. This digestibility makes yogurt (and even cheese) "ok" for babies 8 months of age and older. Many pediatricians will say that yogurt is fine for babies 6 months of age as well.



Most pediatricians recommend starting your infant on Yogurt around 7-8 months of age. Some pediatricians also recommend yogurt as a great first food (from 6 months+).  Selecting a Whole Milk Yogurt is the most beneficial to your infant as babies need fats in their diets for proper growth!

You can buy Plain Whole Milk Yogurt made by such companies as Stonyfield Farm, Cascade Fresh and Brown Cow. You can also Make Your Own Homemade Yogurt! Stonyfield Farm makes the YoBaby brand that many parents know and love! However, using a large container of Plain Whole Milk yogurt will save you money (and save on added sugar) and give you the flexibility of adding your own flavorings to baby's yogurt. As regards yogurts marketed for for infants (between the ages of 8 months and 12 months old), the YoBaby brand does contain natural organic sugars.



The sugar content is less than in a brand such as Dannimals and it is natural and not refined or chemically processed sugar. There are no additives such as starches, fructose syrup, gelatin etc in the Stonyfield YoBaby brand either. You may be surprised to learn that all yogurts, even the Plain yogurts, will contain sugar. Sugar (lactose) occurs naturally in dairy products. This "dairy" sugar is not an additive and we feel that is an important distinction to make!



How Should I Serve Yogurt?

As long as baby has had the fruits/veggies that you wish to mix in with the Yogurt, you are unlimited in what you use. Some of our favorites are:



Yogurt with applesauce and a dash of cinnamon 
Yogurt and Blueberries 
Yogurt with peaches and bananas together (and separate) 
Yogurt with Wheat Germ and no other addition 
Yogurt and mashed avocado 
Yogurt blended with any fruit and water to create a baby-smoothie (using water makes for a thin mix that may slide through a Sippy Cup with ease) 
Yogurt mixed with veggies - sounds yucky to grown-ups but many babies love yogurt mixed with a veggie!
http://www.wholesomebabyfood.com/tipYogu...

Cheese:
Providing there are no dairy allergies, babies can be introduced to cheese from a relatively young age, around eight months. Cheese can be cut into small pieces and eaten as a finger food or melted over vegetables, pasta or on bread.

Yogurt:
Yogurt can be introduced in the diet from eight months onwards, providing there are no dairy allergies. Yogurt is a good source of calcium and “friendly” bacteria that helps the digestion system do it’s job.



Yogurt is also a good source of the fats that are so mportant to a baby in it’s first years.



Yogurt is also a great way for baby to get the fat that is so highly needed during baby’s first year. Check the labels for additives, sugars and starches.



Source(s):



Mommy of a 10 month old boy



</answer>



<answer from>



mystic_e...
Member since: 21 October 2006
Total points: 87415 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



There is no one answer to your question.  Many experts suggest 9 months, some say 6, and a growing group say that the order that you introduce solids is not important as long as you wait until 6 months.

http://www.askdrsears.com/faq/fit23.asp
MILK VS. YOGURT FOR BABIES
"Hello Dr. Bob and Jim:
Why is it OK to give a 9 month old baby yogurt made with whole milk and NOT OK to give a 9 month old baby whole milk to drink?
Thank you for your response."

click here

The answer is that if you give an infant under a year cow’s milk, the infant can develop microscopic gastrointestinal bleeding (you don’t see it in the diaper), and this can lead to anemia and other problems. Yogurt does not cause this same reaction. Now: WHY does this happen? It seems to be the milk proteins that are responsible for this mild allergic reaction. In yogurt or infant formulas, the milk proteins are “de-natured” by heat in such a way that this allergic reaction does not happen.



Full Fat Yogurt for Infants and Toddlers
http://www.drgreene.com/21_1697.html

http://www.westonaprice.org/children/nou...
At Six Months

Early introduction to different tastes is always a good plan to prevent finickiness. Feed your little one a touch of buttermilk, yogurt or kefir from time to time to familiarize them with the sour taste. Lacto-fermented roots, like sweet potato or taro, are another excellent food for babies to add at this time.1



http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/9646449/page...
Food allergy fears get some of the blame for the bland approach. For decades doctors have said the best way to prevent allergies is to limit infants to bland foods, avoiding seasonings, citrus, nuts and certain seafood.

But Butte's review found no evidence that children without family histories of food allergies benefit from this. Others suspect avoiding certain foods or eating bland diets actually could make allergies more likely. Some exposure might be a good thing.



http://www.kellymom.com/newman/17feed_ba...
3. Babies need to drink milk when the mother is not at home.

Not true. Three or four good nursings during a 24 hour period plus a variety of solid foods gives the baby all he needs nutritionally, and thus he does not need any other type of milk when you are at your outside job. Of course, solid foods can be mixed with expressed milk or other milk, but this is not necessary.

[...]

5. Babies need to drink milk to get calcium.

Not true. If you are worried about the baby’s intake of calcium, he can eat cheese or yogurt. There is no need to drink the calcium. Besides, if the baby is also breastfeeding, breastmilk still contains calcium.



</answer>

<answer>



Yogurt may be introduced as early as 7 months old, (the typical age recommendation is 8 months old) depending on your baby’s pediatrician and your baby’s propensity to allergies.
Cheeses are typically offered to the non-allergic baby between 8 and 10 months of age.  If your baby has a known or suspected dairy allergy (either a milk protein or lactose intolerance) then you should wait to introduce cheese and other dairy when your infant is older.



Source(s):

<question>



My baby is 5 months but he wont drink all of his milk now why?

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



20oz is the minimum required until a year old. I'm having the same problem but i think I've found the solution.

My girl wakes up at 6am every morning (bummer eh?) and I give her 6oz of milk and after about 2 hours she has her breakfast. Only give half a jar of baby food. At about 12 shes hungry again and I give her milk (6oz) again. Then at 2 or 3pm half a jar of babyfood. Then at 6 she gets the other jar and a wee bit of dessert. Then at 8pm after her bath she gets 8oz to fill her up until morning. Sometimes I have to feed her half of the last bottle at 10 or 11pm. Usually she's out cold and will drink it. Sometimes not.



Anyway - try not to worry about it too much. When the growth spurt hits at 5 and half months- My Evie is nearly 6 months and is eating like theres no tomorrow.



Its only a phase and try not to get caught up HV's. They always make us feel stupid, but we are not!
Edit- can i also point out that baby food jars say that you can feed a hungry baby from 4 months. My doctor also advised me to do as your doing- breakfast lunch and dinner. No harm says the doctor so i'm going with it and she's more healthy than other babies I've seen. Not a single day sick since she was born.



</answer>

<answer>



He's probably getting too full with  his solids.

Three meals and a couple of snacks is a HUGE amount of solid food for a 5 month old.  At this age he really shouldn't have any solids at all, and if you are going to offer them (6 months is the usual time to begin) one or two SMALL meals a day is more than ample.

I would just stop the solids for a couple of weeks. He'll be hungrier,and will take his formula. Then you can SLOWLY add solids back in.



(He needs at LEAST 24 ounces of formula a day, and most babies are taking in the 30-40 ounce range.)



</answer>

<answer>



http://www.drgreene.org/body.cfm?id=21&a...
At this stage, most of the nutrition still comes from breast milk or formula. The solids provide wonderful experience with flavors, textures, and the mechanics of eating. As the amount of solids they take increases, most babies settle into a pattern of 3 meals of solids each day. The amount of formula tends to drop off a bit, but typically still falls in the range of 6 to 8 ounce bottles given 3 to 5 times a day. Most commonly, a smaller bottle (or half a bottle) is given with each meal and a larger one at bedtime. Some babies also enjoy a bottle first thing in the morning.

A baby can have up to 32 ounces of formula per day. In addition, he can have as much in the way of solids, water, or juice as he wants to supplement this. The mealtime formula is usually given at the end of the meals, to top off the solids in a comfortable and easy way. Even though the solids are now playing a larger role, the breast milk or formula still provides the core of the nutritional needs. If a baby begins to regularly take less than about 20 ounces per day, you might want to offer the bottle first and then solids.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 19 May 2006
Total points: 140 (Level 1)

<answer>



Yes. It is very rare, but it is possible. Two white parents can have a black child if both parents have a white dominant gene and a black recessive gene. Thus, if the child does not receive either parents dominant gene, it will be black. Two black parents can also have a white child.



Source(s):



WikiAnswers



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



What age does child infancy go up to?



</question>



<answer from>



I love being a mummy!
Member since: 12 March 2008

<question from>



Renee M
Member since: 24 March 2008
Total points: 166 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I want to teach my 10 month old  to fall asleep on his own but everytime I leave him to cry it out, he vomits.?



I will go through the routine of feeding him his bottle, in my arms, rock him and sing to him, and i will put him in his crib, knowing he is tired and ready for a nap/bed and i will leave the room and he will cry. I try going back in 15 minute intervals to rub his back and shhh him and leave the room again. I have even tried staying in the room with him. But every time, he gets so worked up he vomits, then I have to take him out of his crib to clean up the mess which defeats the whole process. What shall I do?



</question>



<answer from>



Hunters Mom & A GIRL ON THE WAY
Member since: 28 June 2007
Total points: 3649 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Instead of rocking him and singing to him put him in his crib with a toy and some music. I got a great lulliby CD that plays 24/7 in my sons room it helps with the silence and when I put him in his crib I would often put a toy in with him that he can either play with till he falls asleep or when he gets up in the morning he will often play with it till he is ready to be out of his crib. about 30 min or so of extra sleep!



Source(s):



Mommy of an AMAZING 14 month old BOY and a baby GIRL coming this WINTER!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Gracie's mommy
Member since: 24 April 2008
Total points: 393 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Honestly, and it sounds gross, but you need to leave him alone once you leave the room. It's not going to hurt him if he falls asleep one time in his vomit (my daughter did one time in her sleep and I never even knew until the morning) and you going back in there in intervals teaches him that you WILL come back as long as he keeps crying (called graduated extinction). After you lay him down, do NOT go back in there until he is asleep (total extinction). Don't worry about the mess; he'll be fine. Do this for a couple of nights. Sometimes it takes a week or longer and sometimes there will be relapses, but it works. I started sleep-training with my daughter at 2 months and she cries whenever I lay her down but is asleep within 5 minutes. I have also used the exact same lullaby CD since she was born, and she knows that when she hears that music, it's sleepy time. Works well when we're staying at motels and such, because as soon as she hears the songs she goes to sleep. I did however train her a little TOO well to sleep in her crib, as she won't sleep anywhere else, whether it be the car or her stroller. Oh well - you win some you lose some.



Source(s):



mommy to wonderful 10 month old
nanny and preschool/daycare worker
Book "Healthy Sleep Habits, Happy Child"



</answer>



<answer from>



Kat Hayes
Member since: 30 March 2008
Total points: 241 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



My son did this as well- he got so cranky he would either spew or bang his head against the side of the cot.
I constantly kept going into the room to clean him until one day i just left it. He DID spew all over his bedsheets but then fell asleep. I left him a full 5 minutes (because they need that to fully fall asleep) and went in and cleaned him up.
My line of thinking was that a bit of throw up on him isnt going to hurt him- sleep is more important- and i could clean him up more easily when he was asleep anyway!
It took a couple of times but he eventually got the message and wasnt upset anymore. 
You might also try propping him up a bit when you pop him into his cot as he might be thrwing up because he is lying down and getting upset- propping him up might make him throw up less.
I hope this helps



</answer>



<answer from>



atomride...
Member since: 22 March 2006
Total points: 141 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Distraction. Music or toys, or tv. Something that interests him.

Or the bed is too hard. Or there is something there that scares him. Colors, materials, etc.

A mobile with a light that shines stars on the ceiling.



</answer>

_CEO__7_

<answer>



this is how i taught my girl without allowing her to cry it out.

dinner - 5.50pm

bath with lavender bubbles, then a massage and PJs - 6.10pm

in the night garden is on - 6.20pm - 6.50pm

we read a story and have some milk - 6.50pm

then she plays till she starts fussing, rubbing her eyes etc



when she does this, we pick up her fave toy - soft upsy daisy - say our night nights, kisses, cuddles, into cot with a dummy, and turn her lullaby light on.

i leave the room.

after 20sec, she whines realising im not in the room, i go back in tell her its ok, mummy is just in the other room, its bedtime etc then leave the room again. i continue to do this till she falls asleep.

1st night took 20min
2nd night took 15min
3rd night took 10min
4th night took 5min

thereafter when i leave the room i dont need to go back in anymore as she doesnt whine for me, she just cuddles upsy daisy and watches the lighty up stars on her lullaby light. i go in 10min after i put her down, and she is sound asleep.



Source(s):

<answer>



An extra sippy cup or bottle with nothing in it! Snacks! Diapers, wipes, and desitine! Also a change of close in case of accidents. A bib for eating! <question from>



heyayall
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What can I do to stop my four month old from crying when others nurse her.?



As soon as someone other than myself nurses my 4 month old baby she starts crying. This is only a recent thing and she never done it when she was younger. She is like this with absolutely everyone other than myself including her Aunt and Uncle who live with us and she is around all the time.



She also will not settle to sleep anywhere other then her cot...including her porta cot and pram.

Any help would be appreciated as I am a first time mum and am unsure about this sort of stuff.



</question>



<answer from>



Gracie's mommy
Member since: 24 April 2008
Total points: 393 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Are you around when she's getting a bottle? That could be a problem, as she is old enough now to know that you have the "real thing" and smart enough to know that if she refuses the bottle enough, mommy will give in to feeding her. Have someone give her a bottle with you where she can't see her and even if she consistently refuses it, have them keep trying. She will eventually take it if she's really hungry. She's just old enough to play favorites and is proving it.

As for the sleeping, make sure the bedtime routines stay the same, no matter where she sleeps. Act like nothing is different. One thing that worked for my daughter is a lullaby CD. It's the same one she's heard since she was born and I only play it at sleep times. When she hears the music, she knows that it is time to sleep. Hope this helps.



Source(s):



Mommy to 10 month old
nanny and daycare/preschool worker



</answer>



<answer from>



Kat Hayes
Member since: 30 March 2008
Total points: 241 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I find that my son is more willing to go to someone else who has one of his toys and shows him first. He almost jumps out of my arms to get at the toy- and doesnt care whose got him.
To get him to sleep elsewhere- I had to train him to associate some item with sleep instead of a PLACE. So I bought him a little teddy and sprayed it with my perfume. Now when he gets his teddy and i hum a certain tune- he knows its sleepy time. t5his takes a while for them to learn but be consistent and you will be surprised how quickly they will pick it up.



</answer>



<answer from>



Silly, boy! Tricks are 4 whores
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



When babys get a bit older, some starts to act that way. Are you around when someone holds her? Here's a trick that I do for my baby...
When she is a sleep, rap her in a babys balanket, then when the nurse holds her, she will be ok. Keep doing this until she gets use to of having people hold her



</answer>

<answer from>



Heather Y

</answer from>



<answer>



My dentist calls apple juice "cavity juice" and we've avoided juice with our kids for the most part.  Juice is full of sugar, even "no sugar added" juice.  It is in no way a substitute for an actual piece of fruit.  I'm not a total no juice nazi or anything, but I would say my kids only have it about 3-4 times per year.



</answer>



<answer from>



Yummy Mummy#

<answer>



Hi there,

Yes you shouldnt give your child juice in the first year give him water only. But if you do want to give your child juice the best thing to give him is fresh juice give it to him one part juice to 10 parts of water. Thats is what my denist told me to give my son.

But only give it after a meal as it does not harm there teeth as much.

Good Luck hunni but i would take your dentist advice xx

<answer from>



LaDonna
Member since: 01 August 2008
Total points: 401 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I use it with my 7 month old son, but very rarely and I always dilute it down by half. He generally only drinks like an ounce of it at a time as he is still getting used to it. I have never heard of it causing tooth decay but it makes sense if it has acid in it. I give him grape juice only cuz I have heard its not good to give them apple juice just yet since its hard on there body anyways. If you are worried about it then you can always brush her gums with a very small and soft brissle tooth brush after she drinks the juice or else just give her water till her teeth come in. I am a very teeth concious person. I love my teeth and my smile and would never want to ruin it so I would do the same for my child. I am not worried about it at all and I wont stop giving it to him unless I am told otherwise. Its a decision that has to be up to you. Use your best judgement. You should also reasearch it online. I think that once the child is 6 months juice is fine to give them so long as it is diluted.



</answer>



<answer from>



bubbles
Member since: 30 June 2008
Total points: 611 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



rarely i always give my baby water i would like her to develop the taste for water rather than juice and if i do give her juice i use sugar free

Mom to 3 Awesome Kids

<answer>



Your dentist is right.  With my son, (he is my first) I gave him juice from about 6 months on, and I even put him to bed with it sometimes.  ( I know now that is very very bad) When my son was 3, he had to get almost all of his back teeth capped, I think only 2 only needed fillings.  Thankfully, since I got it taken care of so early it didn't damage any of his adult teeth. He is now 10 and hasn't had a cavity since he had all of his work done.



My daughter is 4, and just had to have a few fillings, she never went to bed with juice, just milk a couple of times.

<answer>



Yes, I have used it in the past.

When Em first started on vegetables, she was very constipated. She would cry and her bottom would bleed when she would finally go. Our pediatrician recommended 1 ounce 100% fruit juice mixed with 3 ounces of water, which I did, and it helped.

As for the concern about tooth decay, I use a small finger brush and baby gum cleaner every other day to clean her gums. When she has teeth I'll help her brush her teeth twice a day.



There are many warnings out there about the harm that comes from formula, juice, vaccinations, etc., but as parents, it is our job to do research and decide what to absorb and what to let pass through. I've decided that I'd rather clean her teeth more often than watch her scream and cry as she tried to poop.



</answer>
