<answer>



firstly, sleep when your baby sleeps.  You need to rest.  If you can't rest when you've just had a baby, when can you?  Enjoy your time while your baby us so small, he will get big very quickly and you will wonder where the time went.  All of a sudden he's 4 months and the new born stage is gone.  Get some magazines and relax while you can.  Buy a yoga DVD, continue with baby groups and strive to meet other mums to perhaps go for a coffee with or go for lunch once a month.  I know it's hard and frustrating.  I had my girls 13 months apart when I was 21 and 22.  I didn't know anyone and my husband was working morning noon and night for cr*p money.  We were skint, I was lonely and I didn't even have my mum because she was in Ireland and I was in England.  Then came the post natal depression.  Relax and think  of the great future all that study is going to provide for yo and your family in the future.  congratulation by the way!! xx

Daisygir...
Member since: 07 April 2007
Total points: 4634 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I know how hard this is, as I too had a fabulous, busy job before my first child was born and I found it hard being at home with a baby.  My baby was very grizzly and colickly and we were both miserable!  My friends also worked at the time and the ones with children lived far away.  However, by the time my first daughter was six months old, we were having a great time!  First of all, I made sure I got out every day - whether it was going for a walk in the pram, going to the shops just to look around, having a coffee and reading a book at a coffee shop while she slept, that sort of thing.  I also left her at the local creche while I went swimming as the total cost was about AUD$6.00.  As my daughter got older, she became far more interactive, and I could take her to other different things such as Gymbaroo (started that at about 5 months I think) and Playgroup (started at 11 months).  There, I met other mothers and made new friends.  Do you go to a mothers' group with your local parenting nurse?  If there's anyone there you like the look of, invite them to the movies or to your house for a cuppa.  Do you have movie sessions where you live that you can go to with your baby, it eats up some time and gets you out of the house.  Also, accept babysitting offers whenever you can, just so you can go out and feel like a person again.  Time out for yourself, even if just for an hour to get your hair cut or to have a swim or a walk, is really important.  I found it hard the first few months, but after a while, I made a new routine at home and enjoyed it!



</answer>

</question>



<answer from>

<answer>



My son started to crawl around 7 months.

<answer from>



Alicia
Member since: 18 April 2007
Total points: 1666 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think the average is around nine months, but it can start as early as seven and a half months.  To encourage crawling, put something your child wants just out of his reach.  Usually a favorite toy will work.  A friend of mine's baby would never crawl for toys, but at eight months old he would crawl for food.



</answer>



<answer from>



Portland
Member since: 27 February 2007
Total points: 1457 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The average is 8-9 months but some babies start at 6 months or as late as 14 months....some go straight to walking.

They'll do it when they're ready,  so there's not much to do to encourage.  Just be supportive when they try.

<question from>



Tara Kay
Member since: 13 September 2008
Total points: 97 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What are some gross motor activities for infants?



I need some ideas for Gross/fine motor activities for infants. I also need ideas for sensory play for infant. I good site would be great too.



</question>



<answer from>



Little Man's Mom
Member since: 25 April 2008
Total points: 4480 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It really depends on the age of your infant.  My son is 8 months now and here are some activities I do with him:

Gross Motor:
*Sing "The Wheels on the Bus" and do action with him --In particular "the people on the bus go up & down" --I stand him up and put him down.
*Let him sit and play (develops balance & back muscles)
*Let him have tummy time (pre-crawling exercises and develops back & neck muscles)
*Hold his hands or waist and let him stand (Develop leg muscles and balance)
*Stand him up against the couch (for balance and leg strength)

Fine motor:
*Let him play with/eat cheerios or gerber graduates puffs (develops pincher grasp)
*Sing "Itsy Bisty Spider" with actions
*Sing "Patty Cake" with actions
*SIng "Head, Shoulders, Knees, & Toes" with actions
*Give him many shapes, sizes, and textures of toys to play with & explore while he is sitting or having tummy time (blocks, stuffed animals, measuring cups, balls, sippy cup, tummy time mat, etc, etc, etc)

Good luck & Have fun.
Also, don't forget to read to your baby!!  Babies looooove books



Source(s):



Mommy of an 8 month old



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks so much!



</asker's comment>

<question>



Breast milk amount dwindling?



I used to breastfeed by pumping and nursing and still am. The last couple days ago, I was really busy. Instead of pumping every 3 hours, I found out that if I pump only every time I feel engorged, I can produce so much more milk. So that's what I did.



Now I realize that somehow I don't feel that intense engorgement anymore. My breasts just produce bare enough of milk about twice or maybe three times a day (?) Sorry I was really really busy that I lost count. I don't normally really count anyway, just stick to the schedule to pump every 3 hours. I got panic so I try pumping again every 3 hours, nonetheless I produce very little amount of milk, about 1 ounce for 20 minutes of pumping, while normally I produce about 2 ounces. That last couple days ago when I pumped only every time I feel intense engorgement, I could produce up to 3 ounces.

I'm so worried, my son is 2 months old and I wish that I can feed him with breastmilk for at least 3 months, if not more.



What can I do? Keep pumping and hopefully the milk production will go back to normal? I've been drinking gallons of water, taking 9 capsules of fenugreek every day.



Any insights will be so appreciated.



</question>



<answer from>

try brewers yeast it is so grose but 100% works i have been breastfeeding for 19 mo now and went through this i tried pumping to up the supply but not much came out i took fenugreek capsuals even these other capsuals called lactation support pills found in health food stors still nothing worked then i bought brewers yeast wich is full of vitamns believe it or not. and i was literly over making again i was ful full full!!!! i warn u it taste nasty but whatever it takes right? people back in the day would ue this to up milk supply look it up but heres a hint the only way i could drink it was 2 scoops of it in a tall glass of oj that is the only way i could get it down really i GARENTEE it

Also the reason why u slowed down is because when u stopped puping 3x a day and u went to one ur breast thought u needed less milk therefore going down on ur supply! it supply and demand the more u pump the more u make what u did was a sure way to make less milk but no fear u can bring it back up continue to pump and feed the baby as many times as u can along with what i suggested! the reason y u were engorged was because u went down from pumping 3x to 1 at first ur breast thought thy needed all that milk so it took a day or 2 for them to see that u only were pumping 1x therefore tricking ur bereast into thinking they need to make less milk! Isnt it amazing how r bodies can figure that out. also i know by waiting till u were engored u were pumping more milk but the reason for this is u had already skipped 2 pumping sessions there for u were stocked up. ALWAYS REMEMBER SUPPLY AND DEMAND the more u emty the more u will couninue to fill back up keep drinking plenty of water as u are already! stopp stressing ur body also feels that and may cause u to go down on milk supply. <answer from>



Gracie's mommy
Member since: 24 April 2008
Total points: 393 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



By only pumping when you were engorged, you made your mind think your son was needing less breastmilk than he really needs. To increase your milk supply again, pump AFTER he eats, so your mind realizes it needs to make more. It will take a couple days to a week for you to see a significant increase, but it will come. Whatever you do, DON'T supplement with formula, as this will decrease your milk supply even more. As for not getting as much out as you used to, its because you stopped pumping so much. Again, pump after (not before) he eats and even if you stop getting milk out, continue pumping for 10 more minutes. The suckling makes your mind realize it needs to make more breastmilk and will do so. Also, make sure to pump both sides equally, or you'll be like me, with a daughter that plays favorite on the right breast and hates the left so mommy doesn't care and now has lopsided boobs! Hope this helps.



Source(s):



mommy to 10 month old



</answer>



<answer from>



Samuel's Mommy!
Member since: 16 August 2007
Total points: 389 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Honey, I think i was in the same boat you are, about a month ago, when my baby was 2 months, my milk supply went waaaaaaay under. I didn't pump or anything, i was just feeding him every 3 hours, then I realized he was always hungry after each feeding, i freaked out, just like you did cuz I was also planning to breast feed for quite some time! My friend told me that it's normal, almost every mom experiences the low milk supply around 1.5- 3 months postpartum. I just kept feeding him and letting him suck longer then usual and now, he gets enough milk!

But when I'm really active or busy doing something active, my milk supply will go down because it's wasting energy on doing something else then producing milk. I've noticed that in mylself.

Hope this was helpful. Good luck and Congrats on the baby!



Source(s):



mommy to 3 month old



</answer>

<answer from>



Pin - Stealing Yer Cupcakes
Member since: 03 July 2007
Total points: 26140 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think it is a matter of bed space, privacy and liability.

Most mothers share a room - and unless you're willing to pay the price of a private room, freeing up the other bed, you're going to run into issues with women who don't feel comfortable with a man not their husband, doctor or nurse in the room,

The liability is on the hospital - if they let an untrained husband do something rather than a trained nurse, something bad could potentially happen.

there are birthing centers, and birthing centers in some hospitals that do allow that- you'd have to look about and see if there were any in your area.

My husband was there all through the birth, and afterward, but first time, I sent him home to care for the dog and to get some sleep since he had to work the next day, and the second time, he had our toddler to take care of.



</answer>



<answer from>



iHαnnαh (εstoy bαstαntε biεn)
Member since: 09 July 2007
Total points: 10190 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have never really heard of that. I mean sure, sometimes new dad's are pretty annoying when in the labor/delivery room because they are all nervous but it's adorable too because they mean well. But they don't try to kick them out or ask them to leave. The partner should always be included in the birth of a baby unless they don't want to be there.



</answer>

<question>



Do babies need pacifiers?



</question>



<answer from>



Ktloop
Member since: 18 August 2007
Total points: 1991 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



some do, some dont. My daughter would not sleep without sucking on something, after 2 days of her sucking on my nipple for comfort I gave in an gave her a dummy (pacifier)  To be honest if she has to suck something I would rather it be a dummy that i can throw away than a thumb . If a baby is not interested in sucking tho , I wouldnt give a dummy as it is hard to break the habit (not as hard as a thumb tho !)  Hope this answers your question :)



</answer>



<asker's comment>



True If she has to suck - She can have a pacifier - Its much better than a thumb or fingers!



Thanks!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



stacki
Member since: 12 November 2007
Total points: 743 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



it depends on the baby; my son didn't take one unless he was hungry;so if we were out somewhere, and he was due for a feed and i couldn't get him the food right then and there id give him his dummy and he'd be fine... nw he has it quite a lot as he is only 3 months and teething and its the only thin he'll suck on... but its so much easier to throw away,,, whereas if they want to suck something they will suck their fingers which can cause so many more problems...



</answer>



<answer from>



Lisa C
Member since: 07 July 2008
Total points: 529 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



They do not NEED pacifiers, but if you with to help soothe them or calm them down from time to time, they can be so very handy. They say breastfed babies should not get them too often because it could hinder their sucking at the breast and give them another "option." Once latching is established and milk supply is good then it is no problem if you ask me. My daughter gets one when we are in the car and I can't feed her or she is just angry, or when we are trying to get her to sleep.

Babies have an overwhelming need to suck. even when they are not feeding so it will come in handy! Some parents just prefer not to use them. I was the loony kid who wouldn't give it up 'til about 4yoa :\



</answer>



<answer from>



first time mommie
Member since: 03 July 2008
Total points: 173 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't give my baby a pacifier, but she sucks on her fingers. so that's up to the parent. I don't give her one because the tell u if your breast feeding, you shouldn't give the baby a pacifier because you don't want to confuse them. So that's mostly up to you.



</answer>



<answer from>



BEC~ ~Lucy's~ ~Mummy~
Member since: 07 June 2007
Total points: 9816 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



They don't NEED them as such but most babies have a strong urge to suck and a paci meets that urge when a mother's breast cannot for whatever reason.
My daughter was about 6 weeks when I introduced one as she would be on the breast for about 4 hours straight every evening and I was exhausted. She wasn't drinking at this time just comfort sucking but as soon as I took her off she would scream. I still put her on the breast every half an hour so that if she was hungry she could eat but generally she just fell straight asleep.



</answer>



<answer from>



new.mum2...
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 172 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most babies from 0 to 3 months have a strong sucking reflex and want to suck for comfort. Some babies more than others. A few don't like pacifiers.

My little one is 7 weeks and I introduced a pacifier when she was 4 weeks as breastfeeding was well established by then and she wouldnt get confused with the latching on. Till then I had felt like a human pacifier as she wanted to suck all day!

Some days she takes it, other days she spits it out after screwing up her face.

After 3 months of age a pacifier just becomes a habit since they lose their sucking reflex then anyway. I am planning to wean her off it after she is 3 months.



</answer>



<answer from>



Emma's MumMum & 25 Weeks 2 #

Vegan_Mo...

<answer>



My daughter who is one year old today didn't take to a pacifier or a bottle of breast milk. Personally, I'm pleased. I wasn't crazy about the thought of her having something artificial. I guess she's her mother's daughter. When she was younge, she did take to sucking my pinkie. Eventually, she started to suck her own fingers, which she also out grew.



Personally, I didn't mind my daughter comfort sucking on my nipples. (Well, when I was hungry or had to go to the bathroom and my husband wasn't home, it wasn't so good. I got into the habit of keeping granola bars and dried cerealy and dried fruit on the sofa and would fill my water bottle before sitting down if I had to, even if she had to wait a couple more minutes.) I would think it would be more comforting for a baby to be curled up next to his or her mother sucking her breast than some fake rubber thing.



Recently, I saw a girl who looked to be about three with a pacifier in her mouth. It just seemed too old for something like that and I was just thankful that my daughter didn't take to one.



</answer>



<answer from>



LAmama
Member since: 27 August 2006
Total points: 716 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Nope.  In fact, allowing a baby to use a pacifier in the early weeks when they are learning to breastfeed can lead to nursing difficulties (there's a different technique for sucking at the breast and sucking on an artificial nipple).  If you allow a young baby free access to the breast, there is usually no need for pacifiers.  Sometimes it is useful to try one in the car if your baby doesn't like to be in her carseat, though!



</answer>

Shes at the stage where she is very curious & active so how would I be able to control/calm her on a long flight? 
Also, what should I be aware of in an Arab country in terms of diseases or sanitation.?
Any tips or advice from people who've had experience would be wonderful! Thankyou!



</question>

<answer>



Ahh you know when i took mine on a long flight she slept almost all of the way, just had to change her in the bathrooms or feed her. Ask when you check in to get a cot, its really handy, plus you get more leg room. Make sure you take enough food and water and keep it all handy in a little bag. .
Maybe take her a little toy, even one of them ones she can chew on, maybe the tv screen will distract her a little, but the motion of  the flight should keep her calm. The only big worry is there ears popping, so if you can time it well just after you take off feed the baby to help prevent that or let them such on a pacifier if they have one. As for diseases you should have been told by your doctor if the baby needs shots. Just stay away from there water, make sure you sterilize it. If your baby is eating baby food you may want to see about taking what she is used to. if not im sure there is somewhere out there that you can get some american food. A change in diet can cause the baby to have the shits hehe. Well i hope all goes well and have a great trip.



</answer>

<answer from>



Seuss
Member since: 20 September 2007
Total points: 176 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Don't get stressed out. I took my 8 month old son to Asia on a 13 hour flight with a stopover and then another 2 hour flight! Trust me - no stopovers is the way to go. Pack a variety of her favourite food and toys. Don't give them to her all at once - let her play until she's bored, take the next toy/food out. My son was busy wiht the hook button and the drop down tray button so that was another plus. Looking out the window and sliding the cover up and down was another great form of distraction. It drove me insane but it was great for him. Also bring her favourite toy that she brings to bed should she sleep on the plane. Bring a spare top for yourself in case of spit ups etc.



</answer>



<answer from>



KeepSmil...
Member since: 10 April 2008
Total points: 4346 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



take lots of activities on the plane for your little one. allow him to explore and more around sometimes as it can be fustrating stuck in a seat for too long.

take steriliser tablets with you and lots of wipes etc for cleaning hands before your little one eats. Avoid salads, ice, water thats not from a bottle, undercooked foods in general.  make sure you are happy in the place you are eating (does it look clean etc) in general the same rules that apply when going to any country. i live in egypt and never have an upset stomach even though im quite sensitive because im careful about what i eat and where i eat.  Suncream and a sun hat for your little one is essential and be wary of taxi drivers.  dubai i wonderful though you will have a lovely time.



</answer>

<question>



QUESTION ABOUT BABY FEEDING BOTTLES, ANYONE HELP?



my son is 32 week, and i would say for the past 5 days or so, when i am giving him a feed from a bottle, he is drinking it, and the teat collapses continually

Is this because its too slow for him? Or too fast flowing??
i have not noticed any difference when breast feeding, but saying that i'm kinda nonsensitive in that area lol.

thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



sophie d
Member since: 24 June 2008
Total points: 1012 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



well it seems that theres not alot of air in the teates i used to have that problem too and would have to keep unscrewing the the bottle lid all the time i just got another teate and that worked :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Glenna
Member since: 20 April 2007
Total points: 22763 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its because he's sucking so hard that its making it collapse.  I suggest getting a nipple with a faster flow, so that he won't have to suck so hard to get the milk.



</answer>



<answer from>



T B
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 829 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on the brand of bottles you are using but the ring is probably screwed on too tight. They make nipples with ridges on the inside to prevent collapse you could try those. Good luck.



Source(s):



Mom of 3



</answer>



<answer from>



Les
Member since: 29 March 2008
Total points: 2951 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



he is sucking it really hard trying to get milk out, it could be that its too slow, try a faster teat, but my son seems to like it like that and doesnt like his milk flowing too fast, when it collapses just take the teat out his mouth until it regains its shape and give it back to him!



</answer>



<answer from>



Mama_Ihe...
Member since: 26 August 2007
Total points: 2770 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Once the teat starts collapsing you need to move up to a faster flow teat. I personally think that the best teats are avent ones although they are extremely expensive. I have also found that for some reason the teats on standard neck bottles do not seem to collapse.



</answer>

<question from>



kass ♥

</question from>



<question>



How long is it ok to let them 'cry it out' ?



My baby is 6 months old and no matter how hard I try I cannot get him to bed any earlier then 1:30 AM. He can be so tired and still fight it until at least that time. I didn't believe in the cry it out method, but thinking its time to try it, as much as it breaks my heart. Last night I gave him a bath, read him a book, put on lullaby's. He was so tired fell asleep at 9:30 PM. Woke up at 10 pm and started crying. Cried until 12 am. Finally I couldn't take it anymore, and went and picked him up. It was breaking my heart!

<answer>



Short answer, take your child to the Doctor.  A 6 month old child should be able to sleep longer than 30 minutes that late at night.  He might be allergic to something that is causing him discomfort.  It could be nothing.  But, when someone has no language skills beyond crying, like children, the best bet is a translator, i.e. Doctor.



Several of our children could not sleep well at night if they were over stimulated during the day.  Maybe you could reduce the amount of noise, activity, many people handling them, etc., and see if that helps!  Quite a few of our family and friends got really mad at us, because we did not allow our small ones to be passed around at gatherings.  So, my stock answer became, do you want to come home with us and sit up with our baby all night?  Because he will be up all night otherwise....

I also do not agree with letting babies crying it out.



Good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



is he always like this? if not he could be teething or sickening for something, so leaving him for 2 hours to cry, isnt something id advise.

get a good solid routine, dont ever deviate from it, if it mean you need to stay in all week to get him into the pattern then so be it. this is my routine.



this is how i taught my girl without allowing her to cry it out.

dinner - 5.50pm

bath with lavender bubbles, then a massage and PJs - 6.10pm

in the night garden is on - 6.20pm - 6.50pm

we read a story and have some milk - 6.50pm

then she plays till she starts fussing, rubbing her eyes etc



when she does this, we pick up her fave toy - soft upsy daisy - say our night nights, kisses, cuddles, into cot with a dummy, and turn her lullaby light on.

i leave the room.

after 20sec, she whines realising im not in the room, i go back in tell her its ok, mummy is just in the other room, its bedtime etc then leave the room again. i continue to do this till she falls asleep.

1st night took 20min
2nd night took 15min
3rd night took 10min
4th night took 5min

thereafter when i leave the room i dont need to go back in anymore as she doesnt whine for me, she just cuddles upsy daisy and watches the lighty up stars on her lullaby light. i go in 10min after i put her down, and she is sound asleep.



the lavender bubbles and massage relaxes her to the point where she is tired but doesnt want to sleep because she wants to play, so i let her play till she is literally ready to fall down.



how many naps does he take a day, maybe try to work toward taking his last nap away, or shortening it. my girl naps for 1hr in the afternoon. she sleeps 12hrs straight at night, waking but self soothing in between.



</answer>

<question>



Breastfeeding and supplementing? ?



My baby is 18 days old, and i breast feed exclusively, but she eats every two hours for an hour or more. My question is, is this normal? I am so exhausted, and friends are telling me if i give my baby formula at night she will sleep longer. I just want the best for my baby. Also whats the best formula for a newborn? Has anyone else done this?



</question>



<additional details>



yup she eats the whole time, and sometimes after she acts hungry still, so i give her a pacifier.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Matilda-...
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 390 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your baby is trying to build up the milk supply that is why she is feeding so frequently.

Make sure you are drinking plenty of fluids to help build up your supply.

Are you sure she is really feeding for the entire hour or is she just suckling for comfort?

I think  a good 10 minutes each side should do, burp her and then if she wants more give her some more.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bridget M
Member since: 20 August 2008
Total points: 255 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Talk to your lactation consultant or peditracian. Also, have you tried pumping and giving your milk to baby in a bottle. This is good for 2 reasons...if your baby is having trouble getting it out of your breast and someone else can feed the baby while you get much needed rest. Formula will not 'hurt' your baby however breast milk is best and you should discuss this with the baby's doctor. Good luck and much rest!



</answer>



<answer from>



natsum19...
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 162 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



MMMMMMM



</answer>



<answer from>



Mummy Moo
Member since: 20 April 2007
Total points: 826 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



She is just trying to build up your milk supply, but she could also be sucking for comfort rather than still feeding.  try breaking her off gently and burping her then if she is still hungry give her more.  Supplementing, especially so early, is not a good path to go down as it will affect your milk supply and there is no guarantee it will make her sleep longer - it could just give her a poorly tummy as she's used to breastmilk meaning she might not sleep very much at all!  You're doing a great thing by breastfeeding, perservere and it gets so much easier.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kat Hayes
Member since: 30 March 2008
Total points: 241 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most babies (now this is only my personal knowledge) after 3 weeks so a vast difference in the amount they feed. They start taking more in each feed and becoming more adept at taking more in more quickly.
I breastfed my 10 pound 11 baby for 1 week, but soon realised that I was having to constantly feed him as I was not producing enough milk to sustain him so i switched to bottled formula. 
He is 6 weeks now and feed approx every 3 hours during the day and sleeps from 930pm to 630 am each night. 
Formula is harder to digest so your baby stays fuller for longer. 
I use S26 GOLD.
When you give your baby a bottle of formula instead of breastfeeding it is called supplementing- you do this when you stop producing enough milk or when you are trying to wean your baby off the breast.
I dont believe that there is medically any reason not to supplement or to completely wean your baby off breast milk if you are tired and not enjoying the feeding routine. 
Rory is one of the healthiest, happiest and most settled companionable babies and he has been bottle-fed as I said from 1 week old.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kelly
Member since: 14 August 2008
Total points: 273 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



giving formula at night makes some babies sleep longer, others it can upset their stomach and make them stay up all night. Personally I never saw a difference.

Is your baby actually eating for that whole hour? or is she latched on just using you for comfort? I recommend having a look at www.drjacknewman.com for the videos and articles about telling whether your baby is actually eating or just soothing herself. Do NOT give a pacifier though if you are breastfeeding as it can detract from the bf-ing. I hate the things anyway though.

A newborn feeding every two hours is (exhausting though it may be) completely normal. It will get better though as she takes in more and will sleep longer between feeds.

Keep it up and try not to give formula........some breastfed babies ESPECIALLY ones so young, if given a bottle will refuse the breast after. A bottle is much easier and faster than getting milk from the breast, so it can put the baby off. If you do use a bottle in the end, go for the Tommee Tippee ones as they are closest to the breast shape in their teats.

HTH!



Source(s):



www.drjacknewman.com



</answer>



<answer from>



Gracie's mommy
Member since: 24 April 2008
Total points: 393 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yep, totally normal for her age, in fact every 2 hours would've been a blessing for me. My 10 month old was eating every 1/2 hour to an hour until she reached a month old. Are you positive that she is eating the entire hour and not just comfort sucking? The easy way to tell with a newborn is to watch her jaw. If it's moving up and down, you know she's actively eating. If it's not, she is using you as a pacifier. Take her off, and even if she starts trying to eat again, wait and see what she does. If she's done, she won't cry for more. The norm at this age is every 2 hours, 20 minutes on each side.

If you supplement, your baby will probably sleep longer, but it will mess up your milk supply as it's trying to regulate itself to your baby's needs. If it misses a couple feedings because you gave your baby a bottle, it will think your baby needs less than it really does because you aren't exclusively feeding.

Sounds like you are doing awesome. I'd just watch your daughter to make sure she isn't comfort sucking and don't worry about giving her a pacifier. I freaked out about it because I thought it would give my daughter nipple confusion but my husband stuck one in her mouth at 2 weeks because we couldn't get her to stop crying and she was never confused. Soothie brand pacifiers are the best for breastfed babies. Also, if you need a good bottle that won't cause confusion, get the First Years Breastflow bottle, exclusively at babiesrus.com and their stores. My husband gave pumped breastmilk to my daugher at 3 weeks to help out and she never even knew the difference. No problem with a soft spout sippy cup later on either.

Hope this helps and hang in there. It DOES get easier.



Source(s):



personal experience



</answer>

Uh...... a little to young for a pet, as it means you'll have another totally dependent on you being to take care of. However, I'd recommend a cat. <answer from>



Alix
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 118 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Cats are brilliant pets because they can be your friend, but they clean, toilet train and exercise themselves. You've got enough to handle right now without cleaning up after a puppy, so I wouldn't go there. Birds are pretty but noisy and often don't keep kids interested for long. Plus, your little boy's too small to appreciate it much yet. I'd go for a cat personally. But toddlers and small children often torment kittens a lot, so if you were going to get a cat, either do it now so that by the time he can chase it around it's old enough to be able to get away, or get it once he's a few years old and can understand the concept of being gentle.
Hope this helps.



</answer>

<question>



Splitting, access and maintenance?



You may have read some of my previous questions.  It's looking like my husband and I are pretty much definitely going to split.  We're both miserable, disagree about everything and I don't want it to affect our one year old.  The first thing he talks of when I say I will leave if he doesn't stop shouting and being agressive in front of her is that he will call solicitors then, regarding access.  I have not a penny to my name, and am worried that because he has money he will get things his way and I won't get listened to.  How much access is he entitled to?  It's likely he will move 2-3 hours drive away and he is saying he wants her every weekend and 2-3 nights a week and that I will have to pay for a train to pick her up each morning (I don't drive) while he goes to work.  At the moment, he never really cares for her and they don't have much of a bond and I think going from nothing to that much access is a big leap for her to get used to.



He earns a salary of £30,000 per year which the CSA calculator says means he has to give between £60-70 a week towards his daughter, but he also gets £450 a month in lodge money which he doesn't actually use for that- he spends it on going out,  and is going to be getting £1000 per month plus in private earnings from next year, yet he says he cannot afford to pay that much maintenance.  The CSA won't know about the lodging money or private money, but he is saying he will say he cannot afford to pay that much when clearly he more than can afford to.  He says he will never ever talk to me again, even regarding our daughter.  How can we resolve this?  I don't know why he won't be civil but it seems our poor daughter is going to be stuck in the middle if I stay or go.



</question>



<answer from>



Terra T
Member since: 23 June 2006
Total points: 2852 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It looks like you are in Europe so I can't really share any of my knowledge of US law with you.  My suggestion is to call a family law attorney.



</answer>



<answer from>



flutterb...
Member since: 19 June 2008
Total points: 779 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well I am not sure exactly how things work in England but let me answer your question based on my personal experiences here in America. I'm sure things don't differ too much. First of all no court will take a child away from her mother unless there is ample proof of some sort of abuse or neglect. Second, seeing as how your daughter is very young, you should be able to present a good case that your ex should only have visitation on the weekends especially since he works during the week and won't be able to care for her then anyways. As far as child support, he should have to provide the court with proof of income and proof of expenses. This would include any subsidies that he receives, like his housing allotment. As long as he makes more money than you do he will have to pay child support. Also he won't be able to just say that he can't afford the court set amount. He would have to provide documentation that he can't afford it and from the sound of it that wont work. I would suggest contacting your local family court and finding out if they have any sort of legal aid for women looking to get out of a bad marriage or if they have legal aid for low income persons. This way you could have an attorney as well. Also it would look better if you were the one to file the divorce, access and support papers. Good Luck you and your daughter are in my thoughts.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



Yes, we do it nightly as part of his bedtime routine. He absolutely loves kicking his little legs and splashing the water. It is also the one thing that can calm him down if he's getting fussy. <answer>

My doctor also said that if they seem not to be settling down at all for whatever reason, if you give them a luke warm bath, with bed time soap for babies, it can settle them down and help you get them to sleep at night.
My doctor also told me just to wash their hands and feet every day, with a wipe at least.

<answer from>



Tiffany H

Total points: 185 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If he loves his bath, feel free to make it part of your daily routine. If he doesn't love it, it isn't necessary to bathe him daily. As long as you are changing his diaper regularly and cleaning his diaper area after poops (I don't recommend using prepared wipes that contain alcohol, soap, or perfumes), and spot cleaning after spit-ups, he shouldn't need to be bathed more often than every three or four days. Longer is okay for some babies -- if he starts to smell you will know it's time for a bath! If your baby's skin is drying out too much you will want to cut back on the frequency of baths and apply an alcohol-free, unscented baby lotion daily -- and especially after each bath.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sara C
Member since: 10 June 2008
Total points: 3734 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't. In the summer we bathe Em every other night and in the winter every third night. Mainly because she has eczema and the soap and lotion (even the most gentle kinds) tend to irritate her skin. I know at some point, once she is self feeding, it will need to be an everyday thing, but I'm hoping by then her skin will be less sensitive!



</answer>



<answer from>



C N
Member since: 24 February 2008
Total points: 17881 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I dont give  afull bath every day.  I dont bathe more than every 2 days.  usually every 3-4 days for a full bath.  I clean her bottom area thoroughly at every change, and do a quick butt bath after every poop :)

if you give a full bath every day you risk upsetting the natural skin oils balance and cause overproduction of those oils OR drying out the skin.  if you want to give him abath every day give a water only bath every other day and soap on the alternate days.

ETA using lotion also upsets the natural balance of oil production.



</answer>

Using a fan during sleep lowers SIDS risk by 72 percent
http://www.physorg.com/news142527893.htm...



I know how much I worried about my son {and still do} and that he would die in his sleep. I would look up everything I could on the subject and I just came across this article. It's from Oct. 6,2008. <question>



After having baby.. how exactly did your weight fall off?



After you had your baby how did your weight fall off after birth for the first month? When did your body start feeling like it does normally? What did you do to help get you through this tough time? Did you exercise, eat differently, anything special?



I am almost 2 weeks post partum. I gained weight leaving the hospital (water) and have dropped only 17 pounds since I came home. I thought I would loose more. I didnt know if you continue to loose after 2 weeks.. or if this is it and I better do more squats and sit ups.



Just disappointed I only lost 17 so far. I am breastfeeding and watching what I eat .. and have been very healthy. So whats your story?



</question>



<answer from>



kristal g
Member since: 18 April 2008
Total points: 285 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



they say give it up to 6 weeks...after that its up to exercise and dieting.



</answer>



<answer from>



jeff
Member since: 21 May 2007
Total points: 138 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Breastfeeding definitely helped me.  My son is 8 months old and still breastfeeding.  You burn 500 calories a day just by breastfeeding.  You should eat between 1800-2200 calories a day though.  But my weight loss scheme went like this:  I kept a food diary, I made sure I wrote down everything I consumed including drinks.  You want to look at the label, and write down how many grams of fat, and how many calories you are taking in.  This should make you aware of where you can cut out some extra grams of fat.  Drink a lot of water also.  It should all start falling off gradually, you don't want to psych yourself into thinking you're going to be instantly back into your pre-pregnancy jeans.  Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Ella
Member since: 20 December 2007
Total points: 10018 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Spend your time enjoying your baby, not worrying about your weight.



I am 16 weeks post partum and started dieting 3 weeks ago, ive lost 9pound so far,and another 14 to go...im not in a rush, i still look good for a mommy



</answer>



<answer from>



offended
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 598 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I *felt* back to normal at about 6-8 weeks, but I still weighed more than I did before I was pregnant. I gained 40 pounds in pregnancy. My baby is 6 months old now, and my weight has continued to slowly melt away. I'm just a couple pounds over my pre-pregnancy weight, and it's totally normal to have a few extra pounds while you are nursing your baby. Those milk boobs have some weight to them!



</answer>



<answer from>



Frosta Darlin (BCA)
Member since: 18 July 2007
Total points: 9558 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I wouldn't exercise until you are at least 6 weeks. Sometimes it takes up to a year or more or go back to pre pregnancy weight. Just remember that your metabolism slows down after having a baby so you will have to watch how much calories and fat you are actually consuming. Foods high in sodium will make your body bloat and retain water. 17 lbs in 2 weeks is a lot actually. Don't expect miracles to happen, your body took 9 months to put on the weight, expect it to take around 9 months to get back to normal.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Do you have advice for exclusively bottle feeding using breast milk?



Hello, we're having a baby in spring. I won't be nursing directly (please don't get into trying to convince me otherwise; I would if I could, I can't) And anyway, I'll need to go back to work sooner or later.



Of course I still want my baby to have breast milk, so I plan to pump and store milk so my husband / parents can feed the kid whenever I'm not around.



Do you have any special advice for this approach? Shall I just follow the usual breast pumping instructions + the usual bottle feeding instructions, or is there something different about feeding breast milk exclusively through bottles?



(I hear formula can be more concentrated, for example, so amounts might differ...)



</question>



<answer from>



Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 30289 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



Exclusive pumping is hard.  So I WOULD have to encourage you to take a long hard look at your sitation and see if there is ANY way to nurse your baby rather than pumping and bottlefeeding.



If that's not possible --
First, if it IS possible, try to nurse directly for at least the first couple of weeks.  Your baby is more efficient than the pump at stimulating your supply, so nursing will get you off to a good start.  After a few weeks, you can begin pumping at times when baby would normally nurse, and gradually make the switch over.



If you can't nurse at all, then you would pump often from day one.  Because the pump isn't as efficient, you'll probalby need to pump more often than you would nurse -- at LEAST every 2 hours around the clock.  As you get better with the pump and your letdown improves, you may be able to pump less often after your supply is well established.



Of course you will want the best pump you can afford -- renting a hospital grade pump would be ideal. Otherwise, buy a top quality double pump.



Good luck.  EPing takes a lot of dedication, and I have great admiration for women who commit to doing it.



</answer>



<answer from>



offended
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 600 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Establishing and maintaining milk supply when baby is not nursing



By Kelly Bonyata, BS, IBCLC



It is important to express your milk to establish and maintain milk supply if your baby is not nursing at all or not nursing well. By expressing, you will also have your milk available to feed baby - every bit of moms' milk that baby gets (even the tiniest amount) is like liquid gold.
When should mom start pumping?



* If baby does not nurse immediately postpartum, mom should begin pumping within 6 hours of baby's birth -- starting early makes a difference for future milk production.



What pump is best?



* If baby is not nursing, seriously consider renting a hospital-grade pump (such as those made by Ameda or Medela) that will allow you to pump both breasts at the same time. A hospital-grade pump is the best choice for maintaining or increasing milk supply.



* If you are not able to rent a hospital-grade pump, consider buying a pump (preferably a quality double pump) and/or hand expression.



How much milk should mom be pumping if baby is not nursing?



* Aim for pumping 750-800 mL (25-27 oz) per day by 7-10 days postpartum. If you have twins or higher order multiples, aim for pumping 800-950 mL (27-32 oz) by 14 days postpartum.



* It's useful to evaluate mom's 24 hour pumping output at 10 days. If supply is borderline (350-500 ml / 11-17 oz) or low (less than 350 ml / 11 oz), then galactagogues (prescription meds or herbs to increase supply) or other interventions should be considered.



* The research tells us that milk production at 2 weeks is an indicator of breastfeeding outcome, so it is important to get a good start. Even if milk production doesn't start out well, however, don't get discouraged--many moms will see an increase (even as late as 9-15 weeks after birth) if they continue with regular pumping.



How often should mom pump?



* 8-10 times per day: Until supply is well established, it is important to get at least eight good nursing and/or pumping sessions per 24 hours. Ten sessions per day is better, particularly if you have twins or higher order multiples.



* These sessions don't need to be evenly spaced, but you should be nursing/pumping at least once during the night in the first few months or anytime you notice a decrease in supply. Avoid going longer than 5-6 hours without pumping during the first few months.



* When pumping during the night, milk yield tends to be better if you pump when you naturally wake (to go to the bathroom or because your breasts are uncomfortably full) than if you set an alarm to wake for pumping.



* If you are having a hard time getting in enough pumping sessions, adding even a short pumping session (increasing frequency even if milk is not removed thoroughly) is helpful.



How long should mom pump at each pumping session?



* If baby does not nurse at all:



o The first few days, before mom's milk comes in, hand expression is often the most effective way to express colostrum. Double pump for 10-15 minutes per session for additional stimulation.



o Once mom's milk is in, pump for 30 minutes per session, or for 2-5 minutes after the last drops of milk.



* If baby nurses but does not soften the breast well



o Double pump for 10-15 minutes after nursing.



* Empty the breast as thoroughly as possible at each session. To ensure that the pump removes an optimum amount of milk from the breast, keep pumping for 2-5 minutes after the last drops of milk. Use breast massage prior to pumping, and massage and compressions during pumping to better empty the breasts and increase pumping output.



Additional tips



* Rest & relax as much as possible.



* Skin-to-skin (Kangaroo care) can make a significant difference in pumping output.



* If double pumping is difficult to coordinate in the beginning, then single pump, alternating sides. Move to double pumping as soon as you can.



* Avoid any medications that might interfere with milk supply (hormonal birth control, pseudoephedrine, ethanol/alcoholic beverages, bromocriptine, ergotamine, cabergoline)



* If supply is not increasing as expected by 7-10 days after birth, consider the use of galactagogues. Fenugreek, metoclopramide (Reglan) or domperidone (Motilium) can be helpful for increasing milk supply.



Source(s):



http://www.kellymom.com/bf/pumping/bf-li...



</answer>



<answer from>



barbie_1...
Member since: 04 February 2008
Total points: 1087 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, one thing I was surprised to hear that a lot of mothers didn't know is that breast milk can't be microwaved. microwaving zaps all the good nutrients out of the milk. Instead, microwave a bowl of water for about 2 minutes and set the bottle of breast milk in the warm water for a few minutes. good luck!



Source(s):



breastfeeding mother of a beautiful 2 month old boy



</answer>

<question>



Children close in age...nursing?



My son will be one tomorrow :).  He was born at 35 weeks and I had to have a csection (he was healthy and went home with me).  It took several days (maybe 6 or 7) for my milk to come in.  I assumed it was due to the csection and early birth.  He didn't gain weight at first and I think it was because my milk took a little while to come in.  Well anyway I quit nursing him at 4 months and I still have milk in my breasts if I try to express it.  I am 9 1/2 weeks pregnant and I'm curious if the milk will be there right away this time since it really has never went away.  I will be having another csection.  Will I still have colostrum and then milk or will my milk come right in (maybe with the added colostrum nutrients in it)?  Just curious what others experiences with this were????



</question>



<answer from>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I also had a section @35 weeks and it also took a full week for my milk  to come in after my second child  also a section  my milk came in by day two  . The milk that is currently there will most likely dry up if your are not nursing .Good luck and happy nursing

<asker's comment>



thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Ingrid
Member since: 27 February 2008
Total points: 416 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your body is smart and knows that a new baby will require new-baby colostrum not mature-baby milk. Even if you were still exclusively breastfeeding your first son, your breasts would go back to producing colostrum after your second child is born. And then your milk will come in again.



Our bodies are brilliantly designed that way.



</answer>



<answer from>



jackmatt
Member since: 17 December 2007
Total points: 11710 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes your body will still be able to produce colostrum & milk for the new baby. Just don't decide to let the one year old nurse anymore or you could go into preterm labor (I say this only b/c some women have actually done so)
OB/GYN RN & mom



</answer>

<question>



When to turn my son's car seat around?



my son is 6 months old and weighs nearly 18lb. i still have him rear facing in his seat atm, but it is becoming very hard to get him in and out this way, also he is straining his neck and trying to twist himself  to try and look towards the front. what is the recommended weight and age to put the car seat forward facing (i through out my car seat box) i would like to know when it is COMPLETELY safe to change it?



</question>



<additional details>



thanks for all your answers. VERY glad i asked now. i wont be turning my son's seat around any time soon, and will be sharing your info with my friend who has her 8 month old daughter (who weighs less than my son) forward facing. very helpful. thank you



</additional details>



<answer from>



Glenna
Member since: 20 April 2007
Total points: 26167 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You CANNOT turn it around prior to 12 months of age AND 20+ pounds (I mean, you can, but its incredibly unsafe).  However, its now recommended to leave them rear-facing even longer.  The longer the better actually.  Leave them rear-facing until they reach the weight limit for that car seat.  Some can stay rear-facing up to 30 pounds.  Just look on the seat.  It should have a sticker that states the weight limits.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Beth
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 969 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The very minimum is 1yr AND 20lbs...not either or.  But really it's recommended you get a convertible carseat with a higher weight limit, most are 30-35lbs, and keep them rear facing until that limit.  Height isn't a factor in that.  Their necks even at 1 aren't very strong and they can be internally decapitated pretty easily in a crash when forward facing, rear facing is MUCH MUCH safer for kids.  As long as you can keep them that way is best.  My youngest is currently 13mo and 20lbs and is still rear facing, he has a Britax Marathon an he's really comfortable in it, and it's really easy to get him in and out of, alot easier then the infant seat was plus he can sit up more and I can give him a toy and he can play, he doesn't mind sitting rear facing at all, and really even if he did he still would be, not risking his life.  Remember it only takes one time, you may not get a redo you know?



</answer>



<answer from>



mom 2B again
Member since: 20 December 2007
Total points: 2407 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is very important to keep your child rear facing as long as possible.  Here are some links that have information about rear facing and why it is so important for the safety of your baby.
http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/9916868



http://www.diaperpin.com/articles/articl...



http://journeytocrunchville.wordpress.co...



*edit*
"Children 1 year of age and at least 20 pounds can ride forward-facing. It is best to ride rear-facing as long as possible." Direct quote from the American Acedemy of Pediatric's  website.
Here is the link
http://www.aap.org/family/carseatguide.h...



</answer>

<question>



Wow, "crying it out" method works!!!!!?



My baby is almost 10 weeks old. When I put him down to take a nap, he would sleep for only 30 min. then cried. I had to pick him up and hold him for another hour or so. I decided two days ago, I am not going to pick him up. So when he started to cry, I went there, gave him his pacifier, touched him and left the room. After an hour of crying he finally fell asleep. Well, two days later, I put him down, he really did not cry. I had to go there three times within 30 min. to comfort him. I just had to give him his pacifier and he went right back to sleep. He has been sleeping for an hour and a half!!! So ladies, who would like to try this method, be consistent and do not give in. Believe me, it was horrible to listen to his cry. It is a great method that will keep your baby and you happy. Good luck to all of you who decided to try this method.

<original file>1661.html</original file>

<category>

<question from>



stary818
Member since: 30 November 2007
Total points: 393 (Level 2)

<question>

<answer>



you can pump a little (not all cuz your body will just make more) to help ease the pressure. or take a warm shower and try using your hands to help squeeze some milk out. other than that you'll  just have to wait it out. if you dont use your milk, your body will automatically dispose of it and since it works on supply and demand, if you dont demand any more, your body wont make any more. normally no more than a couple days.

<question from>



angel

</question from>



<question>



What I can feed my ten month old?



I was wondering what my baby can eat at ten months old? She has two teeth up front i just started trying to teach her to feed her self she is a little babied so she has me do everything for her at this point. I know that's bad but im so afraid of her choking on something. Im afraid to feed her anything but baby food. If i feed her table food how should I do it I would like to see her feed her self. Any comments would be appreciated



</question>



<answer from>



Cade can't hear the trolls!
Member since: 06 December 2007
Total points: 5669 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



She will do fine on table foods. Just give he chunck/bites of soft friuts, breads, steamed veggies, cheeses, meats. She can have almost everything except honey. She ownt choke, she may gag but statr out slo and let her pick it up.



</answer>



<answer from>



Alyssa's mommy
Member since: 19 May 2007
Total points: 20733 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Cook food till it is fork tender (steam, boil, bake, etc) then cut it into small pieces. Nothing bigger than a cheerio to start. Or even start with cheerios! Try easy soft things like bananas. Most babies can self feed tasty stuff really easy.



Babies, like us, use the back of the mouth to crush up their food. They just use their gums. The front teeth are for biting off pieces of food only. So having 0 teeth or 4 teeth makes little difference when eating soft table foods.



You can feed peas, cooked carrot pieces, broccoli, small chunks of cheese, noodles, breads, meats, all sorts of raw soft fruits and cooked hard fruits... you can even turn things like applesauce into a food a 10 month old can self feed. When Alyssa is feeling independant and doesn't want to be spoon fed I just mix her applesauce with a bit of baby oatmeal so it is thick enough to pick up. She gets a kick out of it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Heather B
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you are afraid of her choking give her something soft like a very ripe banana and cut it into pea size pieces. Another excellent choice are Gerber puffs the just melt in her mouth, other brands have the same thing too like Parent's Choice has them. As for feeding herself just put 2 or 3 pieces at a time of whatever you're feeding her on her highchair tray or a plastic plate and let her explore them. She might pick them up and mush them in her hand at first or something, but it's new to her and she is just trying to figure out what it is. Let her take her time. Also it would be a good idea to take a CPR class in case, God forbid, she does choke you know what to do.



</answer>



<answer from>



GagesMom...
Member since: 16 April 2008
Total points: 1150 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



My son has been on table food since 8 months old. I just feed him soft pieces of food. He likes those Gerber pasta pickups, I just cut them in half. A good rule to go by is have the pieces be no bigger than yuor thumbnail. Just offer a couple of things. My son likes peas, ground chicken, corn, cheerios, kix, mac and cheese and bananas. She will get the hang of grabbing and bringing to her mouth just fine.



</answer>



<answer from>
Member since: 08 June 2007
Total points: 671 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I understand her concerns. She may gag and seem like she's choking, she's reacting this way because she's not use to the texter of the new foods you'll be introducing to her. It'll get better once she gets use to it. It'll probable take a few tried until she gets use to it. I never did go through this with my baby. I just start giving her cherrios, toast, and smash bananas she loves it. She's 7mos.



You can start her off with:
Soft fruit-smashed bananas, pears, peaches, and ect
tofu
steamed veggies-buy the frozen veggies
cherrios
toast-bagels or plain muffins
yogurt
avocado
cottage cheese
beans
scrambled egg yolks
graduate puffs
unsalted crackers
pasta



Once she's mastered those, introduce her to small pieces of chicken and fish. Then she can start eating what you eat. Don't over season the food though.



Good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



j-LyNn♥
Member since: 09 May 2007
Total points: 15910 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was the same way about 2 months ago about my 9 months old feeding himself real foods. I even asked a question about it. He was chocking on Cheerios so of course I was even more worried about bigger things. BUT, you just have to let them do it. I did and it worked great. Put your baby in the highchair/walker (whichever you choose) and give a piece of food (like a piece of toast, slice of banana...etc...) and let her have at it. Just keep an eye out. She'll probably gag a few times before getting the hang of it but that's normal.



Now my son is 11 months and eats just about anything himself....I can't even feed him jar foods or table foods from a fork/spoon because he wants to do it himself.



Don't be afraid to give her table foods. Just mashed or cut-up well until she gets the hang of chewing. You can start off with a small slice of toast (bite-size pieces), a slice of banana, green beans...anything soft and something she can hold onto.



Good luck!



Source(s):



&lt;3 Mommy of 2 beautiful boys; Tyler 3.10 years & Riley 11 months (preemie) &lt;3



I've been there....it can be scary at first....but they become pros!!



</answer>

<question>



Reposting my question - what would you do?



I am a SAHM with a 19 months boy and an almost 3 months girl. I breastfed my son for 10 months and stopped after 3 months of my 2nd pregnancy - I couldn't make any milk at that point.
Now with my daughter I have so many problems.
I had to stop breastfeeding her at week 1 because my nipples were bleeding. I freaked out when I saw some blood coming out of her mouth. So, I decided to pump the milk and feed her with a bottle.
I tried to breastfeed her everyday but it was too painful. When I recovered completely, she ended up refusing the breast. I tried everything including medela SNS, finger feeding and so on. No way!
She nurses only when she's sleepy but it's not enough.
I don't want to try anything else to breastfeed exclusively. I tried for a week and it was a nightmare for me and especially for my baby.
So I pump night and day. The problem is that I don't have time to do anything else and I have 2 kids. I would like to spend more time playing with them.
Question: If I pump 7 times a day I can provide 90% of the milk my daughter needs. If I drop a couple of pumps my milk supply decreases considerably and I can provide only 60% - 50%.
Of course my baby is more gassy and fussy with more formula.
What would you do in my place?



Thank you for reading.



</question>



<answer from>



Jasmine
Member since: 02 May 2007
Total points: 1784 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would pump when convenient and supplement with formula for the rest (even if you can only get one bottle from pumping).  You can put a few drops of gas X in the formula to prevent the gas problem, I've heard this helps a lot.  Also, you could look at switching bottle types or formulas, all which can contribute to the problem.  Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



GagesMom...
Member since: 16 April 2008
Total points: 1150 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you are ok with the decision to stop breastfeeding and really don't want to pump you can try formula. I had to use soy formula for my son because milk based gave him bad gas and made him spit up allt he time. We had no issues with the soy.



Pumping 7 times a day seems like a lot. Kudos to you for doing that, I would have quit long ago. Maybe thats just me.



Also, have you tried a nipple shield to see if that will help her get used to the breast again?



</answer>

<question>



One twin being born a few days earlier?



is it possible for twins to be born weeks apart? if one is extremely premature and they are able to stop the birth of the second? or if one is born is it inevitable that both will be born?

<answer from>



Leesa
Member since: 18 July 2006
Total points: 3279 (Level 4)

<answer>



Yes it is possible.  I have twins and this was something that my doc mentioned to me during the pregnancy.  They can sometimes stop labor after one comes out and buy the other baby a few more days or even a couple weeks.  Thankfully I was able to go full term and not deal with any of that.

<answer from>



Lexi Lou
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 148 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is possible for twins to be born weeks apart.  During my sisters pregnancy with fraternal twins, her babies were in such a position the baby on "top" was adding excess pressure to the baby below.  At 28 weeks she started dilating and having contractions.  She was put on hospital bed rest but it was not enough to prolong the labor. She delivered baby number 1 at 29 weeks.  After vaginally delivering the first fetus her cervix starting closing, and we did not meet baby number 2 until she was 35 weeks along.



</answer>

<answer from>



Paris Rose
Member since: 12 September 2008
Total points: 965 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I doubt it, I carried twins and the one died in the uterus, I had to wait until I went into labour with the live twin before I could give birth to them both. My twins arrived 11 minutes apart.



In non identical twins there are two sacs, so theoretically it is possible but not likely, as you will be having contractions for the birth as well as the hormonal response. It would, I imagine, be very inadvisable, as it was in my case, because it could lead to serious problems for the twin left inside.



In identical twins they share the same sac and thus would have to be born during the same labour.



Hope that helps!



</answer>



<answer from>



9 mth old & another on the way
Member since: 30 August 2006
Total points: 5100 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



no this isn't possible once one twin is out they have about an hour  to get the nest out due to fluids and such  even if they are in separate sacks



</answer>

<question>

<answer from>



Landon's Mommy
Member since: 23 October 2008
Total points: 169 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Nik's mom
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 146 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Have you tried swadding him?  My little guy really liked to be held, too, and still is a super cuddly kid at 10 months.  One thing that helped us with sleeping, was to swaddle him before putting him to bed.  He was even happier during the day swaddled, laying on a blanket on the floor, watching me make dinner, or whatever.



To swaddle:
You take a large square cotton receiving blanket, lay it on a bed like a diamond, and fold the top corner down.  Lay baby's head on the folded corner, with his feet pointing toward the opposite (bottom) corner.  Then you bring the left corner over his body, and tuck it under his bum, and then the right corner over his body, and tuck that under his bum.  You can swaddle with his arms in, or out, depending on what works better for you.



Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



claire g
Member since: 28 December 2006
Total points: 5751 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



My eldest son (who is 8 now), was 9 weeks prem, and i had exactly the same problem.
To be honest, i found it was just a case of putting him in a kangaroo sling:



http://www.attachedtobaby.com/?gclid=CLa...



Hope that helps, because i found it great- i could carry him and also get on with doing things!



</answer>

Noah's Mommy & Marine Wife.

<answer>



Landon's Mommy, don't be so ignorant. A baby cannot be spoiled, especially at 3 months of age AND born premature, they don't know how to manipulate yet.

I found at that age my son really enjoyed his swing. I also took him around the house with me in his bouncer because as long as he could see me then he was content. But, at that age, your baby may just need some extra cuddling time and that's okay too.

<question>



Are there set times your baby should have a check up with Health Visitor or doctor? Every month or so? (in UK)?



I feel like I have lost contact with my Health Visitor and wated to know if there is a set time for a check up (eg. at six months)



</question>



<answer from>



Richmari...
Member since: 09 January 2008
Total points: 954 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



2 months, 4 months 6 months, 9 months, 1 year



</answer>



<answer from>



MajsticS...
Member since: 26 November 2007
Total points: 547 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



in the US we have what are called "well baby" visits. They need to have their immunizations/weight check & overall health check @ 1 week after birth, 2 mos, 4 mos, 6 mos, 9 mos and 12 mos. After that its just every year. I find it best to just schedule it around their b-day every year, makes it easy to remember.  Then around 2 years or 3 depending on how many teeth they have,  they should have their 1 st check up at the dentist. Hope that helps!



Source(s):



Mommy X 6 !



</answer>

<question>

Each of the next two weekends we are flying out of town with my 7 month old son to visit family.  One time will be with my husband and the next will be just me and my son.  3 of the 4 flights coincide with a time when I usually give my son solid food.  He has been eating solids for about 2 months now and eats two huge meals of them (today for lunch he ate a large serving of oatmeal, a 4 oz jar of pears, and about 2 oz of mango).  The process is really messy and he always tries to grab the spoon and feed himself which makes it even more messy.  My question is, during those flights can we skip the solids and just nurse him?  Will he miss them since he is eating so much?  Should I change the timing around of when I offer them or will this confuse him?  We will be trying to keep the same nap schedule and everything else while we are away.  What have you done when traveling with your 6-8 month old who is eating solids but not yet less messy finger foods like cheerios?



</question>



<answer from>



lo
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 1050 (Level 3)

<answer>



id switch the nursing and solid foods schedule.as long as hes getting them sometime during the day.. i think he'd be okay and not really know  the difference.  i would try to stick to a nap routine as  best as possible..sometimes though.. you just cant when traveling.

<answer from>



MajsticS...
Member since: 26 November 2007

<answer>



I agree with # 1. You may want to pick up one of the feeder bottles..they actually have bottles that you put jar food into and the baby can suck it like  a bottle. I don't usually like those but if he just has to eat and if you find nursing is not cutting it, then that would be a LESS messy option, than using the spoon. Or just go ahead and feed him the food and bring extra clothes on board! :P I would make sure you bring the food wtih you just in case. you'd hate to be stuck on a plane with a screaming baby that you can't console,  and the other passengers would not like it either, so bring some just in case.... <question>



Has anyone started potty training their kids as soon as they can sit up?



I am planning on starting to potty train my baby as soon as he can sit. He is only 3 months now, but I am thinking by 6 or 7 months I can start. What was your outcome? Are you glad you started so early?



</question>



<additional details>



Again, I said start to potty train, not expect my child to walk to the potty. The idea is that the earlier you start the easier it will be to learn as he grows

Member since: 02 November 2007

<answer from>



Noah's Mommy & Marine Wife.

If you start that young, it's not the baby who's being trained - it's you being trained to recognise the signs that they want to go. Babies that young simply don't have the bowel or bladder control.

<answer from>



MajsticS...
Member since: 26 November 2007
Total points: 551 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You sound like a 1st time parent.....Very excited..and want to do things right! Thats GREAT! BUT...its not possible...In order for a child to begin the potty training process, they have to be able to communicate a sign or word for Pee/poop, they have to have the bladder/muscle control, to be able to produce the BM into the toliet. And generally they have to be able to walk to the toliet themselves, and get on it themselves, which a child that young can't do. Around 1 year you can begin to put him on the potty say before bed, bath, or at regular intervals,  not so much to start training him, but to get him used to the toliet and not scared of it, and he may catch on to peeing on command, but usually BM take alot longer to get the hang of. And sorry to disappoint you but its proven, that BOYS usually are not fully potty trained until age 3. Sorry! :(
My daughters were fully potty trained at age 2, and my son at age 1 week before he turned 3. My 2 adopted kids JUST finally got it! and they are 3.5 and almost 4. Hope that helps!



Source(s):



Mommy X 6



</answer>



<answer from>



lillilou
Member since: 25 October 2006
Total points: 14737 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Actual toilets can be pretty dangerous with little ones falling into them head first.  And potties, are bascially germy and more work then I would ever want to deal with.  That said - I think starting late, is a much better, safer, and cleaner idea.



That and with my pampers points, were getting a lego set.



Source(s):



google toilet drownings



</answer>
