<question>



What do you consider a fully-stocked diaper bag?



I'm 36 weeks and getting everything ready for the hospital.
And someone told me to make sure i have a fully stocked diaper bag.
Now i can think of diapers, wipes, extra onesies and outfit, but as a first time mommy i'm coming up short...
Anything extra that you have found helpful to have in your newborns bag?
I'm going to be doing my best to breast feed, so i don't think i'll need bottles... or formula.
Any other suggestions?



</question>



<answer from>



Noah's Mommy & Marine Wife.
Member since: 08 October 2007
Total points: 45491 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



You won't need a diaper bag for the hospital stay. The hospital will provide you with everything the baby needs while they are there. You MAY want to bring an outfit to bring baby home in, a pacifer if you are planning on using them, and a blanket and snow suit if it will be cold.



Other than that you don't need anything. The hospital will provide diapers, wipes, and clothing while your baby stays there.



</answer>



<answer from>



ashlee
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 533 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



bum cream is a good one, most ppl use vasiline when first born, helps cleaning up those tar poops. maybe a pacifier, baby nail clippers, (nails are usually long when they come out) , a comb. other then that i think you good !



</answer>

<answer>



If you are going to do formula, I suggest getting a box of little formula packages. Each pack has 2 oz of formula so eventually you would use more than one, but they are great space savors in a bag in stead of a can.



Have burp rags also. If you use pacifiers, have a spare on incase you loose it. A small blanket.



What's with the thumbs down, I answered her question. No she doesn't need it for the hospital but that's not what she asked!

<answer from>



ashbaby4...
Member since: 16 August 2006
Total points: 2811 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would say:
diapers, wipes, extra onesies, socks, travel sized baby lotion, burp cloths, the baby brush/comb, any special "going home outfits", if its cold then a hat or two if you want to use something besides the hospital hat, formula AND bottles just in case you change your mind (I breast fed so don't think I am pushing bottles on you).



Don't forget to pack your mommy bag too!



Once your baby is older you will giggle at how much stuff you used to carry around just in case you needed it.  I only carry diapers, wipes, snacks and a sippy cup and that's IT!



Best wishes with your little one and enjoy every moment!



OH I almost forgot blankets and a paci if using one...maybe pack one just in case.



Source(s):



ME momma to a handsome 21 month old son!



</answer>



<answer from>



mistydee...
Member since: 04 May 2008
Total points: 1196 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Make sure you have a spare hat - the baby's generally still a bit covered in goo when they're first dressed, and while we had loads of extra clothes, we didn't think about a spare hat!



Don't mean to burst your bubble or get you worried, but I spent 4 days in hospital trying to breastfeed without success, so in the end had to give her formula. You might want to just look into it now, maybe pick out a brand and have a couple of bottles sterilised just in case. I literally had to stop a the supermarket on the way home from hospital to get bottles and a steriliser!



Oh, and a load of terry cloths to put over your shoulder when you're burping him/her.



(Also, make sure you've got something to eat for after the baby's born. I was starving, and all we could find at short notice was a couple of chocolate sponge rolls - which just made me nauseous)



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 12 January 2007

<question from>

<question>



My 3 month old is comfortable sleeping on his stomach, he has already rolled, can he sleep safely this way?



</question>



<answer from>



rmjrusse...
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 533 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Rolled from stomach to back or back to stomach. My baby can roll from stomach to back, but I still put her to sleep on her back. They are at the greastest risk for SIDS between 2-4 months old.



</answer>



<answer from>



lo
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 1053 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



as long as they have head control... can lift it if its stuck in the mattress... they're okay. once they start to roll.. they sleep however they like and i stopped worrying.



</answer>



<answer from>



sockthin...
Member since: 27 April 2008
Total points: 3414 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



My daughter slept on her front from 3 weeks old.That was how she was comfortable. She would never sleep for longer than 15 minutes on her back.



Source(s):



Also consider that at the moment, babies are supposed to sleep on their backs, 20 years ago parents were advised to put babies on their stomachs, and 40 years ago, they were meant to be on their sides...can't people mak up their minds?



</answer>



<answer from>



hour_of_...
Member since: 17 October 2006
Total points: 108 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



my 4 month old is the same way. she will ONLY sleep on her stomache(even though dr said not to all the time) or in the car seat when she is REALLY beat. and she rolls too. fun when she rolls from stomache to back and whines cause she wants to be on her stomache. then u have to flip her every 15 mins. but, now she will flip and just cry herself to sleep on her side/back. if the kid sleeps, comfy enough



Source(s):



parenthood



</answer>

<answer from>



aabc44
Member since: 15 January 2008
Total points: 2543 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



you may have a "snacker" on your hands. I didn't know anything about that until I had my second. these babies are just taking their time to nurse/bottle, looking around, getting distracted, nursing 1-5 minutes, and come back for more in an hour. It was really difficult to time her feeding sessions: the dr. said to feed her every two hours when newborn. but she would nurse for 1-2 minutes now, 3 minutes 15 minutes later, 2 minutes another 30 min later, and so on for three months while I was on maternity leave, day and night.
After i started work, she did the same with the bottle.
And she had a poor latch too, either my breast were too engorged, or she would only suck on tip, that would make her frustrated. in time (3 months) she nursed better from the breast, but only prefers the short bottle nipples (like NUK, not Avent-which i had a full set from my first)



My oldest one in turn, was a very effective nurser, in 15 min she would empty the breast, burp and go to sleep.



be patient, this is the least of your worries...



</answer>

<question from>



James Lee's mommy2be
Member since: 21 February 2008
Total points: 757 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



More bottles questions?



Can I get some feed back on the Avent Tempo Disposible Nursers?



What's the difference in newborn, slow, medium, and fast flows? How many of each would you recommend?



How well does this system work for those who pumped milk?



</question>



<answer from>



momoftwo
Member since: 11 April 2006
Total points: 18233 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Toddler & Preschooler



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I really wouldn't go past medium flow because with medium and fast flow both of my children would slobber it out as they drank or end up gagging on it as it came out too fast.



Newborn is great because they have to work at it a little more, which sort of makes weening from the bottle easier.  When they are a year old they would rather suck on a sippy cup than a bottle with a newborn nipple that is hard to extract fluid from.



The fast flow would be pretty good if you plan to add rice to the bottle, but I woudn't recommend adding rice.  It's a personal choice though



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks. I appreciate the weaning advice too! Lol.



</asker's comment>

<question>



Question about resealable Gerber food packs?



I bought the plastic little boxes/packs of Gerber 2nds vegetable purees. We microwaved the 1 pack. Our little one didn't eat the whole pack. We placed the pack in the fridge, but then I remembered reading that you shouldn't eat food that you already microwaved once. Is this true?



</question>



<answer from>



daddysli...
Member since: 04 September 2007
Total points: 584 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Thats what I thought too.. I would suggest getting a microwave safe bowl, and pour what you need in there and microwave it.. and save the rest in the fridge. If I remember correctly you can only save those for like 2-3 days in the fridge.



</answer>



<answer from>



Parkers Mom!
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 4587 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its ok as long as they eat it same day not the next day or two. So just try to give it to the baby in a few hours.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ree
Member since: 12 June 2007
Total points: 1161 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



We always do.  However I always put some of the pack on my daughter plate, then add as I need to this way the pack itself doesn't become contaminated.  But I do save whats left and re heat it either later that day or the next.



</answer>



<answer from>



Beth
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 987 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I THINK, not positive, if you warm it from fresh or the first time you cook it at all is that way it's ok, but not if she ate out of the pack. like if you were feeding her straight from that jar putting the spoon she ate off back in there you aren't supposed to save that.  But I would think if you just tooksome out and fed her from another bowl and not from the pack it would be ok



</answer>



<answer from>



Luna27
Member since: 09 February 2007
Total points: 6116 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



You aren't supposed to reheat the same package or let them eat from the same package after it has sat.  (reason for the second is that their saliva has gotten into the food and will start to break it down).  What I will do is put the amount of food that I want to feed him into a separate bowl and heat it up that way and then save the rest in the fridge for later.



</answer>



<answer from>



Noah's Mommy & Marine Wife.
Member since: 08 October 2007
Total points: 45594 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



If she already ate out of it you risk the chance of bacteria by putting it back into the fridge and storing it for later.



Next time just put a small amount into ANOTHER bowl for this purpose so you don't have to waste anything.



</answer>



<answer from>



baby girl
Member since: 31 October 2006
Total points: 1610 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



One reason why you shouldn't microwave (or use) the Gerber plastic packs PERIOD is becasue they are packed in the #7 plastic with BPA in them.  I am not some crazy Mom who rambles on about stuff, just wanted to let you know.  Check the bottom of the container, you will see a 7.



Source(s):



Gerber insists they are safe, but why take the risk? Buy food in glass.



</answer>



<answer from>



Grizwald
Member since: 24 April 2007
Total points: 817 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Re-microwaving isn't the issue.  The potential harm is that the food became contaminated with germs if you fed your baby straight from the resealable container, and if given enough time the germs will spread through the leftovers and your baby could get sick from it.



I admit, I fed my son straight from the container AND re-nuked the packages to re-feed later that day or the next day.  The world is full of germs, and if you try to isolate your child from them all, you're going to be very busy.  As long as you don't let the containers sit at room temperature between feedings, your little one should be fine.  My son's a healthy, happy 2 year old, and hasn't suffered a bit from how he was fed as an infant.  Trust your parenting instincts!  Go with what your gut tells you.  :)



</answer>

<answer from>



mushmarl...
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 4377 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It will take a lot of work and will not be easy to reverse this.  Start trying to lay him in the crib for daytime naps.  Eventually he will get so tired that he will fall asleep in their.  If he cries then pick him up, comfort him and then put him back in the crib.  Every time he falls asleep put him in the crib.  Just keep it up.  Eventually he will sleep in there but it may be hard to transition and it will be very tiring.  Or you can get a bassinet and put it beside your bed so that he is on his own but still close enough to hear your breathing.



</answer>



<answer from>



MM
Member since: 04 July 2008
Total points: 3020 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Co-sleeping is a very bad thing to start because its a nightmare to stop. As your baby is only 2 months old its best to put an end to it now becasue the older they get the harder it is. The only way to stop it is to bare the crying for 1 or 2 nights let them work out that the crib is there bed.  If you think at 2 months he is having a tantrum wait until he is 1 and you want to break the habit he will turn blue from screaming. Nothing will happen to him while he is crying even though its distressing it will end; put him in his crib awake and when he cries go to him every couple of minutes to comfort him but don't pick him up and rock him just touch him so he know he's safe and leave him alone. It hard but best to stop the habit younger than older; my sister in law is still co-sleeping with her 3 year old and she is pregnant with her 2nd and just can't break the habit she is at her wits end and wishes she had never started co-sleeping.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sonya C
Member since: 23 October 2008
Total points: 157 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had the same issue with my 6 month old.  I took 3 days and dedicated myself to fixing this problem.....My motto was :sleep in your crib, or dont sleep at all".  Needless to say I had a cranky baby for the first two days but thats all it took. It'svery important to stick with a routine, like supper, activity, bath and bed, and stick to it.....A baby only has to do something 3 times before it becomes a habit! When you put him down, and he cries, hold him again until he falls back to sleep.  If he cries on the way down to the crib, make sure you lay him in there for a second before you pick him up to soothe him.  It lets him know that even though he cries you are still gonna put him in his crib.The first night I tried this with my little girl, she woke constanly, and I was doing this for 3 hours straight.the next night she woke every 3 hours, and the nest night after that she slept the wholenight.  You should break this habit now, while it'snot so hard.



</answer>

MoM oF tWo

<answer from>



milkmaki...
Member since: 03 June 2008
Total points: 743 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Is it really hurting anything to let him sleep with you???  Our son has slept with us from day one and I have discovered there is nothing better in the world than baby snuggles and waking up with my whole world/family in my bed!  Our sex life has not suffered in the least.  If anything it is MORE exiting!  It is like being a teenager again, doing it in forbidden and naughty places!  I breast feed, so having my baby in the bed is the easiest thing in the world.  He squirms to let me know he is hungry, I roll over, latch him on, and go back to sleep!  That way, not one in our house is sleep deprived!  The way my hubby and I look at it, it is better to let my son sleep in the bed now so he knows we are always there for him  and to help him find his own independence when he is ready than to force him to be independent and end up with a clingy, needy child!  There is a great book with an author named Jay Gordon called "Good Nights".  It explains all of this and why it is SO important in much greater detail than I can here.  Look for it at your local library or buy it at a book store or on-line!  Good luck with your precious baby!



</answer>

It's eye boogers, something could've gotten in her eyes, she could have an infection like red eye, or dust could be stirred up from vacuuming or her tear ducts are fully developed now and are flushing her eyes properly, it could be anything, if it is a lot of goo, then take her to the doctors.

But this is a very common problem for baby's.

Ren J

<answer>



Sounds like pink eye. The doctor can prescribe some antibiotic eye drops. Another possibility is a blocked tear duct. My daughter had a blocked tear duct off and on until she was a year and had to get surgery on it. Most children do not have to get surgery on it..it goes away. Still though, if it's infected either way she needs the eye drops.

<answer from>



ohmygosh
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It could be pinkeye.  It could just be conjunctivitis brought on by a cold.  If it her eyes become red or when she wakes up they are crusted shut from all the goop, see your doctor.  If they are just a little boogery, it will probably work itself out on it's own.  Randomly, if you are nursting and she is an infant, squirt a little breastmilk into her eyes if it's a very mild irritation.  Thats what my pediatrician recommended to me when my son's eyes got goopy.  People think it sounds nuts, but it's a fantastic natural remedy for mild eye irritation.  It will actually work for people of any age, but docs only recommend it for infants who are already breast feeding.



</answer>

<answer>



We have a bunch of more neutral clothing, but we usually always pair them with some gender specific clothes, just because that's how everything lays out.  I think it's much easier to dress little girls in boy colors than it is to dress little boys in girl colors.  A little girl can look absolutely adorable in a light blue outfit, a dark blue outfit, and even a blue and grey "running" suit, but you can't do that the other way with a boy.



For us I find that most of our little boy's pants are kind of gender neutral, but his shirts are usually pretty boyish, except for the plain, solid colored, long sleeved shirts we just bought.  When he was littler, though, we did have a pair of jeans for him that were technically girl jeans.  They had a flap over the front hip pocket and had little green dinosaur foot prints on the leg.  I thought they were boy pants when I bought them, but looking at their fit and the details made it pretty clear they were girl pants.  Oh well!



I do have a type of floral print on my sling, though, so anytime that I have him in my sling, even if he is dressed to the 9s as a boy, people still think he's a girl because all they see is the black fabric with flowers on it.  But, come on, the sling is an accessory for me, not for him.  :)



Edit:  Superman's mom, that sleeper (and your son) are adorable.  I can see why you would want to use it.

<answer>



You kicked him out twice, so he went and stayed away.  How does that equate to him pushing you away?



Now you are going to punish him by not giving the baby his name.



You sound like a fruit loop.  You are already using that child to get back at its father, and the child isn't even born yet!  You sound like prime time for Dr. Phil.



If you print off this question and these answers and hand them to your child in 18 years, is he or she going to be proud of you?



The father is better off if he stays away from you.



HOWEVER, your baby is not better off.  Your baby needs his/her father.



Give the father encouragement by giving the baby his name.  Wouldn't the baby want that, too?



Encourage the father to come see his baby as often as he wants:  in the hospital, out of the hospital, on Mars if he wants to.  Let the child get to know his/her relatives on that side of the family.



But leave that poor guy alone.  You're done playing him.



I'd take you to court if I were him.  I'd take you to court to gain full custody of that child from its manipulative mother.



Don't mess up your child by messing with its father.  Sheesh!

Good luck and for the sake of having a normal child, do not allow your ruined relationship with him to cause harm to a relationship with his soon to be baby.

Oh BTW, I don't think he's calling and acting like he cares just because your staying with your parents I think he might have finally woke up and realized the time is almost here and he needs to step up to the plate as a man. Again Good Luck!!!



</answer>

<question>



My 5month old baby came home with a foul smell...what would you do?



Let me give you a little background as to what happened.....My son goes to a home day care where he is the only baby and the only other child at the day care is like 2yrs old. I chose this daycare when I was returning to work after my maternity leave.



On this particular morning, I rang the doorbell and no one answered right away. When the door was opened for me, my son's caregiver's grandson (who by the way 30yrs old) had no shirt on, with a doo-rag on his head let me in. Well, Ms. R (thats what we'll call her) came from the back of the house, still in her nightgown and the other little boy with her. They both looked like they both just woke up. I was a little disturbed that she wasn't up and ready to receive my son that morning. I shouldn't have had to wake her. I was running late and decided not to question it right then and there.



Well, when I picked my baby up after work. She was still in her night gown. When I got home, took off his pram suit I smelled a very foul odor on my baby. Not to be disgusting but he strongly smelled musty and un-washed private parts (of a woman that is). I had to take my son's clothes off immediately, give him a bath, lotion him up and put on his jammies. My husband was outraged.



I spoke to her this morning about it and she claimed it didn't come from her but from her grandson who she says does not wash up. By the way, if you're wondering, HE DOES NOT EVEN LIVE THERE.



Mrs. R is an older lady of about her 60's or early 70's. I didn't want to offend her bcuz of her age but I had no other choice to speak on it. I don't believe it was her grandson bcuz I asked did her grandson handle my baby. She said no but then why would my baby smell like that if he is stinky?



What would you have done? SERIOUS ANSWERS ONLY!!



</question>

<answer from>



Emily E
Member since: 22 August 2007
Total points: 6448 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I breastfeed and they took bottles when I was at work.  I always used drop in Playtex nursers.  When you express milk and store it in milk bags, you can put those bags right into the Playtex bottles and not have to worry about spilling.  And they are BPA which you should be careful of, but not crazy careful.  Some nursed babies will not take a bottle or are very picky about what bottle they will take. My first child would take breast or bottle, didn't care.  My second would take a bottle, but only if it was extra warm like nursing, and my third all but refused a bottle.  I could be gone 8 hours and he would take 4 oz!  At that was at 4 months!! So you are going to have to see what your baby does.  As for pacifiers, my oldest would use any but prefered a Nuk, my last two hated them.



And if you plan to nurse, you really only need a couple 8oz bottles, you don't have to fill them!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Megyvett...
Member since: 24 October 2008
Total points: 177 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



My daughter is breastfed and the only bottles she will use is playtex nursers because they are similar to the breast.



</answer>



<answer from>



Wolfchil...
Member since: 19 April 2007
Total points: 632 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't know anything about bottles, lol, but I wanted to give you some advice about pumping.



You have to be careful with pumping that it doesn't reduce your supply, cause that can prematurely end breastfeeding. So, try pumping on one side and feeding your baby on the other at the same time. Pumps aren't as efficient as a baby so if you only pump at a time when you'd be feeding, without the baby feeding from that side afterwards, your body will start to make less milk.



</answer>

<original file>5350.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk80546.txt</current file name>




<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Newborn & Baby



</category>



<question from>



Mary H
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 91 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the best feeding/sleeping routine for a five and a half month old baby?



I know that each baby is unique and should guide you. But I need a basis for a routine and am finding it difficult to get hold of one.



</question>



<answer from>



Sophie's Mommy
Member since: 31 January 2008
Total points: 2929 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I can only tell you what works for us:



5:30 to 5.45ish - rice cereal and a bottle
She usually takes a quick cap nap by 6.15ish
Bath time by 7.20
Story, playtime, or conversation time after bath
6 oz bottle by 8-8.15
She is asleep by no latter than 9.15 most nights.
We are really flexible on the times and dont push her too much. if she seems fussy and tired or hungry earlier than 8 we give her what she needs and let her get to sleep earlier.



EDIT: she is 4 months old.



</answer>



<answer from>



Humpty
Member since: 26 August 2008
Total points: 314 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i found that trying to use someone else routine just made me feel inadequate, cos my wee topsy did not fit the routine! tried Gina Ford, and was at suicide point after 2 weeks.



just do what feels natural, and if not look on the web, cos there is loads of baby books, penelope leach is a genius, and very supportive.
don't get stressed, do what you need to, not what someone tells you to



good luck mrs humpty



</answer>



<answer from>



Morgan S
Member since: 08 February 2008
Total points: 179 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



you should try to work it around your routine there are books to help you with this. the best ive tried is when he/she wakes up in the morning feed him/her then its playtime then nap time and repeat. with the amont of naps she takes a day;



</answer>

<answer>



My 7 month old likes the sound of his voice and frequently makes noises just because he can.  Like, he was screaming in the middle of the grocery store the other day.  And it didn't sound like happy screams, but I knew he was fine.  I bet everyone else there thought it was weird though.  If your daughter is tired though (and it isn't bedtime yet) try reworking her nap schedule so she gets up from her last one a little later and closer to bedtime.  Or maybe you should think about putting her to bed earlier.  She may just be moaning because she is tired.  Also she may get bored easily if it stops temporarily when you move her.  If you play with her and give her lots of attention, does she stop moaning altogether?



</answer>



<answer from>



ivy9toes
Member since: 30 October 2006
Total points: 9935 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



She could just be fighting sleep. If this is a new behavior, then I would consider foods you are feeding her prior to bedtime, maybe her tummy is too full?



Mine did that and it turned out that she just got tired of being held and didn't want to miss out on anything. It was frustrating for her that she was sleepy.



Best of luck, mom. If it progresses, I would talk to your doc.

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



wow. Tough one. You know, maybe he's full for the day. (?) Their eating habits change as they grow so its not always going to be the same routine. It seems like just as soon as you get a good routine going, they go and change it all around....maybe he just had enough milky mommy! I'd put him to bed and be prepared for a night waking. Hopefully things will be back to normal tomorrow. Babies are different every day just like adults. For example -- tonight I just ate half a tub of icecream and tomorrow I will probably starve myself to compensate. ;)

i'm a mom

<answer from>



ihavease...
Member since: 24 August 2008
Total points: 1402 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ahh memories.



Either ask your older daughter to help - that way you get to have time with both of them but to be honest, does it matter that your youngest is dressed?  As for the nappy, use pull ups.  They work just as well as nappies and is easier to put them on and take them of.



I had this problem with both of mine and I made it a game for both of them.  Get her attention by saying, with a pair of tights / trousers in your hand, "Can I have your arm please so I can put your tights / trousers on".  Put them on and see their faces when they know you've got it wrong.  Your oldest will say that they belong on her legs and say something like "noooo they don't look they fit".  Carry on the banter and then say "do they belong on your legs?  Show me".  Ta da they're dressed.



I still do this when they don't want to get dressed - only this time I (try to) put them on me and this gets them into giggles and they take the clothing of me and put it on them themselves.



Your youngest is just trying to be like her sister so let her do her thing.  My oldest learnt to dress herself when she was 14 months and her sister learnt by the time she was 12 months, the oldest was 13 months when she was climbing comfortably the stairs on her own with no assistant and her sister was 11 months so let her do her thing and you will soon find that you're not doing things for the youngest for as long as you were for your oldest.



Good luck.



Source(s):



My 3 and 4 year olds.



</answer>

<question>

<answer from>



tired n hungry
Member since: 02 September 2008
Total points: 191 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



8 months is still early to hold his own bottle but I would give him a cup because you don't want him getting used to the bottle its bad for the teeth and it's harder to wean him off it.



</answer>



<answer from>



babyblue...
Member since: 21 September 2006
Total points: 293 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



My son was about 8-9 months when he started holding his bottle. We started introducing the cup at about 9 months per what the doctor told us. The WIC people told us to give the cup at 6 months, but my sons doctor disagreed. Now the WIC dieticians are saying he shouldn't have a sippy cup, but a real cup. He turned 1 on Sunday and I know with my daughter (she is 4 1/2) her doctor told us sippy cups were fine until her 4 year check up (and she has had 3 doctors since birth and they all said about the same thing). Does your son have a pediatrician he sees regularly? I would see what they say and trust them over the WIC people, just tell them what they want to hear. That's what I do LOL.



Source(s):



personal experience



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 30 October 2008

I got one when my son was a few months old and I was breastfeeding.  My appointment was at night (6pm-11pm).  I just gave my baby pumped breastmilk until the morning, just to be safe.  He turned out just fine :)



</answer>

<answer>



We spend around $200 every two weeks on groceries(I'm including Noah's diapers and formula in this and our pets' food). So $400/month on that.



For gas we spend about $160-$180/month. I rarely drive since I stay at home and my husband drives one week out of the month since he carpools with three other guys.



On bills(car payments, phones, TV, credit cards) we spend around $800/month.



We don't pay for water or electricity and we also do not really pay any rent because we live in base housing. His BAH(basic allowance for housing) gets taken directly out of his checks so we never see it.

Sunsolei 4 Obama

<question>



My 9 month old is vomiting and has diarrhea?



Is it normal and okay for older babies to get the stomach flu? Because I could have sworn that he has been vaccinated for rotavirus by now. Is it possible that he has rotavirus??



Here's what happened:



I was holding him and he shat, and it went out the sides of the diaper and got all over me. I changed him, left him bare bummed for a second on the floor and he went again. I changed him and he went again.



I was holding him and trying to put him down, I breastfed him and then he sat up and vomited all over the bed. It was "projectile" vomiting, I picked him up and he vomited again, all over me.



I sat with him in the rocking chair and he went to sleep. He is sleeping now and seems okay. But I am really worried about him becoming dehydrated. Should I wake him up and feed him and see if he vomits again? Should I let him sleep?



Do you think I should call the doctor NOW, or wait until morning?



He MAY have been exposed to this "bug" at the doctor's office on Monday. This is what I suspect.



</question>



<answer from>



tamarg03
Member since: 01 November 2007
Total points: 177 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



well he could have acid reflux so i would contact his dr first thing in the morn



</answer>



<answer from>



Mary O
Member since: 19 February 2007
Total points: 828 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



A young child can dehydrate very quickly.  Your baby has both diarrhea AND vomiting so a lot of fluid is being lost.  I would call the doctor now.  This has absolutely nothing to do with acid reflux as another person answered.  Be on the safe side and call the doctor.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kristin
Member since: 14 June 2006
Total points: 12631 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Call and make an appointment with your doctor in the am.  The doc will see him the same day but it doesnt sound like its a "rush to er" kinda thing.  even if he has been vacinated against the Rotavirus, he will still get sick and still get the flu.  Continue to try to breastfeed or offer him water or pedialite in a cup to keep him hydrated.  i know you are worried but this can wait till the morning.



</answer>

<answer from>



Jacob's Beloved
Member since: 23 October 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Absolutely not! You have to remember the massive changes that are going on inside your baby's body every single day. It's not comfortable! The only way a baby can communicate with you at this age is to cry. So guess what?
She's tired, she cries.
She's hungry, she cries.
She's wet, she cries.
She's cold, she cries.
She's gassy, she cries.
She's hot, she cries.
She's overstimulated, she cries.
She's bored, she cries.
She's constipated, she cries.
She can't reach something, she cries.
She's scared, she cries.
She has a hangnail, she cries.
She doesn't recognize someone, she cries.
She doesn't like the way something smells, she cries.



Understand? Don't fret it. Just say to your mother "Thankyou for your concern, but I can handle this." And know that you can.



</answer>



<answer from>



The Sh*t
Member since: 16 July 2007
Total points: 16440 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



The Mexican red eye myth is called a myth for a reason.  It's not true, it's not true whether it comes from Mexican heritage or German heritage (yes we Germans have similar myths like that).  Likely the baby is just teething or she might not be feeling real well, could be coming down with a cold or ear infection, or she could be just going through a fussy stage most babies have periods of time where they are more cranky than usual.



</answer>

Pretty high. Can be a viral infection specially that now she started with runny nose. But if she continue with the temperature is better for her to be checked by the pediatrician because now that you are pregnant you don't want that to be more complicated later when you have the baby. Better now. If that tends to be a bacterial infection instead then she will need antibiotics, but as per you said she just started with runny nose and that is possibly viral. BUT bacterial infections can be complications of viral infections.



</answer>

<answer from>



mystic_e...
Member since: 21 October 2006
Total points: 92195 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



http://www.drgreene.org/body.cfm?id=21&a...
I was surprised to learn in medical school that fever, far from being an enemy, is an important part of the body's defense against infection. While a fever in a child signals to us that a battle might be going on in a child's body, the fever is fighting for the child, not against.



Most bacteria and viruses that cause infections in humans thrive best at 98.6 degrees F (37C). Raising the temperature a few degrees can give the body the winning edge. In addition, a fever activates the body's immune system, accelerating the production of white blood cells, antibodies, and many other infection-fighting agents.



[...]



A fever does not necessarily need to be treated. If a child is playful and comfortable, drinking plenty of fluids, and able to sleep, fever treatment is not likely to be helpful. Steps should be taken to lower a fever if the child is uncomfortable, vomiting, dehydrated, or having difficulty sleeping. The goal is to bring the temperature between about 100 and 102 degrees F -- not to eliminate the fever.



[...]



Fever is a signal that something is going on in your child. Usually this is a minor illness, but it can be a serious infection, such as meningitis. Any child less than 90 days old with a fever &gt;100.4 degrees F should be examined by a physician right away, to rule out a serious infection (unless there was a DPT shot in the previous 24 hours). Children of any age who have a fever &gt;105 degrees F should also be seen, unless the fever comes down readily with treatment and the child is comfortable. Any child who has a fever and is very irritable, confused, has difficulty breathing, has a stiff neck, won't move an arm or leg, or who has a seizure should also be seen right away.



Even without such symptoms, children under 6 months of age with a fever should be examined by a physician within 24 hours (again unless they just had a DPT), since they may have some infection that needs to be treated. Older children with a fever (6 to 24 months old) who are acting well and have no other symptoms should be seen if the fever lasts 48 hours (or 72 hours if they do have minor cold or flu symptoms).



http://askdrsears.com/html/8/t082100.asp
WHEN TO PAGE YOUR DOCTOR



* Remember, fevers are your body's natural response to infection, and not necessarily a sign that something serious is taking place.



* Low-grade fevers are generally not serious, are easily treated, and can wait until the morning to be evaluated by your doctor.



* Fevers of 101 to 103 (38.4 to 39.5 Celcius) are also generally not serious and can wait until morning to be evaluated, except as indicated below.



* High fevers of 104 (40 Celcius) or higher that quickly come down to 100 or 101 (37.8 to 38.3 Celcius) with the treatment measures below are also generally not serious and can wait until morning, except as indicated below.



So for now, don’t rush to page your doctor. Read through this section, and call your doctor during office hours, or page your doctor according to the following guidelines:



Here are the situations that usually warrant an urgent call to your doctor. If none of these fit your current situation, then you probably don’t need to page your doctor. Follow our treatment advice below and call your doctor during office hours.



* If your infant is 6 weeks or younger, and has a fever of 101 or higher, this is considered a medical emergency. Your doctor should evaluate your infant right away, either during business hours, or in an emergency room after hours. Do not give any fever-reducing medications in this situation (you don't want to hide the fever until after a doctor has evaluated your baby). Be sure to confirm any fevers with a rectal thermometer (if available) before contacting your doctor.



* Infants age 7 weeks to three months with a fever over 101 warrant an appointment with your doctor within the next several hours. You generally don’t need to page your doctor in the middle of the night in this situation if the office opens within the next few hours. Simply follow our recommendations on treating fever below and call your doctor in the morning. If it is the early evening you should probably page your doctor, since the office won’t be open until the following day. Be sure to confirm any fevers with a rectal thermometer (if available) before contacting your doctor.



* If your child of any age has one or more of the following symptoms, you should probably call your doctor right away:



o High fevers of 104 (40 Celcius) or higher that don't come down to 101 or 102 (38.3 to 38.9 Celcius) with the treatment measures below.



o Lethargy – this means more than your child just isn't acting right or laying quietly in your arms. Lethargy actually refers to your child being limp, lifeless, unresponsive, or won't make eye contact.



o Irritability - this means more than just fussiness. A truly irrita



</answer>

<question>



Breastfeeding question....?



So i have heard that breastfeed burns calories but i was wondering does pumping have the same effect or no?



</question>



<answer from>



MLE
Member since: 16 November 2007
Total points: 274 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



yes it does...although unless you have a really spectacular pump and are super motivated it won't be as much as if you were to just do it naturally (there are natural factors between baby and mother that help the milk supply, way different than hooking up to a machine).  I lost 40 lbs. breastfeeding exclusively for 6 months, and I do not lose weight easiliy.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I sure hope i can lose 40 lbs just breast feeding!!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Joshua and Ashley
Member since: 12 May 2008
Total points: 6445 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yeah it will.
Breastfeeding requires about 500 calories a day to simply produce the milk. You can use those extra 500 calories to add more food to your diet or to help you lose weight after the birth.



It just making the milk is hard work, therefore you lose calories.



LOOK AT THIS
How many calories do you burn while breastfeeding?
• Have you ever wondered how many calories you burn while breastfeeding or pumping? Certainly we know the milk takes energy to produce, but how much?



When I was pumping for my first child I could eat ANYTHING! It was great! I was also pumping over 80 oz of milk per day - we purchased a deep freezer just for my milk supply.



Studies have shown the average nursing mother burns 600 calories per day.



http://www.cerean.net/calories-burnt-bre...



Source(s):



Due Oct 24th.



</answer>



<answer from>



xxunlove...
Member since: 13 October 2006
Total points: 3391 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Pumping does have the same effect, since your body will produce more milk in response - which requires calories, of course. It may not burn as many calories, though, since a baby can easily get more milk out than a pump does.



</answer>

<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Newborn & Baby



</category>



<question from>



Brunn
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 2994 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



My daughter is 5 weeks and has reflux?



she takes prevacid for the reflux but she still up all night long because she is miserable... i was just wondering if it was ok to put a little bit of cereal in her bottle at night just so she can sleep better and to keep the formula down. if so how much should i give her... i dont mind being up with her all night it just that i want her to sleep for more than an hour at a time. I have heard that a little cereal at night helps fill them up so they sleep longer and also helps keep the formula down so she isn't spitting up all night



</question>



<answer from>



Shelby
Member since: 05 October 2008
Total points: 391 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hello...
Well, let me tell you about our experience...
Our son was spitting up (projectile spit up! Out the nose too!) and when we brought him to the doctor for this problem, the diagnosed him with reflux. They put him on 30 days of pepcid, told us to keep him elevated for 20 minutes after we fed him (using a sleep positioner/wedge was perfect for when trying to lay him down) and also to put 1 tsp of rice cereal in his formula (4 ounces)to help "keep the food down". This did work (thank goodness!) and by the time we needed to refill the pepcid, he had outgrown it. We also made the changeover to Similac Alimentum formula (you can read about it on their website - it's for fussiness/colic/gas) At 4.5 months he's still on the Alimentum and now taking 3 tsp of rice cereal in his 8 ounce bottles (also mixed with solids once a day).



I have heard so many conflicting opinions on the cereal in the bottle, but we were not doing to make him sleep better, as some people believe this does for a baby. We were doing it for the medical purpose of keeping his food in his belly and not coming back out. It's worked for us, and I'm sure for many others. But, I can see your hesitation for doing this and I'd always suggest you speak with your doctor.



Also, check with your insurance to see if you are covered for infant formulas. Some insurances will cover a full year for your baby - and if this is the case you can have the doctor write out a prescription which you'd just pick up at the pharmacy monthly. We do this with the Alimentum.



Best of luck - I know it's so hard. You want their food to help soothe them, and it's such a difficult thing to watch your baby fuss after being fed. It's a viscious cycle, but you will find the right balance in time...



:-)



</answer>



<asker's comment>



very informative thank you



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



USMC Wife, Pitbull Mama
Member since: 20 May 2007
Total points: 4470 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



A friend of mine is having the same issues. She was told to keep her daughter's head elevated after each breast for about 15 min, she also puts her in her vibrating bouncer if she's having issues sleeping.



Call your Pediatrician before doing anything to make sure it is ok to do. I was told not to give my daughter anything but breast milk and formula for the first 4 months.
FYI: the infant sleep positioners have been linked to SIDS, so please do not use one.



</answer>

<question>



My 9 month old has been vomiting, and has 100.9 temperature, what should i do?



She has vomit 4 times in about 6 hrs, every time i give her something to drink, she vomits...no diarrhea, what can I do?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>

<original file>10002.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk83310.txt</current file name>




<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Newborn & Baby



</category>



<question from>



josh'smu...
Member since: 11 May 2008
Total points: 136 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Hi my son just got his first tooth last week but wen i saw it for the first time i could feel it coz it came r?



right out, yesrterday i saw another one but its jsut on th top of the gum i cant feel it is it cut throgh yet or not is he still having pain as he has been waking in the night and fussing alot if so how long till i can feel it like i did the first one



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



It varies between kids and teeth.  No sure bets.



Should be soon though.  Give him things to chew on that will help.  Day old pizza crust helped one of mine.  A wooden peg (clothes pin) another.  One tried to take chunks out of his cot!



there are homeopathic remedies that help the discomfort or you can go for good old kiddies paracetamol at night whatever helps.  2 of mine learnt really poor sleep habits while teething but by #3 I was wise and gave them pain relief before bed and stopped the bad habit befoe it started.



Any grown up who has had a painful wisdom tooth knows the pain so be sympathetic, but try to stave off long term habits.



It will come through -- and the next and the next and the next.



Enjoy though all the firsts are exciting!



</answer>

<answer from>



tolerant...
Member since: 24 October 2008
Total points: 401 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yip lots of us have done it.  Luckily most of us have not had a serious injury though.  something about mothering instincts saves them - but not always us.



I bought a 2nd hand high chair for my 1st and didn't know the straps weren't connected properly.  5 mth old slipped straight under the tray and landed (luckily) bum first on the floor.  I think I cried more than she did!  She was fine tho (but I never told hubby about it!)



Baby # 3 was in my arms when I tripped on something on stairs -- I kept her upright on top of my chest but I was in bandages for  weeks with a chipped bone in my foot.



Accidents happen you can't predict or prevent everything, just minimise what you can and live your life.



Babies are tougher than you think, as long as you are doing your best you will be a great parent!!



NOTE our worst accident was my oldest who (for some totally unknown reason) at the age of 5 put the end of  the rake in her mouth while on the swing.  It hit the ground and stopped dead, she didn't.  Blood from her nose and mouth sure was scary esp as I didn't know what had happened and she was too hysterical to tell me.  She was lucky not to need surgery AND to eat almost exclusively ice cream for a week!



Be well!



</answer>



<answer from>



Brenda A
Member since: 12 December 2006
Total points: 622 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yup! I was getting my daughter out of her swing one day, and her head fell forward and it redistributed her weight enough to make the swing come right out from under her. She fell right through my hands!! Scared the dickens out of me and we took her to the ER. She was fine (I think it hurt me more than it hurt her!!). Just a little bruise on her head.



But like anything that you carry all the time, it is possible to drop it at some point. It's an accident, but just follow up and see the doctor if necessary. Good luck! Parenting is hard work!!



Source(s):

although i love it now(holly is 6.5mths)i didn't really like it to start with,we did plan holly so i should of been prepared however i dont think i was,it was such a shock from getting in from work and just sitting doing nothing to now never having 5Min's to rest(or that's what it felt like).

Meghan

Total points: 1941 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I wouldn't give it up for anything in the world. Being a stay at home mom was my dream career since I was a kid, and now I get to live out my dream :-)



</answer>



<answer from>



NewMomma
Member since: 12 March 2007
Total points: 6075 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Before I had children I thought I loved the newborn stage best. Now that I have two of my own, I realized that the newborn stage is actually my least favorite stage of a child's development. The sleep deprivation hits me pretty hard, plus my hormones get all wacky, so while I don't dislike it, it is not my favorite time.



That being said, I love being a mommy. It was the only career I've ever truly wanted and I am so lucky that I get to stay home with my children. My oldest is 28 months and my youngest 6 months and since a couple months ago mommy hood turned the corner to being the absolute most fun time ever. Sure, it has it's challenging moments, what worthwhile endeavor doesn't, but once colic and numerous nighttime wakes ups are gone, it just keeps getting better and better. My littlest is the sweetest baby and now that she's really interactive the true fun has begun. And my oldest, oh gosh, I learned with him that every stage is better than the last, yes, even the terrible two stage is a wonderful one! :)



</answer>

<question from>



Get Well Travis and Adam!!!
Member since: 01 June 2006
Total points: 1094 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



I want to have a baby so bad but I'm battling depression and anxiety: best to wait a while longer?



I am 26 years old and married btw.



</question>



<answer from>



Beverly W
Member since: 14 February 2007
Total points: 1001 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



having a baby is alife altering experience, wait until you are more settled, fight and conquer your own demons first, before you bring a child into the world. best of luck



</answer>



<answer from>



lm
Member since: 12 June 2008
Total points: 121 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



DEFINITELY wait!  Having a baby really throws your hormones out of wack more and adding sever sleep deprivation and a screaming child will not help matters.  I would find the cause of your depression and anxiety first.  Is it environmental or chemical?  Or is it your way of viewing life?  I would see a doctor and rule out chemical issues (low seratonin) things like that.  If it's not that I would recommend a therapist.  But try to at least figure out where the depression and anxiety are coming from.  It is best to be as on top of your game as you can before you bring a little child into this world.  I'm sure you will work through your difficulties and when you do have that child it will be quite a physical and mental drain for a while but it is worth it!  Take care and good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Lulu86
Member since: 05 February 2008
Total points: 4023 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'd say you should wait until you are on top of your depression and anxiety.  Pregnancy puts your hormones all over the place, I cried more than I have done in years!  Then when you've just had the baby it's tough.  You're so tired, emotional, stressed and anxious about taking care of your baby.



Good luck with whatever you decide.



</answer>

<question from>



Aislyn Nichole is here!!
Member since: 25 August 2008

</question from>



<question>



I'm a little freaked out... TMI warning!?



Okay, I gave birth to my daughter 15 days ago. I've had the normal bleeding that comes after delivery, with the occasional jelly-looking blood clots, although I haven't had one in about a week or so. Then early this morning (about 4 hours ago), I went to the bathroom and there was a weird looking mass in my pad. I looked closer, and it looked like some kind of clot, but it wasn't dark red or jelly-like, like it had always been before. It was a little slimy looking, with some darker red coloring, along with streaks of pink (almost skin-colored). The part that really scares me is the fact that there was a hard piece of something in there. I'm sorry for the TMI, but I really need some advice on whether or not I should call my doctor, or if it's normal. Please please help!!



Thanks so much!



---J



</question>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



I live in a small apartment . Where is a good location for my son's first birthday?



I don't want to spend too much money but I want everyone to be comfortable and make the occasion very memorable.



</question>



<additional details>

</additional details>



<answer from>



Sunny
Member since: 22 February 2008
Total points: 13132 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>

<answer from>



STAR [:Happy Bday Johnny:]

<answer>



The hospital will show you exactly what to do, but essentially it is.. everytime you change his diaper (about every 2 hours) you make sure there is no blood coming out, it will look red, but make sure there isnt blood clots and alot of blood. Then you will squeeze the ointment onto a gauze and you place the gauze right over his penis so it is covering it all around, and then you put the diaper on.



</answer>

<answer>



the nurses will show and help you learn what to do with it.  i was told to put vasoline on it to keep it from sticking to the diaper for a change.  during a diaper change i was to clean with a warm washcloth (no wipes) and cover with vasoline to prevent sticking.  other than that it heals all on its own

No, I don't think you can overfeed your baby, at almost two weeks 5 to 5 1/2 oz seem normal, he might end up staying at that much for some months and what would change is after every so many hours of feeding time  (i.e. 2 hrs instead of 4). Overfeeding is giving him like 8 ozs at only 2 weeks old for every 2 to 4 hours and you're not, so, don't worry.

Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 30480 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



You cannot overfeed a baby if you let him take what he wants.



However, I'm very puzzled by your comment about not having milk yet.  How do you know you don't have milk?  By 10 days most women DO have milk.  And if yours is slow about coming in, the best way to encourage it to come in is to be nursing as often as possible.  Every time you give a bottle you AREN'T nursing, and your body doesn't know that it's supposed to be making milk.



So start putting baby to the breast.  IF there isn't enough milk and baby is getting dehydrated, talk to a lactation consultant about feeding a bit of formula with a syringe or spoon or cup.  If you continue with the bottles your baby WILL end up completely formula fed.



</answer>

<question>



Please help me figure out what doc I need to go to! My infant has rectal bleeding, vomiting and crying spells?



What kind of Doctor do I need to try to find to see my son? A Pedartic Genetic Doctor an Pedatric Immunologist Doctor or some other type of doctor? Here is a good bit of info on him and the things going on with my little guy,  so someone can maybe point me in the right direction. My son is 3 months old and has had rectal bleeding for over 2 months now and vomits a lot! His ped. referred him to a Ped. Gasternologist. The ped gastor. says he believes he is highly allergic to milk protiens. He had his formula switched a total of 6 times and is now on Neocate. As well as Beechnut cereal with every feeding, the Ped. Gastern. told me to stick 2 tsp in for every ounce, however I felt that was way to much cereal, for a 3 month old to be on. He is also on 3 acid reflux medications as well. The bleeding and vomiting subsided for about a week, but now it is all back again and now he is EXEREMLY fussy! I cant seem to do anything to calm him down. He falls asleep crying and wakes up crying! He has had a rough start at life, he was a NICU baby, need to be on a ventalor, cpap, nose cannale, feeding tube, had pnumonia 2x's well in the nicu and had bronctics approx 2 wks ago. He had lung diease as well when he was born and was not able to keep his own oxygen level, they did blood gasses on him several times a day when he was in the nicu, he had yellow jaundice & had to have phototherapy as well when in the nicu. He also need a blood trasfusion when he was a week old, he had surgery for Pyloric stenonis when he was a month old. Nothing seems to be getting better for him. The doctors will try something new with him and the sythpoms subside for a week or two and are right back again. I dont know what else to do or what other doctors to have him checked by! No doctor has done blood work or any test on him. I am getting fed up with the docs. I hate seeing my baby in pain. And feel helpless when I cant do anything to make him better! I thought he may have Necrotizing Enterocolitis but I would have thought they would have tested him for that in the nicu. He has just about every sythpom of it except the budgling stomach. I mentioned it to the gastren. doc and he didnt want to hear anything about it! He is thinking it is the milk allergy as well as acid reflux, well if it is that why isnt the medication working and why is he still having all the samethings still going on! Why do they go away for a few days when they try something new for him then come back. I feel like they are using him as a guiene pig. I dont know where else to turn!



Now today he woke up crying at 615am, his crib, blanket and pjs were soaked with throw up. I picked him up out of the crib and he threw up more all over my shoulder and down my back! His last feeding was at 407am and he only drank 4oz. He had to take his medication when he got up do I gave him that at 630am. I of course cleaned him all up, changed his diaper cause he had popped! The poop had little spots of blood through, today it wasnt bright red it was darker. And the poop was a VERY dark color, hard to tell if it was DARK green or black, I used a permant black mark and made a little mark on the diaper and compared the color to the poop and it seemed to look quite the same!



He hasnt had an fevers, except a small one about a month ago. That went away in a few hours.  And he is gaining weight, atleast when we were at the doctors last he was! Thats why I think the doctors dont feel this is anything to be concerned about! But, I know my baby and I feel there is something more going on with him.  We are going for a second opion for a Ped. Gastnerologist, but cant get in til Feb. 2nd, however he is on a waiting list and if anyone cancels they said they will get him in sooner!



PLease help me! And him!!!



He had an ultrasound, upper gi and an x-ray, they said, they saw acid reflux but everything else looked ok!



</question>



<additional details>



We took him to the ER when this all first started about a 2 months ago and they said they couldnt do anything for him, cause he wasnt running a fever. And that it sounded to be milk protien allergy! I just dont understand that, he DOESNT get anything that has MILK PROTEIN in it and has for over a month now!



</additional details>

<answer>



i don't know where you live but i doubt the ER will do anything, they will just refer you to a specialist. (except a children's hospital may do more for you than a regular hospital)



have you talked to his regular pediatrician about the second opinion and see if your regular pediatrician could call the specialist to see if they can get him in sooner?



often times if the doctor himself calls the specialist and speaks to him they will fit your baby in sooner.  call your regular ped and ask for them to call you back and explain this and just ask him or her if they could please call the specialist and see if they could do anything to get your baby in sooner for a second opinion because you feel you were not getting enough help from the one they referred you to.  this is really the only way you are going to get in sooner unless someone cancels.  just beg your doctor to call on your behalf (and i do not mean a secretary from his office, the doctor himself should call)



and if none of this works and you still can't get in for the second opinion sooner, THEN consider going to an ER at a children's hospital if you have one near you, but i would go to specifically a children's hospital if you can and hopefully they could get you in with someone sooner.



i am sorry that sounds awful..

<answer>



My daughter also had acid reflex and a milk allergy (that we did not know until 5 months old because we had to switch doctors) and i know how hard it can be my daughter cried for 2 straight weeks with almost no sleep and no eating because it much have hurt so bad. My daughter also had blood in her poop but 2 formulas later and 2 med later she is finally a happy 7 month! <answer from>



dizzy
Member since: 21 August 2008

<answer>



I would take him to a major medical hospital for pediatrics only (here in CT we have one called "Children's Medical Center" in Hartford and then there's Yale New Haven Children's Hospital.  they're both quite a distance.  I don't know where you live or if any at all but it's worth taking him there to the ER and they have specialists of all kind.



My son, (he's now 15) always suffered from Asthma, pneumonia, rectal bleeding etc (similar to yours) until it came to a point that all he was pooping was fresh blood at age of 9,  No doctor helped until I took him to the Childrens Center and they did an emergency colonoscopy and endoscopy, it turned out that yes he was allergic to milk protein, so he was not able to have anymore milk protein products (not lactose intolerant, which is totally different) and they had him on Orange juice to get calcium and soy foods.  It was a life changing experience for ALL of us and he stayed on that strict diet upto 3 years ago, never again suffered from asthma, rectal bleeding, pneumonia and he's normal now and eats EVERYTHING.  It was a pain but it was well worth it and only temporary.  If I'm not mistaken there's baby formula made from Soy.



In any case, I would take him to a major medical facility specializing in children.



Good Luck and take care.



Heads up, sounds like you're doing a great job mom.



</answer>

<question from>



Aislyn Nichole is here!!
Member since: 25 August 2008

</question from>



<question>



I'm a little freaked out... TMI warning!?



Okay, I gave birth to my daughter 15 days ago. I've had the normal bleeding that comes after delivery, with the occasional jelly-looking blood clots, although I haven't had one in about a week or so. Then early this morning (about 4 hours ago), I went to the bathroom and there was a weird looking mass in my pad. I looked closer, and it looked like some kind of clot, but it wasn't dark red or jelly-like, like it had always been before. It was a little slimy looking, with some darker red coloring, along with streaks of pink (almost skin-colored). The part that really scares me is the fact that there was a hard piece of something in there. I'm sorry for the TMI, but I really need some advice on whether or not I should call my doctor, or if it's normal. Please please help!!



Thanks so much!



---J

Volks
Member since: 26 March 2008
Total points: 11131 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Marriage & Divorce



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



When you START a child on solid foods, it's about letting them experience new tastes and textures....it's not about giving them solids to fill them or give them nutrition really.



When you start solids, you should be giving him just a taste or two, maybe once a day.  When you feed him an entire jar of baby food, then that's one less nursing he'll do or one less bottle he'll be taking.  There are no solid foods out there that can match the nutrition that a baby needs like breastmilk or formula.



Solids should not really be a major part of his food intake until he is a year old.  Breastmilk or formula needs to remain the biggest source of nutrition until the child is a year old.



Until then, you let him have a taste or two, and as the months go on, he can have a little more.  But you should ALWAYS offer the breast or bottle FIRST.  Then give him some solids if he wants some, NOT the other way around.



</answer>



<answer from>
Member since: 04 January 2008
Total points: 11901 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



my daughter was only 4mos at weaning so she was only taing a few spoonfuls once a day, then up to half a jar once a day, then a full jar then i increased to 2 meals a day and so on.



if he is ok with it and he is obviously hungry, and ready for it to take the full jar - dont worry!



</answer>

bernie2u...

<answer>



Sounds normal. The first step food isn't usually alot. But like someone suggested, give him a bottle before you give him solids. Right now he doesn't "need" solids. But I do keep jar food on hand just in case we are traveling, going to grandparents houses, etc. I try to organic brands or regular Gerber. Debbie

<answer>



Well, personally, one of the things that I hated on all my breastfeeding classes that I attented was that I was not told straight up on how much it hurts and on how some milk duds (spelling?) will not open to spread the milk and what to do to ease the pain, It was all like, caring and loving and easy and support, blah blah blah, sweet talking 100% of the time, fit in some true facts too, loss of sleep, possible colic, chest pains, you'll feel lumps but don't get paranoid, etc etc and I think you'll have more moms looking for you and refer others as well.

<answer from>



Apryl S
Member since: 19 September 2007
Total points: 185 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I took classes before the birth of my daughter which touched on breastfeeding but did not go into great detail.  I breastfed my daughter and the first couple of days I had a very difficult time getting her to latch and it became very frusterating.  The nurses in the hospital were not very helpful and in fact made me more discouraged.  They would comment on how my daughter really needs to start nursing and made me feel like a bad mother.  My husband talked to a supervisor and thank God, they immediately sent in a lactation specialist who informed me I was doing nothing wrong and that it takes time, she then showed my the football hold which was so much more comfortable to hold my baby and the baby liked it more and from there it was so much better.  So to answer your questions, pleases stress to your pupils not to be discouraged that it takes time and it is not because they are doing something wrong, it just takes time and not to get frusterated.  And show the mother's the different holds, in my classes I was showed more of the basic baby across your lap , this way each mother and baby can find a postition comfortable for them.  Also, provide them with information that there are lactation specialists out there who are happy to help them and there is nothing wrong with asking for help.  Also, go over ways that mother's can sooth the pain and cracking of nipples the first couple of days and again stress not to be discouraged that it will go away.  Breastfeeding was one of the best experineces of my life after those first couple of days, time I will never forget.



</answer>



<answer from>



NewMomma
Member since: 12 March 2007
Total points: 6077 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Honestly, I went to two breastfeeding classes and read the entire "The Womanly Art of Breastfeeding" before my first was born and none of it truly prepared me for breastfeeding. Being told that it can be difficult or how to latch a baby is one thing and experiencing a screaming baby who can't figure out how to latch or the pain that comes with bleeding scabby nipples are two distinctly different things. If you could actually have women try latching with a real, live baby, that would be the best, albiet a little weird. LOL.



The obvious things, like showing a correct latch, what to expect schedulewise, what to look for if a problem like thrush or mastitis arises etc. I would also stress that the beginning weeks might be a little difficult but that it really does get better and is worth the effort. Also, providing the contact information for a really good lactation consultant, more if you have them, would be invaluable. I saw four or five different consultants with my first and it was only the last one that was actually able to help my son figure out how to latch.



</answer>



<answer from>



BABA BOOEY!! Obama/ Biden

<answer>



i so wish i had taken a breastfeeding class before i gave birth to my first, maybe i would not have quit after 5 weeks



breastfeeding was very frustrating for me and i thought i was strange because i thought it was supposed to come naturally, i would cry and get very upset about it, i had a very hard time with breastfeeding and quit after 5 weeks



i have since learned it is that way for a lot of people, not just me.  i think that is the most important thing to know, that it can be very frustrating but it does get better and not to give up and seek help if you need it and that you are not weird, that many mothers have trouble with it.



also showing the different ways to latch on and that it is NORMAL if the baby constantly eats for the first few weeks and also address the biggest concern most mothers have "how do i know my baby is getting enough??"

<answer from>



tolerant...
Member since: 24 October 2008
Total points: 403 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am in New Zealand, I have a friend who is Jamaican, who was flabergasted by the fact that antenatal classes included breastfeeding at all -- there is just NO problem with feeding AT ALL in Jamaica - she said.  I asked my midwife about this, she had travelled alot including Kenya, and told me about studies which showed that there is a strong visual element to learning to breastfeed.  That is, that in 3rd world nations where breast feeding is the ONLY choice and it is done completely openly there is no issue with success rates.



In western society, many women are frowned upon for feeding in public places, families are seperated by house, city or whole countries and we don't have the opportunity to observe breastfeeding in action as a natural part of our community.  Therefore we may be missing a huge chunk of valuable knowledge without even being aware of it.



The best possible class, in my humble opinion, (fed 3 babies successfully) would be to have members of your previous classes come along and demostrate FOR REAL breast feeding, to talk about any problems they had and to talk about how they solved those problems.



Your expectant mothers may be nervous as many of us have never seen anyone elses breasts before, so encourage them to get comfortable with their bodies and the natural rhythm of feeding.



And yes breastfeeding did hurt at first and that was OK.  I had a couple of cracked nipples but with support from my sister in law who had overcome major mastitis, I made it through and gave my kids the best start I could.



Good Luck.



</answer>
