<answer from>



Volks
Member since: 26 March 2008
Total points: 11131 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Marriage & Divorce



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



The first thing I would start out with is asking the class how many of them know moms who "couldn't breastfeed".



I'd bet nearly everyone will raise their hand.



Then give them the facts that at least 97% of women can breastfeed, and the vast majority that can't have had surgery that prevents it.  Tell them that nearly every woman can, but many give up when a problem arises and that's why you're there....to show them what 'can' happen and how to work through it.



The best thing that I think you can teach is that it's not always as simple as it sounds, but it's worth it, no matter what.



For instance, I had severe pain while nursing for about 3 months.  Everyone said "it shouldn't hurt, that baby must not be latched on properly".  I felt that she was latched on properly, but I saw a Lactation Consultant anyway who verified that she was latched on PERFECTLY.



But it still hurt, a lot.  It brought tears to my eyes every time she nursed for 3 months.  But I was determined to make it to a year, even if I had to walk through fire to do it.  After about 3 months, the pain subsided and I ended up nursing both my kids for just over 2 years each.



My point being is that even if it isn't smooth sailing, moms need to seek support and just don't give up.  Even if it's inconvenient, mom's shouldn't give up.



I see people around me that were like "Oh I tried, but I leaked too much" or "It hurt" or "I'm going back to work, so it's too much of a hassle".



I think it would be great if you could remind women that it's not about them once they give birth, it's all about the BABY and breastmilk is what's best for them, and that it's their responsibility to do the best for their baby at all times, even if she leaks, it hurts, she has to go back to work, or whatever else.



Believe me, if I can get through the pain for 3 months, anyone can.



I also think that you should tell them all the facts about that your milk doesn't come in for a few days and that's NORMAL, and the baby does NOT need formula during that time.  Explain what colostrum is and why it's so important that a baby have only the colostrum until the milk comes in.



I would also be sure to let them know that it's FINE if the baby nurses more than their friends or that it seems like that baby is always hungry.  Many women see this as a sign of not having enough milk, but it's almost always NOT the case.  Remind them if they're seeing wet diapers (I forget how many a day), then the baby is doing just fine.



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Since you have ,been going thru this 15 years you know the drill. Depression is affected by diet, stress, drugs, and exercise. You have to get walking again. That will help increase the natural happy drug in your brain.The sunlight is also great for depression. You feel yourself slipping, I can relate. It is good that you recognize your symptoms and acknowledge it before you are too far depressed. So get to walking again, check your diet, and remember baby picks up on your emotions.Call a friend, heck e-mail me. Have you spoken to your MD about it? Are you on any birth control? Some birth controls make the hormones so wacky that it causes depression.

<answer from>



ILuvMyLi...
Member since: 24 October 2006
Total points: 2470 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I know the feeling...you're in good company here. =) I had my son in January, and chose to ignore the signs that I was developing depression because I convinced myself that I didn't have time to get depression. I was in my last few months of nursing school, working part time, my hubby works 2 jobs, and of course money is always an issue. Everything kept piling up until I was horrible to be around. My mood swings were horrible, and I would be angry or crying for no real good reason.



I felt like I wasn't being fair enough to my boy. I was still attentive, but I felt like he was missing the fun part of me. When he was 5 months old I saw a doctor, and went on Lexapro for a couple months. Now my son is 9 months old and I am happier than I ever was. I was able to finish school and am enjoying quality time with my family.
My point is...if you don't feel like yourself...get some help. See a counselor or a doctor, depending on how you feel about medications. After dealing with PPD I am not at all ashamed to admit that I used medications to help me come back to normal, it saved me a lot of heartache. Don't feel guilty, or beat yourself up, it truly is something that we cannot control. But please do get some help. It's worth it...I promise. =) I hope that helps.



Source(s):



22 yrs old, happily married for 4 years, mommy of 9 month old Quinton, and fully recovered from PPD.



</answer>

<question>



Extended rear-facing mommies: I think it's time, I am so sad!..?



My grandma bought a cheap car seat for her car for when she has to pick my daughter up from day care. The kind she got is not a convertible car seat, so when she had it put in her car it was obviously forward-facing. She picked Ava up from daycare today and took her to her house, then brought her home a little later. Then a little earlier tonight my mom was taking her to the store, which the car seat in her car is rear-facing. I had a hard time getting her to sit in the car seat. Usually she doesn't want to sit in the car seat, but I figured it was normal.. but tonight it was worse. So, I am thinking I am going to turn her around so she's forward-facing.



But, the problem is... I feel terrible for turning her around since I know it is best for her to be rear-facing.



How do I go about turning her around? This is a lot easier for her, because she likes being forward, but a lot harder for me to deal with because I want her rear-facing.



</question>



<additional details>



Ava is 15 months, BTW.



I know she is old enough to be forward-facing, but it is much safer for her to be rear-facing! I know she can "legally" be forward, but I didn't want her to be.



Cali - Just wondering if you can explain to me why you think a child is safer forward-facing?



Do a little research and you will find that rear-facing longer than a year is a LOT safer than forward-facing!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Connors Mommy ツ
Member since: 02 June 2007
Total points: 10408 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



This may sound a bit harsh...



Is it worth more trouble dealing with the possibility of internal decapitation, or more serious injury, god forbid.... or dealing with the obstacle of getting her into the seat, rear facing?



My mom has a forward facing seat, and mine is rear facing... My son has to deal with it.  Safety first.  That's more important then weather or not he likes it or not.



Personally, I'd stay rear facing till she's outgrown the weight limit of the seat.  Trust your gut.  You are questioning yourself for a reason...



How about a distraction with a cracker, or juice to get her to get into the seat, rear facing?



</answer>



<asker's comment>

But, she screams the whole time we are driving until I get her out.
I think I will wait it out and see if it gets any better before making my decision.
Thanks :)



</asker's comment>

Alyssa's Mommy

After 12 months its fine for her to sit forward facing. She probably likes it better this way because she can see out the windows a little better, along with seeing whoever is in the front seat.



Alyssa is 15 months old as well and she loves the new forward facing car seat, as i do because i can see her, and hand her a toy or her sippy cup if i wanted to.

<answer>



Children over one can safely face forward, so don't fret about that. I had a hard time when my daughter turned forward facing. <answer>



I guess you have two choices to make, Mommy.........either keep her backwards facing or turn her forwards facing. At this point, there is going to be pro's and con's either way.
You keep her backwards facing, and she's not happy. *But* you will feel like she's safer. You turn her around, and have a happy baby. *But* you might worry.
You just need to decide which you can live with. But remember, that any decision can be changed. If you want, turn her around and see how you feel. If the guilt/worry is too much, turn her back around. She's 15 months, she'll get over it...LOL.

Marie37

</answer from>



<answer>



The general rule for forward facing car seats in over 1 year and over 20 lbs. I would be more concerned with the quality of the car seat purchased. Since you mentioned it was a cheap one, I would check the NHTSA rating. If it has a high rating, your daughter will be well protected.  If it's not, you really should invest in a good one, even it's just to pick up from day care. From someone who had a devastating car accident as a child, and only 1 mile away from my house, it's important to remember that they can happen to anyone, anytime, and anywhere, and the only thing we can do is be as prepared as possible.



Source(s):



http://www.nhtsa.gov/



</answer>

<question>



What is your fever reducing strategy of choice?



My 10 month old has a bug that he caught from daycare. His temp has been fluctuating between 101.9 and 102.5. He also has a bit of a rash and he's been throwing up. My husband is at the doctor's with him as I type this. So I am not looking for anyone to diagnosis him...but curious what other mothers do to bring down a fever.



</question>

Valerie

<answer>



Since he's vomitting, I wouldn't give him any medication.  Just a cool bath (not cold - that can cause shock). Dress him in a light t-shirt and diaper, and cover him with a light blanket if he seems chilled.



Don't worry too much, 102.5 isn't high for a young child.  My doctors said not to worry until it gets over 104.5!



</answer>

<answer>



Care with a bath, if they get cold while getting out, it could spike their fever up higher. Keep him bundled up and try not to let him get too cold while drying off.



I use Tylenol or Motrin and alternate between the two every 3 hours and don't have any problems with keeping the fever down with it.



Edit - I just now noticed you said he has been throwing up...In that case it might be hard to keep Tylenol or Motrin down him...Well I suppose the bath might be the best solution.



</answer>



<answer from>



Peanut Butter
Member since: 12 June 2008
Total points: 2713 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have four children, and my fever-reducing strategy of choice is nothing.  A fever is part of your body's method of fighting off germs.  We don't routinely do anything to bring a fever down.  If a child is absolutely miserable (like a 1 year old that cries even when being held), then I'll give tylenol as needed, but otherwise nothing.  I'd probably say that we medicate less than 10% of the time that any of us have a temperature.



</answer>



<answer from>



SillyGi...
Member since: 19 April 2006
Total points: 20600 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



A fever us a body's natural defense against disease...so in my opinion, it's best to just let it ride as long as it doesn't get passed 103-104.



By administering fever reducers, you're actually interfering with your body's natural defenses.  Now that's all fine and good when you're talking about a grown up that can "suck it up"...but with a little one...you may have to find alternate methods of dealing with the misery that comes along with the fever



If the child is uncomfortable, then a tepid bath always works and seems to cheer mine up...although...the effects of a bath are short lived in my experience.



At night I'll give him Tylenol or Motrin just because obviously I'm not there to make sure he doesn't spike....but during the day when I'm supervising his condition...I try to let his body do the germ killing the way it was designed to and avoid unnecessary drugs as much as possible.



</answer>



<answer from>



SAHM
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 103 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



infant motrin has always worked best for my daughter.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lauren F (BCA)
Member since: 27 November 2007
Total points: 10344 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



A fever is your body's natural defense, weakening germs.  :)  It's really cool!!



You don't need to give meds, in fact that leads to the reduced fever, leading to more illness since the germs are stronger at a lower temp.
Anyway, the only real worry is chilling or overheating your child, not the fever itself.  Your body will NOT cook itself at high temps.



When my daughter has a fever, we simply offer lots of fluids (she nurses, which is just great during illness!!), and keep her from shivering or sweating.  Lukewarm baths help if she feels really hot, but we also do not want to give her a chill.
It passes just fine!!  Last week she was at 101.5 for a couple days, and then it was gone.  :)



Source(s):



Mommy of a 24 month old



</answer>



<answer from>



Heart's in the 808
Member since: 10 January 2008
Total points: 29071 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Parenting



</answer from>



<answer>



Fever exists for a reason to burn off invading threats...allow his fever to run without intervention while keeping him hydrated...lots of water and Pedialyte...give him toast and applesauce for energy...but mainly keep him hydrated. You can give cool bathes and wipe him down with a cool damp cloth.



</answer>

<question from>



Smithers
Member since: 04 July 2007
Total points: 440 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Baby refusing feeds, could it be Milk Protein intolerance?



Ok, I have quite alot to say, so here goes!



Our baby (Harry) is 13 weeks old tomorrow. Since around 2 weeks, he as struggled taking his milk. To cut a long story, he was refusing milk, gewtting very upset each and every time he was awake. We tried him on Cow & Gate comfort one milk. I believe this is thicker milk. He was having Colic on regular nights too. The comfort milk was helping a little but Harry was still very unhappy. We went to see a specialist who suggested that Harry could be milk protein intolerant. Both our nephews have it so sit could run in the family? He prescribed us some Pepti-Junior milk which is virtually Lactose free (&lt;1g) Before trying the milk, we gave Harry Colief whick coupled with Comfort milk, eased his symptoms considerably. He was feeding vvery well. However, he was still getting very upset when awake and was obviously in pain. However, we had NO COLIC. Since Monday, Harry has been refusing comfort milk and the Colief had made his poos very runny. We started the prescribed Pepti-Junior (Cow & Gate) last night. He had 8oz in the night over  feeds 4 oz each. However, this morning, he has only had 3.5 ounces and has been refusing the feed. He has also been bringing a clear, watery liqued which has an acidic smell to it, back up after feeding and then refusing again. We spoke to the Doctor again today, who has advised to be 'patient and persistent' with the milk over the weekend as the intestines need to time to adjust. However, I am concerned that if Harry continues to have so little, he could become even more poorly After all this, I have a few questions, if anyone could help or had similar experiences:



Is it common for babies with this to take time to adapt?



How quickly should there food uptake increase on this new milk?



Are there any other types of milk that could help Harry?



Could it bne Reflux and if so, how can this be improved



Sorry for the length and depth of this question but any advice from those  in the know or who have had similar experiences would be most grateful. Thank You...



Smithers X



</question>



<additional details>



We have been to see a specialist, and he has advised to be patient. I am just asking if people have had similar experiences and if so, how did it pan out. We are following thhe advice the specialist gave us today and I am just wondering if others have had similar experiences, and what happened if so.



S



</additional details>



<answer from>



luis c
Member since: 25 January 2007
Total points: 1 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



GO SEE DOCTOR



</answer>



<answer from>



kade*
Member since: 22 June 2007
Total points: 1928 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



im sorry ive not got a clue but if i were u id go to ur doc who can transfer u 2 a speciallist who u can discuss this with fully



best of luck xx



Source(s):

<answer from>



chinesey...
Member since: 10 September 2008
Total points: 139 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



go ask your doctor!



</answer>



<answer from>



Valerie
Member since: 05 June 2008
Total points: 1314 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



What a bunch of rude people on here. You clearly said that you have already been to a doctor.



Lactose intolerance in babies is very rare, so its hard to say if the lactose-free milk will help.  Milk protein allergy is actually more common.  If the lactose free milk doesn't help, soy milk would be the next thing to try, but 50% of babies who are allergic to milk protein are also allergic to soy.  After that you have to switch to the crazy expensive hypo-allergenic milk (Nutramigen here in the US).



Your doctor is only asking you to wait a few days, so I would take his advice and see if Harry adjusts.  Changing his formula several times over the next few days could make the situation worse rather than better.  Good luck - I know its heartbreaking when your baby doesn't feel well.



</answer>

<answer>



Sleeping with him for a while will be beneficial, to your son. You can try bringing in his crib next to the bed you sleep in and having him surrounded with a body pillow and see if that will keep him comfortable. and later change this arrangement gradually as he grows out out of this stage,or his eczema clears up, and he is off the steroids. It is nothing you have done wrong, you have the best instinct that anyone can have for what is good for your son, you are his Mom. <answer from>



I'd rather be at the beach
Member since: 28 May 2008
Total points: 3502 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Twice a night is not a lot of waking for a 5 month old.  That's pretty good!  And transitioning to a crib does take some getting used to.  But if you stick with it, and are consistent every night, he'll get used to it!  I know, if I had the option between a full night's rest, and my sleep being interrupted twice, I would be very tempted to choose the full night's sleep!



Just be patient and consistent.



Sometimes babies like to sleep at an angle.  So you could roll up some bath towels and put them under the head of his mattress so he's a little more upright.  Make his crib as comfy and inviting as you can.



Good luck to you!!



Source(s):



mother of a 16 month old boy



</answer>

Yes, keep trying.  It made my son SO MAD when I quit breastfeeding and switched him to the bottle.  He was only about 12 weeks old. Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008

Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm a bit puzzled as to why you are wanting to wean this early.



If you are having breastfeeding problems, I'd encourage you to contact a lactation consultant for help in solving the problem. Most early problems CAN be solved with a little time, help, and positive support.



If you must wean for some other reason, then just be patient.  Try different bottles, different formulas, and try having someone else offer the bottle.



If there is no reason you have to wean ... why not just continue?  Breastmilk is, by far, the best food for a baby, and EVERY medical/nutritional organization recommends breastfeeding for, if at all possible, a minimum of a year.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bubbles
Member since: 15 October 2007
Total points: 128 (Level 1)

Other times, some babies just refuse formula. Best of luck

<question from>

<question>



How do I change baby's formula?



I had my baby on Enfamil (soy) for almost 5 months now. I moved and WIC covers Nestle Good Start here. How do I go about switching his formula? Should I just start giving him the NGS or should I do a gradually, like one bottle a day, or half of each formula? Please any tips would be helpful!



</question>



<answer from>



Baby Sophia- Any Day Now!
Member since: 25 April 2008
Total points: 218 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



When I switched my daughter to a Low Iron form of Enfamil, the doctor recommended mixing a little of the new in with the old.  Then half and half, then a little old with the new, and then finally, just the new stuff.  I did the same when I switched her over to milk.  I think that babies have an easier time when it is not such a shock to their system.  Good luck!



Source(s):



Someone calls me "Mom"



</answer>



<answer from>



Deanne S
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 149 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would say try it gradually.  Start with one bottle a day, then two, then three, etc.  My son had no problem transitioning from formula to formula.  Yours might not have a problem either! :o) I know that their might be an issue going from soy milk to milk based formula, so that is why I suggested doing it gradually.



Source(s):



Mommy of a 13 month old and 19 weeks pregnant!



</answer>



<answer from>



CC
Member since: 10 October 2008
Total points: 215 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had to do the same thing and they suggested that I do half and half for a few days. I did it for 2 days and when I ran out I switched him over completely. His transition was very smooth and we didn't have any problems. Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



Clarissa M
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



A quick change could upset his stomach.  A gradual change would be better for him.  Start giving him a bottle a day of the goodstart, then increase it everyday.  Although goodstart inst soy.  So it will probably hurt his stomach either way you do it.  My son is on goodstart.

<answer from>



ruckey95
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 251 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have been through the whole deal of changing babies formula several times, and though they claim they are all the same with the same ingredients that is so far off, I did with my first born switched her straight from one to the other due to her having tummy problems with the first. The switch resulted in tummy problems done in only one day. My second child was switch due to WIC situation as well, we did the half and half for each bottle for a couple of days finishing up what we had purchased, there never seemed to be a problem.
Now you never know how a baby is going to adjust, they are not all the same, you might want to start it off 1/3-2/3, it all depends on how sensitive your babies tummy seems to be. I would also be sure that while making this change to not be offer anything else new to the diet, too many new things at once can really cause tummy upsets, and maybe even allergic reactions that you can pinpoint as to what caused it.
Good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



chinesey...

Total points: 139 (Level 1)

<answer>



My daughter actually had no problems switching formulas. I switched 5 times in less than a month, not that it's a good thing.

<question>



Can i give my 11 month old son fish?



i like to give my baby fish like sardine or tuna which contains omega 3 fatty acids but i am scared of the mercury is fish. please help



</question>



<answer from>



Curious
Member since: 06 May 2008
Total points: 6255 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can do it, just in small quantities and not every day. Ask your doctor / pediatrician for suggestions on other fish to try that might not have such high mercury levels.



</answer>



<answer from>



Erin
Member since: 08 August 2008
Total points: 128 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



When you buy fish from the fish market you can ask the seller if the fish contains mercury, I do this all the time. Your other option is to buy fish from the fishery rather than buying salt water or fresh water fish. You can also ask the fish seller where the fish came from, I know at the grocery stores seafood department it is noted in front of each fish. Another good idea is to ask your childs pediatrician. Good Luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



usagirl_...
Member since: 21 December 2006
Total points: 191 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Tuna is high in mercury. Also any Shell Fish (catfish) and Shell Seafood (shrimps).
Cold water Wild Salmon. Flounder are the better choice for the babies.



</answer>



<answer from>



KATIE K
Member since: 20 November 2007
Total points: 5150 (Level 5)

This is a hard question.  My brother's son's pediatrician (who was our pediatrician when we were kids) told him to feed his 18 month any kind of fish since he is over a year old.  My daugher's pediatrician (they are more modern/associated with the Children's Hospital in our area) told us when she was a year absolutely no fish.  So I didn't ask again.  But when my brother told me what his pediatrican said, I asked my daughter's pediatrician again when I took my daughter for her flu shot.  She looked appalled that I could ask such a question and told me absolutely not, no fish until the age of 3 and even after that in small quantite because their digestive system even then is still developing and fish harder to digest and because of allergy concerns.  I then did some research and the magic age seems to be 3 but then I found some conflicting information that feeding babies under 12 mths. fish prevents Eczema.  But like I said we had two totally different opinions.  Personally, I followed

<answer>



It doesnt neccesarily means she wants to eat, shes just interested in what you are doing, it looks strange to her because she doesnt do this.

Signs that baby is ready to eat are being able to sit up well, having the pincer grasp and hand to mouth coordination as well as not having the tongue thrust reflex, where they spit the food out with their tongue.

</answer from>



<answer>



I wanted to dye my son's changing pad covers red (They were hand-me-downs from a girl, so pink), and his room is blue and red.  I bought some R.I.T. dye from the craft store, and it worked great... but now he's three months old, and red STILL gets everywhere every time the changing pad gets wet.  It's a pain to have to wash it separately -- I did accidentally dye my husband's socks pink... oops!  I've gotten his clothes even dyed in little pink splotches from him wetting on the changing pad while I'm changing him.  Basically, even though I thought I was saving money and being frugal, I wish I'd just bought blue or red changing pad covers!!  (PS -- I'm not sure I would dye burp pads, because when they spit up and get them all wet, that blue dye is going to transfer right onto yours and his clothes!!)



Source(s):



A sad, sad dyeing Mom! :)



</answer>

mommy of 2

<question>



Its 12:00 am my time and my 5 week old won't go to sleep?



i am tired i had a tooth pulled this morning plus i have been up since really early how do i get my little one to sleep thanks he's been awake for three hours. taking little cat naps and when i go to lay him in his crib he wakes up and starts yelling if i try to put him in the bed with me he wakes up also. ahhhh i am sleepy and my 2 yr old will be up in a few hours help please



</question>



<answer from>



kadee
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 131 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



he is not in his deep sleep mode yet, usually takes about 20 minutes after they fall asleep. When they are in the light sleep they will wake up when you put them down. Wait for the hands to be relaxed not fisted and a sure sign is when they their limbs go limp, like their arm is dangeling. Once that happens you have about 60 minutes before they hit that light sleep again. Of course check the obvious, diaper, comfort of clothing, a full tummy always helps. When I know mine is tired and she is fighting it I will put her on my shoulder and pat her back, walk around the house and make a shhh shhh shhh sound. That sound reminds them of the womb. You could always drive around the block or mine falls asleep in the stroller. I've strolled around in my house in the stroller, from room to room. Make sure there is as little stimulation as possible like the t.v. Just a few ideas. Good luck.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



short to the point and i was putting him down too quick cause i was so tired lol thank you very much



</asker's comment>

<answer>

Also, try to "swaddle" your baby in a blanket, that helps them feel secure and makes it easier to sleep.



good luck

<answer from>



mystic_e...
Member since: 21 October 2006
Total points: 93484 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



31 WAYS TO GET YOUR BABY TO GO TO SLEEP AND STAY ASLEEP EASIER
http://askdrsears.com/html/7/T070300.asp
#
TRANSITIONING TECHNIQUES



Many infants need help making the transition from being awake to falling asleep, which is really a prolongation of the bedtime ritual that conditions baby that sleep is expected to soon follow.



# Nursing down. Nestle next to your baby and breastfeed or bottlefeed him off to sleep. The smooth continuum from warm bath, to warm arms, to warm breast, to warm bed is a recipe for sleep to soon follow.



# Fathering down. Place baby in the neck nestle position (nestle baby's head against the front of your neck with your chin against the top of baby's head. The vibration of the deeper male voice lulls baby to sleep) and rock your baby to sleep. If baby doesn't drift off to sleep while rocking, lie down with your baby, still in the neck nestle position, and let baby temporarily fall asleep draped over your chest. Once baby is asleep, ease the sleeping baby into his bed and sneak away.



# Rocking or walking down. Try rocking baby to sleep in a bedside rocking chair, or walk with baby, patting her back and singing or praying.



# Nestling down. For some babies, the standard fall-to-sleep techniques are not enough. Baby just doesn't want to be put down to sleep alone. After rocking or feeding baby to sleep in your arms, lie down with your sleeping baby next to you and nestle close to her until she is sound asleep. We call this the "teddy- bear snuggle."



# Wearing down. Some babies are so revved up during the day that they have trouble winding down at night. Place your baby in a baby sling and wear her around the house for a half-hour or so before the designated bedtime. When she is fully asleep (see limp-limb sign) in the sling, ease her out of the sling onto her bed. For babies who are used to nursing off to sleep in a mother's arms, fathers can wear their baby down to sleep and give mother a break.



Wearing down is particularly useful for the reluctant napper. When baby falls asleep in the sling, snuggled with his tummy against your chest or draped over your chest once you lie down, you both can take a much-needed nap.



# Swinging down. Wind-up swings for winding down babies are a boon to parents who have neither the time, energy or creativity to muster up rituals of their own. Tired parents will pay anything for a good night's sleep. Once in a while a moving plastic seat may be more sleep inducing than a familiar pair of arms. Sometimes high-need babies associate a parent's body with play and stimulation and will not drift off to sleep in a human swing. For them the mechanical one is less stimulating, if not downright boring, and therefore can be a useful part of a sleep-ritual repertoire. Yet remember, high-need babies are notoriously resistant to mechanical mother substitutes and will usually protest anything less than the real mom. Before you actually spend money on a swing, you might want to borrow one for a week or two to see if the spell of the swing will last. You may discover that you are uncomfortable with mechanical mothering and decide to get more creative. Still, swings have their moments.



# Driving down. If you've tried all the above transitioning techniques and baby still resists falling asleep, place baby in a carseat and drive around until she falls asleep. When you return home and baby is in a deep sleep, carry the carseat (with the sleeping baby) into your bedroom and let baby remain in the carseat until the first nightwaking. If she is in a deep sleep (witness the limp-limb sign – hands unclenched, arms dangling loosely at her side, facial muscles still), you may be able to ease her out of the carseat into her own bed.



# Mechanical mothers. Gadgets to put and keep baby asleep are becoming big business. Tired parents pay high prices for a good night's sleep. It's all right to use these as relief when the main comforter wears out, but a steady diet of these artificial sleep inducers may be unhealthy. We remember a newspaper article extolling the sleep-tight virtues of a teddy bear, with a tape player in his stuffing that sings or makes breathing sounds. Baby can snuggle up to the singing, breathing, synthetic bear. Personally, we are not keen on our babies going to sleep to someone else's canned voice. Why not use the real parent?



</answer>

<answer>



My wife had similar symptoms and it ended up being an ovarian cyst.



Something is going on in that area - it may not be gynecological, though.  Are your bowels moving regularly?  If you have a family history of diverticulitis tell your doctor.  Have you ever had any appendix trouble?  Sometimes a problem in that region of your body can upset your body and cause a period to start due to inflammation.



Source(s):



My wife - who wishes you well.



</answer>

<answer>



Your child will NOT suffer poor health because you could not breastfeed, some women just can't. My mother chose not to breastfeed any of her kids, and I'm very healthy, I rarely get sick, maybe once a year.



To lose the guilt, you have nothing to feel guilty about. It shouldn't, nor does it matter how a baby is fed, as long as he or she is fed. A mother who does not feed her child at all has reason to feel guilty, you do not.



Personally, I struggled for 3 months to breastfeed before I gave up. I too felt guilty and attempted again when my daughter was 7 months. It worked for a while, but we had to stop again. If your milk has not completely dried up and if you are interested in trying again, feel free to send me a message. I will give you tips and advice, medications and herbal supplements to take to increase your supply. It will hurt at first, and it will be a battle, but it is worth it.



Good luck.



</answer>

<answer>

I couldn't either because my little one had a problem with her jaw and couldn't latch for long enough.  I ended up pumping for the first few weeks, then switched to formula.  My baby is now 2 and very active and healthy.

<answer>



Actually, if you still want to try you still can after 2 weeks.  But it sounds like you want to know how to lose the guilt.  That will happen when you see your baby love you. Breastfeeding is very hard- I had 4 sons in 5 years and nursed them all.  In fact I lactated for 8 years in a row!  Tough times but fun. Anyhow, my second son decided to wean himself very early-probably because I was pregnant with #3 right away- but anyhow he was my only one who was formula feed.  Point is: there is no difference among them.  They are all bright and healthy boys.  All that being said, if you want to try again, go for it.  I know all women are different but I went on vacation for 2 weeks and thought that my milk would dry up.  When I came back, I kind of regretted weaning the baby and so when he tried to nurse, I let him and to my surprise I had milk.  He nursed for a year after that.

<answer from>



Jeffrey's Mom
Member since: 18 September 2006

<answer>



I would call and ask a nurse before you give it to him. They gave us strict instructions on what tylenol to give to our son for his circumcision. It was 0.4 ml every 4 hrs for the first 24hrs. But our son didnt seem to have much pain with his surgery. Call just to make sure. Hope this helps.



Source(s):



Concentrated infant tylenol drops 1/2 fl oz (15ml). Is what the front of our son's tylenol  bottle says. The hospital gave it to us

<question>



Is your baby on soy formula?

</question>



<answer from>



shelbyxm...
Member since: 15 January 2008
Total points: 5515 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Talk to your doctor befor you switch your baby out. My doctor put my daughter on Soy till she was a few months old then we switched back. She is most likely fussy cause she is gassy so maybe try and burp her to be absolutly sure she doesnt have a "bubble" left in there. My daughter was hard to burp and was really gassy if I didnt get all the air out.
Some tricks I learned to get her to burp is to rub her back then lightly pat then rub; lay her back gently and bring her back up slowly; or pat her bum gently.

<answer from>



Apryl S
Member since: 19 September 2007
Total points: 195 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Talk to your pediatrician before switching.  My brother's son's mother (they are not together) told my brother that he was allergic to milk because he had gas all the time and put him on soy formula.  When my brother got custody of his son, pediatrician told him just because gas not necessarily true, he just may need burped.  Which was the case because he is not allergic to milk.  Check with your doctor because your baby could have an allergy to soy.  I breastfed my daughter but supplement with soy from time to time and everytime I gave her the soy she would projectile vomit.  Told pediatrician and was told symptom of allergy and that she was allergic to soy.  So just because gasy and fussy, does not necessarily mean they are allergic.  Talk to your pediatrician, I have some sites I listed below that I saved when my brother was going through this with his son.  Hope that helps.



Source(s):



http://www.nutritionathome.com/allergies...
http://www.baby-names.tv/Breastfeeding/B...
http://www.babiesonline.com/articles/bab...
http://www.babycenter.com/404_what-are-s...
http://www.babycenter.com/0_lactose-into...
http://kidshealth.org/parent/medical/all...
http://www.askdrsears.com/html/3/T032100...



</answer>

<answer>



I was is labor with my second from 4:20 am (woke up and lost  mucus plug) until she was born at 6:03 pm.  But I was in "active" labor for about 6hrs. I went to the hospital at 11:30 am because i live 40min from hospital  and I did not want to labor around my 4yr old.  I opted to have NO drugs! With my first I had drugs and hated how I felt and had no control.  I just sat up in my bed and talked with my mom.  I had  no IV too.  At about 5 or 530 pm they broke my water and i went into the tub (I was 8 cm).  I was in the tub until about 5:50 then I started to bleed When i was walking to my bed.  I pushed for about 7 min.  She let me push for as long or little as i wanted to.  So i was in total control.  No dumb counting!!!! So at 6:03 I delivered my second girl Kloee Sue weighing in at 6lbs even and 19 in long. I loved my labor and delivery with my second!!!

<question from>



Clarizza C
Member since: 23 June 2008
Total points: 236 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Temporary relief for breast engorgement?



My daughter is 4 days old and breast feeding. I have one nipple that is really short and cannot be latched properly. Currently it is cracked and bleeding and hurts so much to put her on it although I do suck it up and suffer through a couple feedings on it a day if I can. The problem is that I am now engorged so it is even harder for her to latch onto that nipple. The other nipple is fine and dandy and is where the majority of her feedings are coming from. I don't want to get an infection but I also do not want the sore nipple side to get engorged and/or become un usable. I plan on allowing the nipple to heal up and then trying again as we have improved greatly on our latching and I believe we should be able to avoid the pain and be just as effective on the other side as this one. I have taken to emptying the sore nipple side once a day by hand expressing the milk out but want to make sure this is alright and I am not sabotaging my efforts in the mean time. I am calling my lactation consultant tommorow but was wondering if anyone else has these problems before and what advice you can give. My nipples were both pierced before and I believe the sore one was pierced too close to the end of the nipple causing it not to retract completely when stimulated ... just the tip gets erect and it is hard to get the rest of the areola into such a little mouth .. although she is opening up wider now so we may be able to do it. Just so sore from the failed attempts before. Please let me know what you think!



</question>



<answer from>



Nurse JC
Member since: 26 June 2008
Total points: 4579 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You will need to empty that breast more then just once a day. If you only require the breast to fill once then it is start making only enough milk to fill up one time. You can try to use a pump. You can also get a big pot or basin fill it up with warm water and then lean over it and let your breast fall into the pot. The gravity and warm water helps the milk to flow out better. You can also try a nipple shield because of the damage until it heals. But if your baby is latched on properly you really shouldn't feel any pain (yes even with the way it is tore up now). It is harder for her to latch on if the breast is engorged so try to relive the engorgement before putting her on the breast.



Source(s):



Lactation counselor



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you very much everyone for your responses! I have been still feeding off that side and hand expressing only when the pain and fullness is unbearable but hopefully that nip heals up soon ... I tried the cream and a cold compress after and the next time around didn't hurt nearly as bad! Thanks!!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



mushmarl...
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 4377 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hand express from the side that is chapped every time she feeds, even if only for 5 minutes.  Invest in some Lasinol cream, it worked wonders for me and is safe for the baby, it is instant nipple relief!!! For the engorgement, cabbage works wonders, hot showers and just massaging your breast.  Hope that helps!



</answer>

<answer from>



Coley
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 182 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Of all things people warn you about when prego, they never tell you about that!  It is the worst.  I know what you are going through.  This is what you need to do.



Take a hot shower.  The heat from the shower will help tremendously.  You may have to masage your breast a little bit, like someone would when milking a cow.  This will get the milk flowing.  Continue manually pumping until your breast is soft again.  It will help to press firmly on the hard pockets.  You have to do this.  If you don't you will be in more pain, cause possible infection or loose the ability to make milk on that side.  If you can't get a lot of milk out, do it when your baby is upset.  Have your husband hold the baby while crying in the bathroom with you.  The sound of your baby crying will stimulate your milk duct and make the milk come out.  I know it sounds crazy but it's true.



If you don't already have one, I would invest in a breast pump.  Not all of us are lucky enough to produce so much milk, but I couldn't have made it though either of my breastfeeding days without one.



Oh yeah, and the cracked nipple....there's no real way around that.  You will have to toughen it up to get past it.  The sooner you just deal with it the sooner it will be over with.  Rub it hard with a wash cloth in the shower.  It will hurt, but will speed the process.



Good luck and Congats!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



stacy f
Member since: 09 August 2008
Total points: 235 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i had a inverted nipple on my left side and was doing exactly what you were doing , my nipples were painful for the first couple of days, cracked bleeding the lot it was really bad, not to mention i was engorged something chronic, i spoke to a midwife about it



she suggested wetting a nappy a little bit putting them in the freezer then placing them accross your breasts,



hot water really helped but i found the nappies to be fantastic really reall reallly helped me alot with the problem... but try to express as much as possible before you get too hard in that breast or you could be looking at mastitis...



</answer>



<answer from>



Samsonnette A
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 1351 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Try some C a l e n d u la  or



a r n i c a  (W E L E D A)
drops, diluted on a warm piece of cotton wool. Use as a compress. Moisten your breast with a similar lotion in between breast-feeding.
I know what it is like, but do try persevering. Your nipples will soon get used to it and will heal faster than you think.
Good luck !

Most of the answers on this page are "positive". Go for IT Yahoo Mystic-eye CD !

</answer>



<answer from>



jo
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 117 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Definately invest in a breastpump.  It's quite easy to hire them. If you plan on feeding for a while, it may be worth buying one, as any time you get mastitis, cracked nipples or engorgement, a breastpump can be your best friend.  I would pump at every feed to keep up your milk supply (you don't want to end up only producing milk on one side). Before pumping, while feeding on the good side, put a hot cloth on the engorged breast, while pumping massage toward the nipple, after pumping apply a cold pack. Definately use Lansinoh cream for the cracked nipple, but be careful using cabbage leaves, as they can dry up your milk quite quickly.  Watch out for any small white lumps on your nipple, as this could be a milk plug which would need to be unclogged.  It's a good idea to see a Lactation consultant, as I haven't found a GP that's too clued up on breastfeeding problems.  The breastfeeding association is also a great help and can be called 24 hours.  Good luck and all the best!!!!!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



chnchita
Member since: 19 September 2006
Total points: 3235 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Buy Lansinoh cream (any drug store should have it) and put it on your nipples after every feeding. It will help heal your skin faster and it's safe for baby. Also, to help get some of the engorgement pain gone, get a washcloth wet with warm/hot water and put it on your sore breast. Keep applying until the milk starts coming out. This should help with the pain since you'll be relieving some of the pressure. Hopefully the LC will help with baby's latching but definitely get the Lansinoh cream....saved my life! :)



Source(s):



nursed both of my children for 1 year each



</answer>



<answer from>



kadee
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 131 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I went thru this. O.k get in a hot shower. let the water hit your breast as you express it yousellf with your hands. Try to massage from the outer to the nipple. You want to get those hard what feels like rocks in there out. it's a build up of milk. Do this until your breast is completely soft again. You can use hot wet wash cloths but nothing works like the shower. Trust me. My doc told me to do it and it worked. You can also use cabbage. I know that sounds crazy but that is supposed to work too. Look it up. The shower worked wonders. If you are bleeding you definately want to let it heal. My sister got infected and engorged and they had to cut her nipple open to drain it. Try the shower, it is very important you get that milk out. After the hot shower you can apply a cool wash cloth to soothe. Oh and don't squeeze too hard I gave myself vericose veins on my breast. Be firm but gentle.



</answer>

<question>



Blood in stool. Worried or no?



I have been having issues since taking Vicodin..



I've been having a hard time going number 2, and when I do there was  a little red blood in it, and on the toilet paper.  This time I was walking and got a sharp cramp got to the bathroom and kept having sharp cramps before finally mostly liquid stool and some semi hard stool came out, noticed a lot of blood on the toilet paper, then a dark red seemingly small clot spot in the toilet.  I am not on my period.  18 years old.. To be worried or not?



I always thought it was from straining but why would it be in the stool if that were it? hmm.



</question>



<additional details>



This wasn't supposed to be in newborn and baby.. sorry, ugh yahoo! lol



</additional details>



<answer from>



Ethel
Member since: 05 September 2007
Total points: 10457 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Be worried, please see your doctor.



It surely is from straining, but on Vicodin you might not really feel some of the damage you have done to yourself.



You're probably impacted and need to be manually de-impacted (it's as lovely as it sounds).



Vicodin will make your stools hard and dry, and slow down your gastrointestinal tract - and cause you to tear.



</answer>



<answer from>



blondie
Member since: 31 August 2007
Total points: 13833 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



maybe hemorrhoids? you definitely need to see a doctor.



</answer>



<answer from>



mj69catz
Member since: 31 January 2007
Total points: 16281 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Video & Online Games



</answer from>



<answer>



While it could be something you don't need to spend a LOT of time worrying about (like an anal fissure), any blood in the stool is potentially serious and requires an immediate call to the doctor.



</answer>

He is a very hyper dog to begin with, but when we get home he is very very excited..He pee's alot in the kitchen during the day, and at times he has pooped as well, I know he has no choice because he can't go anywhere else but how can I train him not to pee or crap anywhere else in my house? he is allowed in only 4 out of 5 rooms in my house, the bedroom is the only room he is not allowed in. He also has a habit of bitting while we are playing with him, no matter how many times we tell him "NO" or "STOP", or push him away, he still does it. Any advice on all my concerns and questions...please help...I Love this dog but he needs help. <answer>



Seriously, why is this in this section, but that is way too long to leave your pup alone.  Puppies need constant attention and training.  It's going to be a while before hes fully trained and you need to either have a friend, neighbor, or hire a sitter to come feed him and at least play with him or walk him.  4 out of 5 rooms for a puppy is a lot and he must always be supervised when hes out roaming.  Puppies can't hold their bladders very long so expect a lot of mistakes and accidents, never yell, stop doesnt mean anything to him and pushing him only makes him upset and more nervous.  You need to go to puppy training courses.  They will explain how to train your dog and what not to do.

Beth
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 971 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yeah you shouldn't put it on babies clothes. Baby clothes are non flammable and I heard that the softener can reverse that...where it isn't anymore.  But I also just found this and it says researchers say there is a possible link with SIDS, something about the chemicals in the softeners that can cause difficulty breathing among other things.  It also says this



Babies often react with rashes, frequent crying and/or diarrhea. Disinfectants can have the same effects. Experts suggest a possible connection between Sudden Infant Death ("crib death") and the use of these products for washing baby clothes and crib sheets and blankets.



We don't use it because our boys are really sensitive, the only time I have...and not until they were older was Downy Sensitive liquid and then I do an extra rinse after it's done.  But I don't use it everytime, maybe oce a month and usually just on towels not the clothes themselves



</answer>



<answer from>



belinda
Member since: 24 February 2006
Total points: 12597 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Cloth diaperers know that fabric softener makes your laundry less absorbent.  It's not about the scent, although fragrances can be irritating.  If you value absorbency in your baby's laundry (and I do), then just quit using softener and dryer sheets, or use one or the other.  Vinegar is a good fabric softener, and the smell goes away.



A newborn baby doesn't drool much, and they often don't pee much either, so don't worry about the clothes you've already washed.



</answer>

<original file>179.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk90312.txt</current file name>




<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Newborn & Baby



</category>



<question from>



Danielle™ (Reece's mummy!)
Member since: 03 February 2008
Total points: 3196 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Should i cut down on his milk intake?



we moved Reece on to SMA progress milk at 6mos, and he seems fine with it. but on the back of the tin, it says he should be drinking 500-600mls a day. this is only 2 9oz bottles + a bit more. he is having 2 'meals' a day. one in the morning, and one at night. and about 4 9oz bottles! should i add an extra meal during the day, and start to lessen his milk? i know milk is still his main source of nutrients, but i don't want to over feed him on it, by nearly 18oz!



</question>



<additional details>



he's almost 7mos (can't believe it!)



</additional details>



<answer from>



Laura M™♥
Member since: 25 April 2008
Total points: 2110 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



the 500-600ml is just a guideline for a baby who is on solids so if he goes over this amount then thats fine. It is more a guideline for a baby who is established on solids with 3 meals per day with snacks. My daughter is on 3 meals per day with snacks and she generally takes around 24 oz per day. Is your son 6 months or is he older?As you start to increase his solids then his milk intake will naturally decrease anyway. If i can remember right i think my daughter took a similar amount of milk when she was on 2 meals then i gave her a 3rd meal and it wasnt long before she dropped one of her bottles. He is taking the amount of milk that he needs so everything is fine, try giving him a 3rd meal maybe with fruit or rice cakes as a snack mid morning or afternoon and you'll notice his milk intake decrease!
EDIT
7 months is fine then for him to be eating 3 meals per day. When my hv was still coming to our house she gave me a book on weaning which recommends that by 7 months they should be on 3 meals per day, although a lot of people will disagree with this but that was the information that was given to me and also, my daughter was fine with being on 3 meals a day, some babies may take a little longer, you just have to go with their pace, good luck!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Suze
Member since: 06 July 2008
Total points: 3470 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



What is says on the back of the packet is just a guide. Every baby is different and boys are often hungrier.
My son was having way more than that guide until he was well over 1. He probably still does!
You should think about moving him onto 3 meals a day now if he's hungry, and maybe slightly reduce his milk, but as long as it's not interfering with his meals it's fine.



</answer>



<answer from>
Member since: 04 January 2008
Total points: 11898 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



if you arent happy about withdrawing the milk, try 2 meals plus a snack such as chopped fruit, yoghurt or the organix finger foods. you cant overfeed him, even if you did, he would vomit the excess up.



he will eventually need more as he gets bigger an he will let you know if he is hungry. my girl still takes 3x 8oz of C&G toddler milk at 15mos, plus 3 meals a days and prob about 4-6 snacks throughout the day.



he will tell you when he needs more.



</answer>



<answer from>



Brenna momma of little Z
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 728 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi yeah it may be time to add a third meal and maybe cut slighly with maybe 5 ounces less. Milk is majorly important and you can never overfeed your baby unless he pukes if he wants it he wants it. He looks like a smart little chap he knows when he's full, he'll stop if he doesn't want anymore. Try a third meal though it's time for a third one! I feed my girl cereal and fruit morning and night and vegys, meat, sweet potat, applesauce at lunch. I do the vegies etc.. at lunch just in case she gets gassy from something new then hopefully she feels better by bed time! Good luck! Milk's important 75% milk 25%solids till 1 year. I drank tons of similac when i was kid until like age 3 b/c i was fussy and mom didn't have time for me b/c i had a baby brother who had cancer. I ended up with the best teeth in my whole family who all have rotted teeth i mean rotted dentures by age 25 kinda teeth and i haven't ever had a cavity my mom says it's the Similac! Plus i'm not a picky eater at all! Dont worry to much the back of the can is just a guide line. Just like clothes that say 6 mths in the tag don't necessarily fit at 6 mths!



</answer>

<question from>



raxgolde...
Member since: 24 January 2008
Total points: 5058 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



What is the best way to manage my baby's feeding schedule?



When we came home with her, the hospital said to wake her every three hours, during the day, and let her sleep as much as possible at night, in other words let her wake up on her own.



Now she has begun sleeping so deeply during the day that we think that she gets very upset being woken up that she does not eat well and gets really fussy.  We think it might be a good idea to let her sleep as much as possible during the day, and let her wake up normally, that way she eats well and sleeps better afterward.



Any info would be appreciated...citations would be great



Thanks



PS...she is a little over a month old



</question>



<answer from>



Noah's Mommy & Marine Wife.
Member since: 08 October 2007
Total points: 45594 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



At that age if she's gaining weight at a good rate and producing enough wet diapers a day(6-8) then I would just let her sleep when she wants to.



As long as there isn't anything medically wrong with her she should be able to let you know when she's hungry. Obviously don't let her go an insanely long amount of time without eating but I wouldn't think you'd need to wake her ALL the time to eat.



</answer>



<answer from>



Deanne S
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 140 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



With our son we let him eat whenever he was hungry.  I figure that the baby will know when he/she is hungry and will let you know, too!  Good luck, and congrats on your little miracle!!



Source(s):



mommy of a 13 month old and 19 weeks pregnant



</answer>



<answer from>



belinda
Member since: 24 February 2006
Total points: 12629 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Feed her when she asks for it.  She knows when she's hungry.



</answer>



<answer from>



MajsticS...
Member since: 26 November 2007
Total points: 559 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You have to be careful with newborns and infants that age. They are not born knowing what hunger is or what hunger pains are, they don't know when or how often they are supposed to eat. You teach them that, by feeding them, whether you have to wake them or not. A newborn-1 month old  should eat 2-3 ounces every 3 hours, or sooner if breastfed  regardless of whether is day or night, at least until they are about  2.5 - 3 months old. By that age they will still eat every 3 hours during the day and have 1 long stretch at night where they sleep for 5-7 hours( say like from 10pm-4am). You have to be careful that you are not starving her, unknowingly, of course. They should gain about 4 ounces a week or at least a pound a month. Good luck! :)



Source(s):



Mommy X 6 ~ 1 of which is 3.5 months old!



</answer>



<answer from>



mommy2B
Member since: 31 July 2007
Total points: 982 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think you should still be waking her up.  Thats just for the first week or two.  if shes gaining fine, just let her tell you when its time to eat.  "A well slept baby sleeps well" is what my pediatrician told us so don't worry about her not sleeping at night if she sleeps too much during the day.



</answer>



<answer from>



ana
Member since: 23 July 2006
Total points: 75 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i think you should wake her during the day u want to make she eats especially if she is little. and that way she can know the difference between day and night



</answer>

</question from>



<question>



So how long do I hve to wait til i can get my daughters ears pierceD?? ?



anything i should kno before i do it?? shes almost 2 months!



</question>



<answer from>



LaTishia
Member since: 08 June 2007
Total points: 731 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I got my daughter's ears pierce at 4mos by her pediatrician. I wouldn't have it done at the mall. I'm pretty sure all get thumbs down on this. However, she's my child, she didn't cry no more than she would when she gets shots (which is not that much), and I had a professional pierce them. I had mine pierce when I was 2 days old. I did them early because when she gets older I didn't want her to mess with them, which will make her more accessible to an infection. I know a lot of people that wished that would've pierced their kids when they were young because they don't want them to tug on them. As for others tugging on them, just give her the studs with or without diamonds. They can't grip them, but hoops can easily be pulled out.



I respect those who don't pierce those kids ears and I respect the reasons. But I don't understand why people are so critical on those who choose to do it. I mean complain if I put a post on here indicating I'm abusing my child. People need to realize that everyone raises their child up differently and that's fine. That's not our life to judge. I'm a wonderful mother and would do anything for my child.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I agree. there is no reason for all these people on here to be sooo mean!!! I mean she is my daughter an I think having pierced ears is cute!! Thank you for your answer....you made me a lil more confident to have it done! an now i will defintely not have it dont at the mall!!!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



pixelsca...
Member since: 11 August 2006
Total points: 651 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, pierced ears on babies are cute, but remember it's yet another body part you'll have to protect from infection, stop the kid from yanking on them, etc...



I prefer to wait until the child is older and the earlobes are more grown so there's more material to work with. If the kid's earlobes grow in such a way that the baby holes end up very low, that's no good...



Why not wait till your kid is old enough to ask for pierced ears? Then it will be more meaningful to your child and you can make it a special reward, teach self-care of the piercings, etc.



I mean, your kid isn't here to be decorative, it's his/her body you're modifying.



</answer>



<answer from>



Baby girl Due 1/25/09
Member since: 19 October 2007
Total points: 7868 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have to agree with others who say to wait until your daughter is old enough to ask for it to be done. It's really your choice of course, but the possibility of her ear lobes becoming ripped because she accidentally ripped the earring out becomes greater. Babies can't understand that you have to be gentle with earrings. As older children they can at least understand and take care of them properly. And then it becomes their choice as well instead of forcing them to have pierced ears.



</answer>



<answer from>



i&lt;3laura
Member since: 12 April 2007
Total points: 5999 (Level 5)

i have friends who pierced their babies ears around 2-3 months

Why does my 9 month old shake his head "no" a lot?

Your child is on the right track.

<question from>

<question>



When going out do you care more about what your babies wearing or what your wearing?



Ive always been a girly girl and getting ready to go out somewhere is always somthing I find fun. Choosing what to wear etc. But Ive noticed since having my daughter I care more about dressing her up nice then myself. . I love choosing cute little outfits for her and getting her all pretty and I dont get that into what Im wearing anymore. As long as she looks cute as a button Im ready to go. haha. What about you?



</question>



<answer from>



ILoveMyB...
Member since: 06 June 2007
Total points: 6812 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



lol me too! I used to go through 10 diff outfits in one hour with me, now n I do it with her! lol. okay maybe not 10 but 5! I love having her wear sundresses when its hot and cute little pink sleepers with hoodies. and a lot of guys notice her too, they always say what a beautiful baby she is, lol. I dont fix myself up half as much I used to---I now just do the bare minimum--brush my teeth, wash my face quickly, shower, put on deodorant, brush my hair, and have decent clothes on. while I spend an hour or two getting her ready---picking out an adorable outfit, combing her hair, washing her little face and behind her ears, clipping her nails, etc.



Except today was an exception: I actually didnt spend as much today getting her ready as I did myself. Today I not only showered and shaved my legs (looooong overdue!), but I also put some hairspray in my hair, flossed for once, put some moisturizer on my skin, and lipstick! this was all while she was (and still is) sleeping, taking her afternoon nap.
But yes, I agree. And I find I get more joy in gettng her fixed up than I do myself. I guess its partly bc shes new news, and also bc I know I dont have to worry about people judging her based on what shes wearing since shes just a baby, lol, so I can have more fun.



Source(s):



mom to a 3 1/2 month old girl



</answer>

<question>



Can my last name be put on a childs Social Security card?



Here's the thing, my ex got pregnant and had a child and she says it's mine, if it is then fine. But the thing is we haven't done a paternity test yet, but the child has my last name on their SSC, is that legal? i haven't signed or done anything yet that pertains to the child.



</question>



<additional details>



no my name isn't on the birth certificate. i thought i had to sign my name on the birth certificate? i havent done that.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Hunter P
Member since: 06 December 2007
Total points: 463 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes it is legal. If when the baby is born and they ask the mother what the name of the child is and they say for instance "John Smith" then thats the name. Regardless if Smith is the father or not or if she even knows a Smith. Just get the paternity test done if you have doubts and go from there. Just because she named the baby after you does not mean you have any responsibility for the child if the child turns out to not be yours.



</answer>



<answer from>



Hope S
Member since: 21 May 2008
Total points: 2453 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Is your name on the birth certificate. If so then it is legal. The name on the child's birth certificate is the name that has to be on the ssc. If you are that worried that the child isn't yours then you need to get a blood test done ASAP.



Source(s):



TTC #2 still



</answer>



<answer from>



rustybon...
Member since: 10 June 2006

I would contact a lawyer. If the child was given your last name, at birth, then yes, it's legal.

<original file>4790.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk93646.txt</current file name>




<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Newborn & Baby



</category>



<question from>



lovey
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 97 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



My 10 month old will not sleep more than two hours a night.?



he will sleep about three hours thru the day and about three half an hour naps. I constantly keep him active during the day and keep him entertained but he just naps an half an hour. At night i have a full bedtime routine for him by giving him a warm bottle,putting on the baby channel,and getting him washed up but he goes to sleep at two in the morning and gets up at 4 am and goes back to sleep at 7 in the morning then sleeps til 4pm.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



do you rock him to sleep or using other soothing methods to put him to sleep ? the best is to try and teach them to sleep on their own, which is a difficult and painful process but it works. also put him down in his cot the same time every night and he will get the idea it is sleep time. also cut out the baby channel and read nighttime stories to him instead. tv is very stimulating for them especially before going to sleep. also wake him up gently the same time every morning after say 11-12 hours of sleep. in most cases they will wake up on their own. if he wakes up during the night, the best is to pat him lightly on his bum and tell him to go back to sleep and you leave the room.



it is a painful process as he will protest but it will work out in the end. just persevere. also establish a daytime routine for him.



</answer>

<question>



What is the Babywise method?



My 6 month old son has always been hectic when he came to getting and staying asleep ever since we came home from the hospital. Around 3 months old, There was a point where he would be asleep by 8pm after his bath and feeding. He would sleep for 4 hours. He would go back to sleep after I fed him and waking up 4 hours later. That only lasted less than a month. He now wakes up every 1-3 hours of a night crying. He naps like twice a day with the naps only lasting like 25-45 minutes at most. We've tried every thing so far on getting him to and staying asleep while doing the whole nightly routine. He sleeps in our bed during the night even though his crib is in the same room. I'm at the point where I dont even sleep AT ALL because he wakes up so often and it's unpredictable.



I was reading online and heard of the baby wise method. The only thing I've gathered online is that it's scheduled feeding that involved 'snacking'.  I know every baby is different and like I said, he pretty much has been this way since he was born. He's not teething.

<answer from>

srhgreco
Member since: 19 September 2008

<answer>

<answer>



i havent heard of the baby wise method, I have heard the book save our sleep is really good.

Hope this helps



Source(s):



mum of baby boy 6mths.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kelly P
Member since: 01 January 2008
Total points: 2648 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The babywise method is full-on - and is usually easier if started when a baby is younger but will work for older babies too.  It is about parent led feeding - not clock, or demand.  For me it seemed very routine and quite strict aswell although it says its not about looking at the clock, but also about taking other things into consideration and then making a decision about feeding your baby.  I tried it with my son when he was about 9 weeks old, and it did seem to work for a couple of weeks until he went through a growth spurt and although the book apparently makes allowance for that, I found it extremely hard to get him back on track after that.  He was a '45 minute' sleeper which the book also talks about, but nothing I tried could get him to nap longer than that during the day - Babywise seriously screwed up my confidence in my parenting skills with my first baby - until I literally threw it across the room and took the advice of a midwife friend that said when he got older and more active he would start napping for longer - which he did,  it was just him - for the first 6 months he would be up for an hour down for 45 minutes - which is why I found babywise so hard because of the main thing it teaches is the feed/play/sleep schedule which I do agree with but if you are trying to get your baby into a 3 hour routine and he is only up for 1 hour and down for 45 minutes you are pretty much feeding every 2 hours in order to keep to that routine!  My second child was a 'babywise baby' without me even needing to do anything - she naturally put herself in a 3 hour routine, was a great sleeper and only feed because she was hungry, not for snacking or comfort!!  All the best, my advice read the books (most of which contradict each other) but only take out the bits that suit you and use your own intuition rather than try and stick to what the books say as it can end up stressing you out more than the situation itself.  Also I found the best thing was not having the baby in the room as they can sense and smell you and I found I got less sleep especially having them in bed with me,  they are noisey things and do wake up but can also put themselves to sleep if left for a bit to,  for him waking up all the time is more habit rather than hunger and it sounds like you have a good bed time routine for him that is predictable so as long as you are putting him to bed awake, then as he is 6 months if you felt comfortable you could try the controlled crying method which will take a few hard nights but could work, otherwise for my son after we tried everything he just started sleeping through by himself at around 8 months around the same time his naps during the day also started getting longer.



</answer>

<question>



How often should you use wind drops?



My 7 week old son had problems with wind, so we got some Infacol wind drops.

Do you put them in every bottle, or every now and then when he displays wind issues??
