<question from>



Megan
Member since: 11 August 2008
Total points: 444 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Changing from lactose free to normal formula, slowly or all at once?



I asked earlier today whether I should try convert my 5mth old to normal milk as I have heard it is bad to keep them on lactose free. I know now that it wont effect how he handles lactose later if I stay with the lactose free stuff, but I do want to change him over onto normal milk based formula (mainly as there is only 2 places in town I can get his lactose free stuff and its expensive).



Should I just switch it altogether at once, or do it gradually?



Of course if he doesnt go well with it, I will go back to lactose free...



</question>



<answer from>



Mom
Member since: 17 February 2007
Total points: 12806 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Do it gradually over time.  With my son, my doctor had me replace one bottle a day with normal formula... then if he tolerated it ok, the next day we went up to two bottles, etc.



Also - the first time you try it, do it first thing in the morning.  that way if god forbid he has a bad reaction, you can see your doctor, or if he has an upset stomach from  it, it has the entire day to work through it (rather than you being up all night).



Good luck!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Doing it in the morning is a good idea, thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



malwilhi...
Member since: 17 February 2007
Total points: 27962 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



Very gradual over a week or two of time. 1 oz new to 3 oz old for 3-4 days. Then up it to 2 and 2, then 3 and 1, etc.



</answer>



<answer from>



christie
Member since: 22 June 2006
Total points: 992 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You know, my daughter is 6 month and on breastmilk and ocassionaly soy milk or lactose free.
I tried to give her goodstart formula or enfamil, she would threw up an hour after that.
She could tolerate the regular formula only from Similac, but make her gassy all day long.
I try to introduce her slowly to regular formula but she would threw up all the time, so I stop.
I was lactose intolerance when I was a baby, after a year my mom just introduced whole milk right away, and here I am, can enjoy anything milk.
I just don't want to make my baby suffer, because when she threw up, she'll cry and uncomfortable (she barely spit up on soy or breastmilk).



</answer>

<answer>



I saw this baby shower wreath once that was really cute, and the mother could take it apart and use it or just keep it as a decoration for the babies room.  They took the some metal wire and made it into a wreath shape.  Then they twisted those little baby blankets around it and tied them in place with ribbon.  Next, they used safety pins to pin things on it like booties, diapers, rattles, pacifiers, ect... and made a big bow at the top.  If your pretty crafty, I think that would be a good idea, and if it doesn't turn out looking so great or you don't wanna spend that much time making it, you can always put items in a basket like gift baskets you give at x-mas time(you always need things like diapers or feeding supplies).
Another idea is to buy the mother a baby scrapbooking kit, because almost any mother would love something to put pics in, and maybe you could help get her started with taking pics for her of the baby shower, delievery, ect...(depends if your gonna be at those events).  Also, if your gonna spend big or go in with some other people you could get her the scrapbook kit and a digital camera!
Hope this helps!

<answer>



I broke mine at about 18months - 2yrs old.  With both we had them throw their binkies in the trash and then took the bag out so they knew they were gone. <answer>



With my eldest daughter, i was scared of her becoming too attached to it, as i heard that it is hard to get a baby of a dummy, once they are older. So at around 6 months old i just stopped giving it her at once and she was fine, not bothered at all. My second daughter never had 1, tried to give it to her a few times, spat it out, so never persisted with it. I think the earlier you take it away the easier it will be. Goodluck

<answer from>



wl
Member since: 04 October 2008
Total points: 533 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think it just depends on how each toddler tolerates it and how often they need their pacifier.  My family has always started "hiding" the pacifier as the toddler starts to transition from bottles to "sippy" cups.  Maybe start "hiding" it and try to re-direct their attention (play, watch tv, ect) if they ask for it.  I think it would be okay to let them have it a little for comfort like at bedtime or if they are sick, so they aren't stressing out over it.  Maybe start introducing more "chewy" type foods to them also, like carrot sticks so that they have something healthy to replace the need for wanting to chew or suck on the pacifier.  I think it's up to every parent to decide how they want to wean their child from the pacifier, but I think it's okay to do it gradually as well as cold turkey.  As long as they still don't want it by the time they start school, I don't think there is really a particular age that they should stop it. Good luck!



</answer>

<question from>



Yukorak
Member since: 30 June 2007
Total points: 1022 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



7-8 mth old baby waking through the night, why?



Hello, I'm looking for some ideas from more experienced parents!



Our son has a history of sleeping well through the night since around 2-3 mths. From 7 months he has started waking in the early hours and is comforted only by being held. I have a few theories as to why this might be the case borrowed from psychology; i.e. attachment anxiety, stress from beginning nursery / moving home / traveling, or simple learnt behaviour from being rewarded with attention. Teething is a probability since he has broken two teeth in the last few weeks.



I teach developmental psychology and have a habit of over thinking things and am probably missing the obvious things that more experienced parents will know. I would appreciate any ideas or suggestions to help through this difficult period.



He sleeps in his own room and has done since 2 months.
He goes down at 7pm with a feed, and is fed again at 10:30pm and used to sleep through till 6:30am. Now he wakes at 1am-3am and refuses food (unless he cries until 3am and has worked up an appetite). All he really wants is cuddles when he awakens, he has comfort objects but only his main carers will do in the small hours.



I hope I have provided enough info and appreciate any shared experiences or guidance from an experienced parent.



</question>



<answer from>



BEC~ ~Lucy's~ ~Mummy~
Member since: 07 June 2007
Total points: 11910 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



I think you are pretty spot on to be honest.
I love this website....It is very interesting and helped to shed a little light on the cognitive development processes that may affect bub's sleeping patterns
http://moxie.blogs.com/askmoxie/2006/02/...



I must say I love your question... The but where you say you have a habit of overthinking things.... your question really exemplifies how much thought you put into things. It is well worded and informative. I really hope that this comment doesn't offend you but just remember that your child is not a case study. He is your baby and many babies don't fit into the mold of a text book. I say this because I am a speech pathologist and it took me a few months to realise this. I was so used to concentrating on the theory that I had neglected to see my daughter as an individual.



The only other thing I can suggest is to realise that there is no set length of time for this to continue. My daughter slept through the nigth until about 5 months.... I've been telling myself since then that her terrible sleeping patterns are "just a phase".... but I've recently decided that her pattern has simply changed. This is the way babies work too....just when you think you've got them figured out they change their routine and you have to start "figuring" all over again



I hope that helps and like I said, I'm sorry if I offended you at all



ALSO



Given your background, you may find these article interesting
http://www.cyh.com/HealthTopics/HealthTo...
http://baby.families.com/blog/stages-of-...
Maybe your son is experiencing one of these "fussy stages"



</answer>



<answer from>



lovelayn...
Member since: 05 October 2008
Total points: 164 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



My son always slept through the night, but I wasn't so lucky with my daughter (now 4). She would wake a few times during the night. Her doctor told me to try letting her "cry it out" when she cried in the middle of the night and another doctor told me NOT to let her cry. I tried to comfort her at first and when that didn't work I tried the "not going to get her no matter how much she cries" method. I broke down before she did, she's very persistent.



I may not have tried long enough but when the babies crying at 3 am and you haven't slept in a few nights it's hard to stick to. I remember calling my husband when he was away and I would be sitting outside her door just waiting for her stop (sometimes I was in tears too). I gave up on that method and then we tried changing her eating schedule. It worked like a charm. As you know though all babies are different :-)



I would try feeding him a bit later.



Good luck



Source(s):



Two children, ECE credits, experiences :-)



</answer>

<question>



If you saw yourself running low on formula?

i just read a question that someone had ran out of formula and was it ok to mix with rice or cereal until monday!!!! keeping in mind, this is friday, and the Baby was 3 1/2 mos old!



i know that if i see i only have a day or two left, i always buy more, so as not to be without, and we have a few cartons stashed away just in case. and if the worst came to the worst i would swallow my pride and ask to borrow some money!



so what do you guys think? even if you breast feed, what would you do in this situation?

i always have plenty for my son



the person was already on WIC!



WIC is something in america to help low incomes with food for babies, i think, not exactly sure.
the person is NOT  my friend, i don't know who they are it was a question i read.



we also have very little money, but we manage! :)



it doesn't take you to be well educated to know that you need formula for your baby if you aren't going to breast feed

<answer from>



The cat did it.
Member since: 25 March 2006

<answer>



My first two were sitting by 4 months old.  My third is now 17 weeks old and has discovered the world of the vertical as well, lol... We are working with him to get him to sit up.  It really opens up a lot of things when they can start sitting up on their own.  It frees up your hands  a whole lot!!!!  I don't think it is too early at all.  All babies are different, if yours is showing interest in sitting, then great!!  Let her sit, lol.
I remember with my first son, I had read that by 4 mo they should be sitting so when I went into my sons 4 month well check I told the doc that I could not get him to sit up.  So he sat my son up and placed his lil legs just so and boom, he was sitting.  LOL... I can tell you my life got a lot easier after that!!!!  When my two older ones were lil we didn't have all these fancy gadgets, lol, to help them sit, we actually used a small box with blankets in it to help them learn to sit...



Anyway!!!  Next is scooting, or soldier crawling... then it gets really fun, lol!!!  Enjoy!!  :)



</answer>

<question>



Oh hate to ask this again ?



how do you put in a pic instead of avatar



</question>



<additional details>



ok did that but no pic is showing what nw



ok did that but no pic is showing what now



oh know i have wanted to put a pic of son for a long time and it won't work go figure



oh i do not think its a jpg let me try a different one



thanks thought i was in the 360 but i was in a different profile page thanks a bunch got it now



</additional details>



<answer from>



v´¯)-» мaяк's ωifee
Member since: 10 February 2007
Total points: 22995 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You have to make a 360º web page through Yahoo! then use the Yahoo! web page picture as your default.



CLICK "My Profile" .. then
CLICK "My 360º page" ..then
CLICK "My Page" .. then
CLICK "Add/Edit Photo" .. then
"UPLOAD" photo.



Then you use the uploaded photo as your avatar.
(when you're finished with the steps above)
CLICK "My Profile" again .. then "Edit Info" .. then instead of using your avatar as the picture, click "Use 360º picture."



Edit to ADD:
The picture that you upload has to be a .jpg file!



Did you create a page??
Did you upload a (.jpg.) photo to the page?
click save?



When you're in your page (you can upload 3 picture) click the circle next to the picture you want (it's a tiny dot on the right) and click SET AS DEFAULT.



Then go back to your profile and hit 'Use my Yahoo! 360 Picture.'



and it should pop up as your avatar! =]



Edit to ADD again!:
YAY! I see it! He's a cutie!!! =]



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks a bunch and yeah he is a cutie and he always flirts with the girls



</asker's comment>

<answer>



Yes Diabetes is hereditary. Type II diabetes can be avoided by proper diet and excercise, however, Type 1 is develpoed when at a very young age and most people are insulin dependant for life. However, not every body will get it. Just keep an eye out and look for signs of excess sleeping or lethargy and make sure you mention it to the ped. he will run routine tests to make sure your baby is fine.....

<question>



My 5month old baby came home with a foul smell...what would you do?



Let me give you a little background as to what happened.....My son goes to a home day care where he is the only baby and the only other child at the day care is like 2yrs old. I chose this daycare when I was returning to work after my maternity leave.



On this particular morning, I rang the doorbell and no one answered right away. When the door was opened for me, my son's caregiver's grandson (who by the way 30yrs old) had no shirt on, with a doo-rag on his head let me in. Well, Ms. R (thats what we'll call her) came from the back of the house, still in her nightgown and the other little boy with her. They both looked like they both just woke up. I was a little disturbed that she wasn't up and ready to receive my son that morning. I shouldn't have had to wake her. I was running late and decided not to question it right then and there.



Well, when I picked my baby up after work. She was still in her night gown. When I got home, took off his pram suit I smelled a very foul odor on my baby. Not to be disgusting but he strongly smelled musty and un-washed private parts (of a woman that is). I had to take my son's clothes off immediately, give him a bath, lotion him up and put on his jammies. My husband was outraged.



I spoke to her this morning about it and she claimed it didn't come from her but from her grandson who she says does not wash up. By the way, if you're wondering, HE DOES NOT EVEN LIVE THERE.



Mrs. R is an older lady of about her 60's or early 70's. I didn't want to offend her bcuz of her age but I had no other choice to speak on it. I don't believe it was her grandson bcuz I asked did her grandson handle my baby. She said no but then why would my baby smell like that if he is stinky?



What would you have done? SERIOUS ANSWERS ONLY!!



</question>

<answer from>



E D

</answer from>



<answer>



Mother's day out. Give yourself time to catch your breath, regain your composure, and make your time with your child quality time. It really doesn't matter what you do, well do stuff that is focused only on you and relaxes you, not chores or errands.



Good luck. I was in the USAF for 8 years myself.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ms.Estes
Member since: 08 February 2008
Total points: 1072 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I know how you feel.  I'm a full-time student with a full-time job and single parent (my fiance is currently in prison).  Here are some ideas.
•  Cut back on chores — and use that time to put your feet up, nap, or read a book. (if it's possible)
•  Take advantage of sick days or vacation whenever possible. Spending a day — or even an afternoon — resting at home will help you get through a tough week.
•  Try deep-breathing exercises
•  Get regular exercise such as swimming or walking  You can take your baby with you.
•  Do your best to eat a healthy, well-balanced diet so you have the physical and emotional energy you need.
•  Get some sleep while you can.  When your baby is sleeping just take a nap with him/her.
•  Find a babysitter and go out with some friends
.



</answer>

<answer>



I was told this and I was glad I was told this because it's true even if new parents don't want to admit it....



Newborn babies are BORING!  They don't do anything.  THey eat, sleep, cry and poop.  They don't start to get interesting until about 6+ weeks..so don't feel bad if while baby is sleeping one day you look down and think "Man, am I bored."  I love my son with all my heart but he was so boring in the beginning, now he's a whirlwind of fun.



Enjoy your baby....oh...one more thing....



Just because someone gives you advice...you don't have to follow any of it.  Just smile and nod and go about doing things the way you want to do them.

<answer from>



MJ MCK
Member since: 30 March 2006
Total points: 3626 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had never been around babies at all either.  My DS is 16 weeks old now.  If there was one thing I could have differently was NOT TO WORRY SO MUCH!  I worried and worried and worried that I wasn't doing things right, I worried every time he cried, etc...  Babies are a lot more sturdy than we think.  There are times I wish I could turn back the clock to the day he was born and start over.



Just relax and enjoy the special closeness when your baby is so small!  Don't worry about cleaning the house!  Sleep when your LO sleeps!  Don't be afraid to ask for help!  Oh, and if you are going to breastfeed, you may want to limit your visitors to just people you will feel comfortable exposing your breasts to.  You will be breasfeeding about every hour or two while you are in the hospital - and also ask to use a breast pump to help your milk come in sooner.  Also remember your hormones are still out of whack, so you will be very emotional for a couple of weeks!



Oh - and my great aunt told me that the first 3 months are ALL WORK, and after that is gets soooo much easier - and she was right!



</answer>



<answer from>



Carters Mommy
Member since: 01 February 2007
Total points: 13936 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Actually I got told TOO MUCH stuff.  I expected the baby to be up all day and night, crying constantly, I expected to never be able to clean or take a shower, I expected everything to just be a mess.  They lie to you!  The first couple of months baby sleeps all day and all night waking every 2-4 hours to eat, and then falls right back to sleep.  I really expected to be up all day every day going to babies needs.  Newborns don't need much.  A clean diaper, a warm sleeper, a warm bottle, maybe a bouncer and they are set.  You have plenty of time to clean, take a shower, cook, and even take a FEW naps (not just one) during the day.  It's not until 4 months and up they start getting active and everything is a challenge to get done.  But by that time you have developed a routine that baby is used to and you can still get things done.  I literally thought my house was going to be a disaster for the first year or two, and that we would not know what ahome cooked meal was for a long time.  It's not as "hard" as people make it sound.



Here is some info I wish I knew before I delivered.  You still experience "contraction" like pain a few days after baby is born due to your uterus going down.  When we were leaving the hospital they gave me a prescription for pain killers and I said "oh I dont need that, I'm not that sore I'll be fine."  Well my first night home I found out what that prescription was for.  It was the middle of the night and Iwas woken up with pains like I was going into labor.  No pharmacy was open so I couldn't get my prescription until the next morning.



</answer>



<answer from>



kitra
Member since: 22 October 2007
Total points: 1272 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Be ready for post-partum depression. I wasn't prepared for it with my first baby and when the 'baby blues' hit it was terrible. I cried for two days and was ready to send the baby back, I was so tired, sleep-deprived, trying to breast feed, and sore from an episiotomy. Hubby was working full time and I had no one to help me out. When I had my second, I knew it was coming. That made it a little easier, but my angel was my mother-in-law. She was there to help me, hug me, and cry with me. It made a world of difference.
So my advice: accept help until you're ready to fly solo, don't worry about house-keeping, etc. - let someone give you a hand. You'll need to sleep when the baby sleeps at first until that sleep schedule gets on track. Don't be too hard on yourself if you feel overwhelmed...it gets better!



</answer>



<answer from>



momoftwi...
Member since: 14 August 2008
Total points: 3149 (Level 4)



</answer from>

That I may need to seek extra help for household chores. Ends up being that the first three months, all they do is eat, poop and sleep. You have plenty of time to clean up, take showers, watch t.v
the only thing that was correct is the little sleep you get. I got maybe one hour every five hours of sleep.
Good luck and Congrats

Question: If I pump 7 times a day I can provide 90% of the milk my daughter needs. If I drop a couple of pumps my milk supply decreases considerably and I can provide only 60% - 50%.
Of course my baby is more gassy and fussy with more formula.
What would you do in my place?



Thank you for reading.

<question>



Swaddling question... kind of?



Ok, so I swaddle my son when he goes to sleep. This morning I woke up and he had wiggled down into the middle of it kind of. I couldn't see his head at all :(



It scared the crap out of me, but I've seen him wiggle when he was partially waking up. I suppose he could have made a noise while half waking up that woke me up.



Anyway, I uncovered him right away. It was dark, so I didn't see if he had lost any color, but the second I picked him up he responded. And like 2 minutes later (after I had calmed down) I turned on the lights and he looked fine.



It was a slightly heavier blanket than a receiving blanket, only because I had read on a site about swaddling that it was ok to use a heavier or flannel blanket if it was cold... Which it is in my room.



Anyway, I know loss of oxygen can cause problems, so my question is... Do you think he'll be ok?



I'm too worried to sleep. And I only got like 2 hours of sleep. Next time I'll know better and use a lighter blanket...



</question>



<additional details>



I've tried not swaddling him, but he won't sleep without it unless he's on his tummy (on mine or my husbands chest) and I'm too afraid to lay him on his tummy in his bassinet.



Plus he's only 3 weeks old, lol. I'm not trying to swaddle an older baby or anything.



I think I was half awake and I heard him sneeze or something. I remember hearing a noise that made me want to move and check. Which is why I think he'll be ok too, I think I just want to hear it. Lol



Maybe I'll try that. He doesn't seem to like it as much as he used to, and keeping an arm out would keep it off his head too. Quite a good idea... Thanks :)



And I know I should just leave the room warm... But we've been sleeping in the living room out of laziness lol. So I didn't bother to check the room temp earlier to make sure it was warm. I tried using a receiving blanket but he was so fussy. Once he was warm he calmed, and I was so tired...



I can't help but feel like a bad mommy sometimes. I feel like I'm always doing something wrong. And I often correct my husband because of my own insecurities, and then he gets mad because he says I treat him like he doesn't know how to take care of him. And then I feel worse and can't explain.



Anyway, thanks guys. Maybe I'll get some sleep. But probably not lol.



</additional details>

<answer>



Aw, you poor thing!! I can only imagine how scary that must've been. I imagine that since he responded imediately, he'll be fine. If he had lost enough oxygen to cause any damage, he would've passed out (consciousness goes first, then brain cells are affected).



Also, my friend actually puts a blanket over her baby (he's 10 months) when he is going to sleep... seems totally crazy to me....she says he does it himself to get to sleep so now she just does it for him. It is just a light blanket but she puts it over his face and then once he falls asleep she takes it off!!! I know...it sounds MAD, but the point is, the boy is fine.



I'm sure your little man will be perfectly ok



ETA



Try swaddling him with his arm(s) out. Lucy used to wiggle out from about 3 weeks onwards, but wouldn't sleep without it. I left one arm out and that kept her happy for another week, then the other arm had to be left out.... another week or so and she was sleeping unswaddled



ETA (again)



You're not a bad mummy!! You're a new mummy and you're still learning .... in fact the learning will never stop. There is ALWAYS something to feel guilty about when it comes to motherhood but you made an honest mistake. If you had've know what may have happened I am 100% positive you would not have done it.



Say it with me now (lol)....YOU ARE A GREAT MUMMY!!!!!!

<answer from>



wl
Member since: 04 October 2008
Total points: 533 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm sure he will be okay.  Yes, loss of oxygen can potentially cause problems; however, it sounds like he wasn't lossing any for too long.  I work in the medical field, and if a baby "looses oxygen" they will turn blue and usually need some extent of resuscitation to resume breathing.  I wouldn't worry since he had good color.



About the swaddling....it's not reccommend to swaddle a baby while they sleep.  It is better to make sure the temperature in the room is nice and warm and not use covers on babies that aren't old enough to move the covers away.  Just like the potential problem swaddling caused you, it can "smother" a baby no matter how thick or thin the blanket is if the baby is unsupervised.  It's okay to use the things that help hold the baby to keep them from rolling around, but as a general rule, the less in the crib the better.  It's okay to swaddle your baby if your gonna be awake and be able to see him, but not at night while your sleeping and may not hear him (if the blanket's over his face he may not be able to cry).
Please...don't think your a bad mother or anything either.  Almost everyone swaddle's their babies at night instead of warm the room, so it's something you and alot of people probably don't even realize.



I hope this helps you out a little.



</answer>

<answer>



Hello doctor, I don't want your advice because I trust perfect strangers on the internet better. And this has nothing to do with my parental abilities.

<answer from>



wl
Member since: 04 October 2008
Total points: 533 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had a friend that wanted to solely breast feed and after a couple of weeks the doctor told her to start including formula in the baby's diet as well because of the nutruition in it.  Her problem was not enough iron and the doctor said it would help with that, but it also had many other things that would help with developement.  Her doc said it was really hard to provide all the nutrients your baby need with just breast milk even if you ate a perfect diet for breastfeeding.  You should discuss this with your baby's doctor so that he could reccommend a formula that may be better to start with.  It also helped her with "filling up" with too much milk due to irregular feeding, because if the baby got hungry at a odd time or wanted to eat more she could give formula too.  Good luck!



</answer>

BEC~ ~Lucy's~ ~Mummy~

<answer>



I moved my daughter at about 6 weeks. There were two main reasons:
Everytime she woke up I'd resettle her automatically...even though all she'd do was toss and turn for about 10 seconds and resettle so easily without me, I'd automatically put me hand on her. I didn't want her getting used to that happening every hour



But the main reason is that she outgrew her bassinet and we couldn't fit the cot in our room. She is a long baby and very active, she was hitting her head on the side of the bassinet so we thought she'd be better off in the cot



She made the transition very easily and so did we. She slept through the night and I only checked on her when I woke up (which wasn't often lol).



She's now no longer sleeping through (she's 8 months and If she sleeps for 3 hours in a row it's a good night lol), and we've moved ...there is room in our bedroom for the cot now so we are thinking of putting her in there so I don't have as far to go when she wakes up



</answer>

<answer>



My babies stayed in my room for the first few nights of their lives only, after that they were in there own room. I use a baby monitor. I have never had a problem with my girls and sleeping, one 3 and half, and other 7months, they are and were familiar with their surroundings. I'd sleep much better coz even the littlest movement or slightest murmur would wake me and that in turn would wake up babies.



</answer>



<answer from>



Erin R
Member since: 26 April 2008
Total points: 267 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



My son got his own room as soon as we finally moved into a 2 bdrm place. lol. He was just shy of one year. My son has always been a good sleeper so he was fine, so were we. I was just worried about not being able to hear him but a baby monitor does the trick. Also before we go to bed I will open his door a bit and leave ours open as well. He also sleeps with a very dim light on although Im not sure he really cares.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ktloop
Member since: 18 August 2007
Total points: 2698 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I did it at exactly 6 months. She was absolutely fine, slept for longer than she used to in our room !! I didn't sleep as well though !! It was so sad and strange not to have her there next to me !! and obviously you worry more, but you soon get used to it, and its nice to get your bedroom back :)

<question>



Lactose free formula bad for baby?



My baby has a lactose intolerancy. Until we kinda experiement with solids, we dont know what degree of intolerancy it is.. he was switched to lactose free formula when he was about 3 weeks old by a baby nurse.



Lately I have heard that by giving them no lactose, you are killing any chance their bodies have of building up the ability to deal with lactose later. Is this true.. should I switch to normal formula and see how he goes? They can grow out of lactose intolerance depending on the level of the reaction they have to it. I just hope I am not stopping his body from learning how to di that.



</question>



<answer from>



sweet
Member since: 22 August 2008
Total points: 2621 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



that is soooo not true...both of my babies were on lactose free formula, I switched them to one because they both had trouble with gas and spit up and the lactose free was like night and day and they both had no more gas and stop spitting up....both of them can now drink milk and eat diary with absolutely no problems what so ever



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Its good to hear a real experience. Thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Larisa B
Member since: 07 June 2007
Total points: 535 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes babies can outgrow there lactose intolerance. I would try the other formula (milk based) and see how it goes all you can do is try, my middle son had the same problem and at the age of 9 months we switched from Enfamil Lacto Free to Enfamil with Iron and we had no problems, actually became a more content baby, no more gas (well as bad anyway). This was almost ten years ago and I know they have made huge advances with formula and are much better than they used to be so I would give it a shot. Good luck...:)



</answer>



<answer from>



Em
Member since: 26 October 2006
Total points: 5612 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



When you find that you want to introduce cows milk simply do it in slow stages and the lactase (the enzyme that deals with the lactose) can gradually increase. When you're ready I'd start with yoghurt and then mix in a little cows milk with the formula and build up. The lactase just needs time to increase in production, if there is no lactose it virtually disappears, so just build it up



</answer>



<answer from>



Mrs Apple
Member since: 05 May 2006
Total points: 8313 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



My son drank Nutramigen formula when he was born.  This formula is lactose free and soy free.  We started our son on soy formula because I am lactose intolerant.  We ended up realizing that he was allergic to soy and milk.  My son is 2 now.  He drinks Vitamin D milk and eats dairy products.  My son is perfectly healthy.



</answer>



<answer from>



Darianna
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 121 (Level 1)

If your child is really allergic then basic formula can hurt him!!

<answer>



i breastfed my little girl until she was 1!!
ok u need to relax a little, u r both new to this and are still learning.
your milk sounds like its coming in today so she is more than likely getting the milk she needs from her short feeds the same as when she fed for a while.
i would advice keeping her on one breast until she is due her next feed, as the breast starts like a 3 course dinner, with fore milk and hind milk in the back so she is getting the right amount!! the trick with breastfeeding, is to relax enjoy and feed on demand, u cant go wrong this way, if herNappy'ss are wet and she seems content in every other way she is fine!! good luck  xx

<question from>



Minnie
Member since: 09 October 2007

</question from>



<question>



My baby is not sleeping as well now moved into cot?



He was in a mose basket up until 3 days ago and was sleeping from 8am to about 5am then back to sleep till 8am after a bottle. Since moving him to the cot he has been up at 1.30am then again at 5am. Does anyone have any tips?



</question>



<answer from>



Ktloop
Member since: 18 August 2007
Total points: 2698 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am sure he will get used to it, there is a big difference in size of a moses basket and a cot, he will not feel so 'secure' in the cot. You could try putting the moses basket in the cot, put him down in the moses basket for a couple of nights, he will get used to the location etc of the cot, then take the moses basket away , this can sometimes help.



I borrowed a crib off a friend, so went from moses basket , to crib (much smaller than a cot) then onto cot . Hope this helps , good luck :)



</answer>



<answer from>



jackie n
Member since: 06 May 2007
Total points: 1337 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



put something in his cot with your scent on it to comfort him like a sweater that you have worn for 2 days  also make sure he is wrapped snug try the moses basket in the cot for a while first the bigger space is making him feel insecure



</answer>

<question>



Has anyone tried the Brauer brand "calm"?



For those that don't know, Brauer is a homeopathic "medicine" range with products for teething, colic, etc etc
They also have one called "calm". It is supposed to be good for restless babies and those that don't sleep well.... also supposed to be good to facilitate sleep in for teething babies. It is all natural/herbal
Just wondering if anyone has tried it and whether they found it any good



</question>



<additional details>



I've actually had good results with the teething one. I had to restock today and saw this one and thought I might give it a go.



</additional details>



<answer from>



mystic_e...
Member since: 21 October 2006
Total points: 94079 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Generally speaking evidence suggests that homeopathics do not really work, but do no harm.  Most of the ones for babies are in a sugar base and sugar itself is a powerful medicine.



Just make sure that there are no nasty preservative (and "all natural" doesn't mean safe, I've seen some all natural products with sodium benzoate which is bad enough but even worse when they also add citric acid)



http://www.drgreene.org/body.cfm?id=21&a...
"We know that even a 12 percent solution of sugar can be a powerful drug, relieving measurable pain by half during a circumcision"



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks.... good to know they don't do any harm. I'm trying it tonight so we'll see what happens



</asker's comment>
